SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Telecommunications National Code 1996, made under subsection 117(1) of the Telecommunications Act 1991, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats have moved to disallow this code for two main reasons: firstly, because it has been a fundamentally flawed process; and, secondly, because of the inadequacy of the code to deliver any improvement on the previous code. Very few members of the public will realise that the new telecommunications code came into effect on 1 January this year. This is hardly surprising, given that the announcement was made the day before Christmas Eve. The code sets out procedures for installing and maintaining telecommunications facilities such as aerial cabling and mobile phone towers. The code was only tabled in parliament on 10 February, six weeks after it actually came into effect.

Sadly, this new code offers little to those battling the overhead roll-out of telecommunications cables and the unfettered siting of mobile phone towers. It ignores years of complaints and protests in Victoria, South Australia, Queensland and New South Wales in particular. Those who are aware of the code and its content, notably local councils and the Australian Local Government Association and its state based affiliates, argue that it is no better than the last code and that in many respects it is much worse. In fact, they say that it is so bad that it should be disallowed. This is why we are doing this here today.

This is a very strong statement from organisations and people who have so much at stake. We share their concern, and we are now calling on the Senate to do two things: firstly, to disallow the code and, secondly, to ensure that the post-1997 telecommunications regulatory regime gives local communities more say in locating towers and protecting streetscapes and heritage values.

Before I cover the specific reasons that make this code a worse outcome for residents, I would like to discuss the background of the code and the process by which it was produced. Senator Alston promised to introduce a new and tighter code by 1 July 1996—and this should not have been difficult. Austel had conducted a major review of the code and made 57 recommendations in December 1995; yet seven months elapsed before the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) eventually released a convoluted draft code for public comment, which largely ignored those recommendations.

Austel was then asked to conduct another inquiry on the draft and to report back by 9 August. The public was given only two weeks to provide comments in writing. By contrast, it is rumoured that the carriers were closely consulted in its development. I think it is interesting that the Austel report was never made public and that a final version of this code never appeared. In fact, only weeks after the review had been completed, the minister told me he had changed his mind. He said a new code would be a waste of time and effort since he would ensure proper planning and processes superseding the code would be in place by 1 July.

It was then revealed that cabinet was planning to support the roll‐out of aerial cabling for a further three months beyond 1 July 1997 and the existing guidelines for erecting mobile phone towers until the end of 1997. So to appease angry backbenchers and disgruntled residents in their electorates, the minister returned to his promise to introduce a new telecommunications national code. This is the code we have before us.

The process by which this code was developed deserves some very close scrutiny and raises, I think, many questions. On 3 December, a second draft code was released, although it was not then actually available, and another public inquiry was announced. This was the third public inquiry in just 12 months. This time, however, the inquiry was conducted by the Department of Communications and the Arts rather than Austel, which, the Democrats would argue, removed any semblance of independence.

The public was given until 19 December to comment on the draft. These dates, as I will reveal, hold a great deal of significance. Unfortunately for the organisations and councils which struggled to meet the deadline and to lodge submissions, they wasted their efforts. The new code now in force is dated 20 December 1996, 4.00 p.m., just 21½ hours after the close of submissions, yet the department was scheduled to report to the minister on the inquiry by 23 December, just four days after the closing of the inquiry. In actual fact, they reported on the 20th—the very day after submissions had closed.

I have a copy of a letter concerning the code from Senator Alston to the member for Mitchell, Mr Alan Cadman, dated 3 February. There are three things that need to be said about this letter, two of which are quite serious. The first is trivial. The letter completely brushes over the fact that there are transitional provisions in the Telecommunications Bill which will mean that the new planning regime will not take effect from 1 July. That is nothing serious, as I have al ready said, but we have become accustomed to statements from the minister which are less than informative. That was a notable omission no doubt intended to keep a backbencher in the dark whilst appearing to be doing something.
Secondly, the minister gives a completely different set of dates to the real ones, which I took from official documents. His letter says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The draft Code . . . was finalised on 5 December. The inquiry was held by my department between 5 December and 15 December. They reported to me on 23 December, and I immediately signed the appropriate documents to give effect to the new Code.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a significant difference between the inquiry closing on the 15th and reporting on the 23rd to one that closed on the 19th with a code printed by 4.00 p.m. on the 20th.

Through a freedom of information request by Mr Gavin Williamson of Cables Downunder in Sydney, we have been able to unearth information from the department of communications which brings to light even further inconsistencies. I will go through some of these. I have a minute from Ms Fay Holthuyzen of the department to the minister dated 20 December attaching a copy of the code which was adopted and asking for his signature by the 23rd, which is so signed. The minute states the inquiry was conducted between 5 December and 19 December—not the 15th, as the minister's letter declares—and, clearly, the final copy of the code was in existence and in the minister's possession on the 20th not on the 23rd. The obvious conclusion is that the minister is making deliberately misleading statements to his own backbench and to the public to cover‐up the fact that this inquiry was a complete farce.

Let us proceed and consider when the submissions were received and read. The minute to the minister has some very interesting comments on these points. The ALGA submission was received by officers conducting the inquiry at 1.10 p.m. on 20 December—the day the finalised draft of the code marked 4.00 p.m. went to the minister. Ten other submissions arrived on the 20th, while 85 were received by 6.30 p.m. on the 19th. Most of these, I expect, came in quite late. The minute says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: . . . the Department cannot guarantee that all issues in these submissions have been completely identified or fully addressed in this report.

SPEECH.PARA: It further says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Many submitters complained, some in strong terms, about the lack of time given to respond to the inquiry, which was widely regarded as inadequate, especially given the complexity of the document. A few submissions simply noted that because of the short time frame, they were not able to address the matters in the inquiry, or cited this as the reason for simply resubmitting their submissions to previous inquiries.

SPEECH.PARA: This should not be surprising. Copies were supposed to have been available on the web from 5 December. Yet I am informed that Manly Council downloaded on that day only to find that it was the old code. Gavin Williamson from Sydney Cables Downunder said he rang on the 5th to be told that the code was not available. He did not receive a copy until the 9th, while many others did not receive a copy until the 12th or 13th. Given that submissions had to be in Canberra by the 19th, they had to be posted by the 17th, which left many parties with only four or five days to study and comment on what was a very complex document. According to the departmental minute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: A number of submitters either object to or raise concern with the complexities of the revised draft Code. These submitters considered the revised draft Code to be overly legalistic and unnecessarily complex.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, appendix C of the minute, which outlines comments contained in the submission, is dated 21 December—that is, a day after the final draft had been prepared. So much for public consultation! We have seen another example of this with the recent telecommunications bills inquiry where scope for genuine consultation has been squashed. My comments on this will be in the minority report, so I will not repeat them here.

Another point made in the minute is that several submissions, although it does not say which, expressed concern that Austel should not be the body which monitors carrier compliance visual amenity issues given its qualifications and resourcing. Austel, however, has not been given the considerable resources it would need to undertake these and other new tasks. Predictably, the minister avoided answering my questions in parliament on this matter late last year.

Did anything change from the draft to the final? The minute also revealed that the majority of amendments to the draft code as a consequence of the inquiry had little or no effect in addressing the issues raised in the 96 submissions. The majority of the amendments to the code are cosmetic or they needed to patch up appalling drafting in the first place. In fact, I challenge the minister to give details of any amendments made to the code as a result of these submissions.

Some of the key amendments actually made things worse. For example, firstly, `maintenance' was amended to include `the installation of an additional facility' at Telstra's request. Surely maintenance is meant to cover repair or replacement of parts, not for additional installations. Secondly, the definition of a `major road intersection' at which undergrounding is to be mandatory was cunningly redefined out of existence. This was done by specifying that it is an intersection where there are three or more aerial cables strung in layers. Given that there are only two carriers stringing cables, it would be rare to find an intersection which qualified.

Thirdly, an impossible time frame of 15 days was imposed for a council to obtain written agreement from all occupier‐owners to pay for undergrounding, otherwise carriers could go overhead. But it is ludicrous to expect a council to be able to obtain within 15 business days, say, in an average suburban street of 80 homes, the written consent of all parties to agree to pay incremental costs. What happens if one party—only one—is sick, or in hospital, or on holidays or for other reasons away? The very proposal is simply preposterous.

I challenge the minister to explain how the Attorney-General's Department could have received advice from the department of communications after 6.45 p.m. on the 19th and possibly managed to redraft all of the amendments by the 20th. Let me return to the final point I want to make concerning the minister's letter to the member for Mitchell. It says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: I sought and obtained undertakings from the two carriers that they would comply with the new measures I had announced as if they were already in force.

SPEECH.PARA: I have copies of the letters from Telstra and Optus to the minister dated 9 December and 12 December respectively providing confirmation that they would immediately comply with the new draft code. The sheer and utter hypocrisy of this cannot be overstated. The minister had agreement from the two carriers that they would comply with the draft code at a time when most people who had requested copies were just beginning to receive them. The inquiry had effectively closed before it had begun. It is not surprising therefore that no significant changes were made, other than those recommended by the carriers.

The government had sought to legitimise the weakness of its measures by playing on fears of legal reprisal by the carriers. It claimed that carriers are operating under assurances that existing legislation and guidelines, guaranteeing carriers certain immunity from state and territory environment and planning laws, would operate until 1 July. Current revelations suggest otherwise, and I will leave it to the minister to prove otherwise.

The new code may have conned backbenchers, Minister, but it is no substitute for proper planning processes which would give the right to insist on the undergrounding of cables, infrastructure sharing and keeping phone towers away from kindergartens. The `greater protection for residents' has turned out to include little more than grey rather than black cables and mandatory undergrounding at major intersections. I do not know of one community or environment group that proposed grey cabling as a key solution to aerial cabling. I can only assume that it was a solution offered by the carriers because it costs no more. Even if the code is disallowed, they can of course do it in any case.

As I mentioned before, mandatory undergrounding at major intersections will occur only if it is in the interest of the carriers. Major intersections are not properly defined and the carriers are likely to respond to this requirement only if, for instance, heavy traffic would cause cables too much damage. The underground cable rollout is provided for, but only if impossible procedures are followed.

In terms of erecting mobile phone towers, the code supposedly empowers councils to suggest two alternative sites. However, there is nothing to prevent councils from nominating any number of sites under the old code, and this is something they do routinely. The suggestion was made but more often ignored, however, by the carriers. This is the problem with the new code; it does nothing about that. It simply says that they can nominate two alternative sites, and it continues to leave the final decision to the carriers.

One of the frustrations expressed by the ALGA was the fact that carriers can claim commercial in confidence in relation to the siting of their network of towers. Carriers do not have to justify their choice of sites and they can all too readily argue technical or economic reasons for doing this. Cables less than an arbitrary 13 millimetres in diameter continue to be exempted from planning processes, which means there is nothing preventing carriers stringing up bundles of cables, as long as each is less than 13 millimetres in diameter.

This code largely ignores the health impacts of telecommunications facilities. For example, an existing tower next to a school or a child-care centre can have extra banks of aerials without any concern for public health. The ALGA have pointed out further concerns. They say that it reduces the power of the environment secretary; it fails to provide adequate protection for sites of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander significance and for local heritage sites; it pushes the cost of undergrounding on to councils and residents, but at a price determined by the carriers; and it perpetuates a system under which the carriers are their own judge and jury, with very little effective scrutiny of their actions and they can ignore community views almost at will.

While the new code possibly includes some minor improvements to the previous codes, these improvements are largely of a cosmetic nature when compared with the problems I have already highlighted. Moreover, the code allows the government to take a further step away from responsibility for the substantial urban and environmental blight already created throughout Australia by cables and towers. The rejection of this code by the Senate will force national attention on the inadequacies of the policy framework in this area. The considerable damage already done to the urban environment can be corrected only by a carefully considered and strategic approach to reversing the policy framework which was implemented with major party consensus against the strong protestations of the Democrats in 1991.

It is essential that this code be disallowed not just because the outcomes are, on balance, worse for residents but also because the government and the carriers will use it as a smokescreen for further inaction. The Australian community has been treated with contempt by the minister, who staged a mock inquiry and installed a code which is in fact a sham. I fear it will now be used to legitimise the transitional provisions proposed for inclusion in the post-1997 regulatory regime. The carriers will say that they have given ground but that the new code imposes sterner requirements for consultation and hence they need or deserve a time extension beyond 1 July as a compensation.

The government will say that the transitional provisions are warranted because, after all, they have introduced a new and improved code. But the code itself is a farce. The process under which it was developed is a farce and it should be disallowed. As of 1 July this year, a proper system should be put in its place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, I indicate that we will not support the disallowance of the Telecommunications National Code 1996 made under subsection 117(1) of the Telecommunications Act 1991. I think in many ways Senator Allison has identified some of the deficiencies in the present code. She has certainly quite correctly identified the deficiencies in process of how the code was constructed. I think she has done that in detail.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not disagree that much of her criticism is effective—and we agree with it. However, if we disallow this code with all its deficiencies, from the opposition's point of view we will go back to a code that is even more deficient. I do not believe that having a pyrrhic victory of knocking off this code to go back to a worse code to make a political point at this moment is the correct way to proceed.

We have a process in this parliament at the moment when, either today or when we return in a week and a half, we will be debating the whole telecommunications package of bills on the regulatory regime to take place in Australia post 1 July 1997. In dealing with that legislation, all members of the Senate will have the opportunity to move amendments where they believe planning arrangements are deficient.
I believe that it is much better to overcome those deficiencies by having that debate and amending the legislation. That is why the opposition in its minority report, which was tabled yesterday—

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is putting it in the code.

—Senator Margetts, if you can just let me explain. In the area of immunities in particular, which is what Senator Allison's basic proposition is about the code—how the immunities operate and have been operating effectively in Australia since 1901 for telecommunications—I believe the issue she has raised should be dealt with in the legislation. In our minority report we have suggested amendments that I believe will much more effectively deal with the issues that Senator Allison has so quite correctly raised.

SPEECH.PARA: For example, the issue that has set the local government organisations and communities right across Australia into various forms of outrage, disappointment and disagreement is the program of overhead cabling and now the growing concern about the siting of mobile telephone towers. The present system, which is based on a 90-year history of immunities, clearly does not give the local community an effective say in opposing that infrastructure being built.

I believe that what we propose is the best way to proceed. Local government should be able to disagree and have the power to stop that significant infrastructure, such as cabling and towers, proceeding willy-nilly by the carrier. What we are proposing is a simple appeals mechanism; if the council and the carrier disagree, there is a straight appeal to the ACA to determine whether that facility should proceed.

You cannot let councils have an absolute blackball and an absolute opposition to building any telecommunications facility because, if you do, this parliament will never be able to carry out its responsibility, as it should, to construct a national telecommunications system to which all Australians have equity of access. Therefore, you have to balance the quite strong local concerns about siting of facilities, as Senator Allison has so eloquently described in many ways, with the national interest. By having an appeal process that we strongly support, you can get the balance right as far as you can.

In our amendments we say, as from 1 July, no more overhead cables unless local government agrees. I think that is going to be supported by everybody. The government wants to allow a further three months for further cabling to be completed. We disagree with that. Local communities have been under the very strong impression for about 18 months now that 1 July was the cut‐off date. We will stick to that when we debate that. That is a very important issue to be dealt with in the legislation, which is beyond what you can do within the code. Parliament will make that decision.

The next issue is mobile towers. In the legislation, the minister has proposed that low impact facilities continue to have the general immunities that have been in the legislation since Federation in effect for telecommunications. The minister has proposed that Austel conduct an inquiry—what will become the ACA, I suppose—into what constitutes a low impact facility.

BREAK.PARA: In most cases, I do not think there would be any argument even with local government about what those low impact facilities would be—what are ubiquitously described as pit and cable work, and ducting work that has been going on through the streets of Australia for a long time. It also wants to exempt what is already there—what has been built and so on—and I do not think anyone can argue that. No-one can argue about the need for proper access for maintenance of those low impact facilities.

What the opposition believes should be taken out of that inquiry and determined by parliament is telecommunications towers, whether they are for a mobile telephone system, microwave or whatever. Those sorts of facilities now declared as low impact ought to be taken out of that review and should be considered as a general facility, appealable by the local community to the ACA if they disagree with the carrier's intent. I believe that will take a lot of the sting out of the argument that communities have because they feel they are being dudded in the process of consultation.

I do not disagree that the way the carriers have carried on over the last few years has made this debate much more robust than has been necessary. The engineers and the carriers, whether associated with Optus, Telstra or even Vodafone, have continued to conduct themselves as though they are a monopoly with no responsibility to the local community. They have done themselves enormous damage in the local community. For that, they ought to be strongly criticised.

We have seen repeatedly the consultation process going on for some weeks, some months with the local community over the siting of a tower. But at the end, with usually only a very minor modification, the carrier says, `Well, we're going to build it there anyway.' That has created considerable disquiet, considerable anger in the local community. Therefore, it is only reasonable that now the towers should in no way be given the chance to be declared a low impact facility.

In considering the amendments moved by the opposition—and I think they are similar to the recommendations made by the Democrats in the minority report—it now ought to be declared that in no way will a tower end up being categorised as a low impact facility by the Austel review. Do not take the chance. If you do, it will come back to us for argument as a disallowable instrument. I do not think we ought to take that chance.

Overall, the amendments moved by the Opposition and some of the amendments moved by the Democrats in this legislation package, I think, offer a very good balance between the needs of a national telecommunications system and the rights of the local community. For the first time the local communities will be given a right of appeal over the carrier. That has never happened before in 96 years of federation and in the history of telecommunications. It has been a long time coming. The carriers, in my view, have basically brought this on themselves in the way in which they have proceeded in recent years with the roll‐out of cable, with the building of mobile towers.

But remember, the reason that mobile towers are going up is because millions of Australians are becoming subscribers to mobile telephone systems. I suppose one of the highest incidences of mobile telephone use would occur amongst the staff and the members and senators of this place. When using our mobile phone, we all like to get a good reception; we become frustrated if it drops away. The telecommunications companies will tell you that, to make mobile phones work effectively, you need more towers to cover their range.

A lot of people in our community, millions of people, want to have access to a decent mobile telephone system—and that requires towers. In my view, the carriers have not acted sensibly either in having joint towers, common towers, or in the way they have thought about where the towers should be placed. As I have said before, they have acted like the old carriers who had a monopoly situation and complete immunity from the local community.

But I repeat: we should remember that there is a demand for these services that has to be met from a national telecommunications system. I hope that the debate over towers can be a rational one. I think there is a lot of evidence around that cannot be ignored, no matter how you try to look at it. There is now evidence emerging causing us to ask: what are the minimum levels of electromagnetic radiation that should be allowed to emanate from towers?
Yesterday we saw a very unfortunate attack on the personality of Dr Neil Cherry that I think will make the debate worse rather than better. But no-one can say that this debate will—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I would simply ask Senator Schacht to confirm that he is referring to my remarks in relation to the credentials of Dr Cherry rather than his personality.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I am referring to someone, Minister, of whom I think your description at one stage was `shameless charlatan'. Another phrase I think was `snake oil merchant'. Those descriptions do not refer to credentials; they refer to the person himself. I think it was unfortunate, and I criticised you for it in the parliament yesterday.

BREAK.PARA: The community finds the issue of towers very difficult. The debate as to where they are sited will get more intense, not less. Whether it involves Mr Cherry or 20 other people, there will be an argument about it. I met Mr Cherry yesterday, and I thought he raised a number of issues that could not be ignored. He may not be right. But in putting his case, he does raise issues that cannot be ignored.

To the Senate: the opposition does not want to disallow these regulations on the national code. We believe, firstly, that it would go back to a worse code. Though this one might not be much of an improvement, it is still some improvement. I agree with Senator Allison that the process of the code's construction was deficient. I think that any future code in any area of telecommunications under the new legislation will have to be more transparent, with more care being taken about the way the community gets access in the consultative process so that the codes are seen as transparent and supportable by the community. It is no use having a code adopted by the parliament which large sections of the community are aggravated about or believe will not work.

I also believe that most of the issues raised quite rightly by Senator Allison will be better dealt with when debating the telecommunications package of legislation in the committee stage in nearly two weeks time. In those areas I believe that the amendments moved by the opposition will overcome a lot of the community's concern that has been let loose by cables and the siting of towers. They are the two areas that the community quite rightly is concerned about. We believe that the opposition is putting up legislative amendments that deal with those issues, and I hope a majority of the Senate can deal with them in a positive way.

As I said yesterday with the tabling of the committee's report, the opposition is willing to talk to all parties in the Senate, and to the government in particular, to try to reach common ground on these amendments as to how the process will operate for the benefit of all. Therefore, with reluctance, I say to the Democrats that they have made some very good points, but we believe that it would only be an Pyrrhic victory to knock off this code at the moment, when the processing of the legislation is the much more important place to take action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed that this motion of disallowance of the Telecommunications National Code 1996 has been moved. I listened very carefully to what Senator Allison said and throughout most of the 20 minutes of her speech she seemed to get completely lost in the minutiae of a process of consultation. What Senator Allison really needs to focus on is what the actual effect of this disallowance will be.

SPEECH.PARA: Originally under the act we had a code brought in that was completely inadequate. I remember the Democrats criticising that code. That was brought in by the Labor Party originally. It absolutely amazes me that Senator Allison now wants to disallow this new code, because the effect of that would be to go back to the old code that everyone agrees is totally inadequate. Senator Allison should look at the timing of what she is proposing. It is now March. At the end of June or the start of July a totally new regime will come in. Having had a totally inadequate code originally, we now have an improved code. You want to go back to the old code that everyone says is no good—including yourself—then it all starts again on 1 July. Procedurally that is a crazy way to go about things. I agree with Senator Schacht that the better way to proceed is to have a look at the legislation that is coming in and try to negotiate changes to that, because the real world is what happens after 1 July 1997.

What Senator Allison will do with this proposed disallowance motion is create disadvantage to a whole range of groups and I am very disappointed that she has moved it. I am disappointed for this Senate which must now spend time discussing the merits of a code that will become obsolete on 1 July anyway with the passage of the new legislation. I am disappointed for the councils and communities. Senator Allison spent a lot of time talking about those people when she was talking about the consultation process, but what she has to realise is that during a very crucial period—this lead‐up to 1 July—if her disallowance worked those people would lose very important rights, because, if we go back to the old code, it takes away some of the benefits of the new code. Certainly the ALGA does not agree with what Senator Allison is doing at the moment. They want us to proceed at this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who have you been talking to?

—They do not want to disallow it and go back to the old code. Why on earth would they want to do that? I am disappointed also for industry and for the authorities with which they have to interact, because, if the 1996 code is disallowed, there will be very widespread regulatory confusion and uncertainty at a time when we are moving up to a new communications regime. Apart from the smaller parties in this place, it seems as though no-one wants this. Certainly the opposition, the Labor Party and the government do not want it and it is the last thing we need as we move into this new era.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me explain why a code such as the one we are now debating exists. The carriers are exempt from certain state and territory laws so that they are able to plan, build and operate viable end‐to‐end networks. This is very much in the national interest, as it is with other sorts of infrastructure in the country. They are bound to comply with the code in lieu of these laws. I must stress that the exemptions pertain only to some state and territory laws, such as ones relating to environment and planning matters, and not to all state and territory laws. Those exemptions relate to specific activities, such as developing the network infrastructures, communication towers, excavations and controlling cables and structures that contain equipment. These exemptions do not extend to all of the carriers' activities.

What is the point in this debate which has been forced on the Senate over the processes and arguments for and against various codes? The most important point to make is that there is no point in disallowing the 1996 code. Both the 1996 code and the old code it replaces under the Telecommunications Act will change on 1 July. There is nothing to be gained by anyone in the proposals from the Democrats today; not for the carriers, the councils, the communities and certainly not for the government in disallowing this code four months before the whole thing will be consigned to history anyway and the whole debate will have become a waste of time. In the meantime, all you will have done is create an enormous amount of confusion.

I have to support the point made by Senator Schacht that, instead of wasting time on this debate today, we should be focusing on the telecommunications package bill. The report came down yesterday. We are about to debate this bill in full and the real positive contribution that the Democrats could make is in debating amendments to this bill so that we do come up with the best possible information superstructure to put Australia in the lead with the new technological developments that are coming to this country. I urge the Senate to reject this irresponsible motion of disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —How many times during the Telstra debate were we told, `Don't worry about all your community and public interest concerns. Don't worry, because they will be dealt with in the code.' When the first 1996 telecommunications code amendments come up and when the community speaks, we are told, `Don't worry. Wait for the legislation.' It seems that they are going to run out of `don't worries' and that they are setting a precedent so that when we speak up and the community speaks up, they can put it off to some other time. They can set precedents in meantime and say, `Look, you people supported the previous code, so how come you are not supporting this code?' What is it going to mean for the standards that people are expecting governments to maintain?

SPEECH.PARA: Why is it important to disallow the 1996 telecommunications code? It is important because we need to send a clear message to the government that the parliament will not tolerate disregarding community views and failure to follow proper processes. We will not tolerate the promoting of private interests at the expense of good planning and environmental protection.

I was disappointed to hear Senator Schacht emphasise that general immunities have existed since federation. This does not cut any ice once you get into the privatisation era. The general immunities were a different kettle of fish. They were about immunities that existed for a government carrier which had responsibility to the government, and the government had responsibility to the parliament. The community had input via the parliament.

Wake up everybody. This does not exist anymore. We have had that debate. We have talked about the Gambotto case. The minority shareholders of these privatised institutions have the right to make a profit and to maximise their profit. Wake up. The world is not the same now as it was at federation. It has changed. Both the Labor Party and the Liberal Party have overseen this change. You cannot pretend that the changes have not happened and pretend that the changes people are seeing—and are frightened of—in their own communities are not happening, because they are.

I will give an example of how this has worked. There was a telecommunications national road show. Members of my office contacted the federal Canberra office of the Department of Communications and the Arts to ask whether or not people would be able to go to this road show. That is, the kinds of people who actually fronted up at the Telstra inquiry and expressed legitimate concerns about the ongoing code.

Guess what? Those people were not invited at the beginning. It was by invitation only. Only when a number of people contacted them and expressed concerns about an invitation only road show was that opened out. If that is not the case, how come people were not told about it? The reality is that people may have found out about it. When they contacted departments, they said, `Oh, yes, it's now open.' Nobody was officially told about it. It was not advertised—as far as I know, and I might be corrected—to say that people were welcome to come. If people did find out, it was very late in the show.

That is not the way to go about it, and it is very symbolic of the whole way this has gone through. As I say, it was a member of my staff who contacted the Canberra office to say, `Look, people want to go.' We were told that it was invitation only. Only later on they say, `Oh, no, it's open.'

Why is this code unacceptable? It was rushed through with a minimal public inquiry, finalised less than 24 hours after submissions closed and introduced without adequate public information during the Christmas-New Year holidays. It fails to deliver, in any meaningful way, on the promises made by the minister in his statement of 3 December. Remember? `Don't worry. This will be in the code. Don't worry. If the code is inadequate, we will try to stop you from doing anything about it, because we will say that there is something else coming up and there is really no point in saying it.'

BREAK.PARA: This code means that communities will have more ugly overhead cables and more mobile phone towers without the proper planning and community consultation. It seems to me that this is yet another example of where corporate interest steamrolls public interest. That is an assumption which, unfortunately, was echoed by Senator Schacht. Because he likes a nice clear line on his mobile telephone, the public cannot be trusted to know what their best interests are. They cannot be trusted to work out whether or not a clear line—which, by the way, is not guaranteed by more mobile phone towers—on their mobile phone is more important than their health or their amenity or their local environment.

I think you can trust the community to make some decisions about public interest or have some input into public interest. Funnily enough, that is why it is called public interest. If we are giving over the decision making roles of the government to monopolies or oligopolies, there will be little government control and that is quite a different kettle of fish. We are saying to the community, `No, your opinions are less important than the ability of the corporations to make the maximum profit,' which is what it is all about.

The code also perpetuates a system under which the carriers are their own judge and jury. There is very little effective scrutiny of their actions, and they can ignore community views almost at will. It exempts overhead cables of less than 13 millimetres in diameter, and lead‐ins to individual subscribers, from the consultation process altogether.

The code specifically prevents community consultation on a range of so-called low impact activities—who defines that?—including, for example, 30‐metre high mobile phone towers with two or three sets of aerials next to schools. Whose decision is that? It largely ignores potential health impacts of telecommunications facilities. We have seen how important the government thinks that is. We saw that yesterday.

The code allows indiscriminate and uncontrolled lopping of vegetation. The new code reduces the powers of the environment secretary compared with the old code. It fails to provide adequate protection for sites of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander significance and for local heritage sites. It pushes the cost of undergrounding onto councils and residents, but at a price determined by the carriers. Senator Tierney suggests that the Local Government Association is supporting his viewpoint, but those points came from the Local Government Association.

Therefore, it is important that at every point along this process, if what we are given is inadequate and if what we are given is a clear reneging on what was said would happen—which I believe it is: read back to the debate on Telstra—then it is up to us to say, `It's not good enough. Go back to the drawing board and come back with something that is acceptable. Come back with something that has the real public interest at heart.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a couple of comments to round off. I want to run through the so-called 21-point plan of improvements that the government say this code is all about and show them up for the sham that they are.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point is: grey cables rather than black. The community is saying to me, `So what?' We do not know of anyone who has actually praised the government for this. So this is revenue neutral. Obviously, it can go ahead in any case.

The second point is: subscriber drops undergrounded where subscribers agree to pay the cost. This is possibly a minor improvement but, as I indicated earlier, it pushes the cost of undergrounding onto residents at a price determined by the carriers. It is an impossible process in any case to bring about. I suppose you could argue that, if the residents were willing to pay for this, they could do it in any case—code or no code.

The third point is: cables undergrounded at major intersections. We know this will not occur because major road intersections are defined as intersections where there are three or more aerial Telecom cables but, as we know, there are only two carriers doing roll‐out.

The fourth point is: visual amenity impact with Austel auditing the roll‐out. Austel has almost no resources outside the city of Melbourne where its headquarters are located, as I understand it. The code imposes a whole range of new obligations on Austel but no provision has been given to Austel to undertake those activities.

The fifth point is: 3.5 metres minimum height. This is well below recommended standards. Austroads pointed out that a 5.3 metre clearance was required in New South Wales. Mosman council pointed out that AS3000 recommends 5.5 metre minimum height on the centre line of the road and 4.9 metres minimum on the kerb line. The only reason for such low height is to accommodate a second carrier stringing under another cable which, in our view, is already low slung. In fact if the 3.5 metres is measured at the pole and in the centre of a long span the cable could be closer to 3 metres.

The sixth point is: individual streets undergrounded where residents request and agree to pay. As I mentioned earlier, these are impossible time frames. It will be very rare for this to be able to be done by residents in a particular street. As I have said already, it pushes the cost of undergrounding onto councils and residents but at a price determined by the carriers themselves.

The seventh point is: carriers to use best practice to minimise degradation of environmental amenity and visual appeal. It is hardly likely to mean anything unless it is clearly defined, mandated and penalties are imposed.

The eighth point is: carriers may nominate two alternative sites for mobile phone towers. Carriers must provide comments on councils' alternatives. This is a nonsense since councils can do this anyway, and of course they have. They can nominate as many as they want. The problem is that the carriers, by and large, ignore those council recommendations. The new code does nothing to improve that.

The ninth point is: $10 million fine for breach of code. This is good, but the code still does not protect residents. Moreover, Austel, who is to monitor and audit that roll‐out, has not been provided with the resources, as I have said.

BREAK.PARA: The tenth point is: Austel to have the power to audit the carriers for compliance with the code. They have the power but, as I have already said, they do not have the resources.
The eleventh point is: carriers must comply with restrictions on times of day when activities can be carried out. This does nothing about the environmental, health and visual impact of the roll‐out.

The twelfth point is: no aerial cabling in areas where there are none. This is possibly the only genuine safeguard in this whole package. It may provide some hope for residents in new suburbs. But note this is where it is cheapest to do so anyway and the carriers would be foolish to do otherwise.
The thirteenth point is: cables must go underground when all other cables do, unless council agrees otherwise. This will not occur within the life of the code, so it is entirely irrelevant.

The fourteenth point is: public must be notified of all high and medium impact proposals in heritage, residential and commercial areas. Notification is next to useless if it does not change the outcomes and it is the outcomes I think which are of concern to people.

The fifteenth point is: if requested by the council, carriers must consult with community at a public meeting for high impact facilities. Again, this is only of value to enable residents to vent their already well-known disgust and anger, but it does not alter the outcomes.
The sixteenth point is: information on facilities must be provided to councils. Again, information without outcomes is useless.

The seventeenth point is: collocation of mobile phone antennas required, unless not technically feasible, with Austel to arbitrate disputes between the carriers. This requirement is not contained in the code, but it is to be executed as a licence condition, so it is not relevant to this debate.

The eighteenth point is: if a council has telecommunications facilities planning guidelines, carriers must refer to them. Referring to them is one thing but abiding by them is a completely different matter.
The nineteenth point is: carriers must modify their proposals to accord with recommendations made by DEST and AHC. Yes, but once again, the power of the environment secretary is reduced.

The twentieth point is: Austel able to direct carriers to comply with procedural requirements of the code. But, as I have already said, Austel has not been given the resources to enable it to insist on those powers.
The twenty-first point is: consultation time frames similar to those in the existing code. This is an open admission that they are no different or any better.

The Democrats would like to say at this point that we are disappointed that the opposition is not going to support this disallowance motion. I think Senator Margetts makes some very important points about the reassurances inherent in this code—that is, `Don't worry we'll fix it later.' It keeps on being, `Don't worry. Something else will bob up which will satisfy your concerns.'

It is interesting Senator Tierney says that we should focus on the issue. I look forward to seeing how he and the rest of the government will vote when it comes to our amendments to the legislation. It is quite interesting, too, I note that a couple of months ago Senator Tierney went along to a public meeting in his electorate and complained about the fact that the government was unable to do anything about cables and towers in that area. He faced a very angry community meeting but washed his hands of it and said, `No, there is nothing we can do. We are only in government. We are still having to deal with this problem from the previous government.'

Senator Tierney also referred to the ALGA and seemed to suggest that councils were opposed to this move of ours. I am happy to run through the list of complaints that the ALGA made. I am sure the ALGA made representation to government, the opposition, ourselves, the Independents and the Greens. I will not do that because I think it was a pretty feeble argument and not backed up by any substance whatever.
I will conclude my remarks at this point. I recommend that the Senate votes with the Democrats on this disallowance on behalf of a very great number of people out there in the community.

PARA.TAB: That the motion (Senator Allison's) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Campbell) proposed:

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Senate adopt the recommendations contained in the first report of 1997 of the Procedure Committee, which provide that:
(a) paragraph (10) of standing order 26 be amended to provide that the period of notice of matters to be raised at supplementary estimates hearings be not less than 3 working days; and

(b) standing order 69 be amended to provide that a summary of petitions be circulated at the commencement of each sitting day with a general announcement by the Clerk and that a petition not in conformity with the order may be presented in accordance with the order only with the approval of the President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel compelled to speak about this today—and I apologise to the government for not having spoken about this earlier—because it was only yesterday, just before I was due to come into the chamber, that I was alerted to the fact that in the short Senate Procedure Committee report, the first report of 1997, there are two issues that are to be changed.

SPEECH.PARA: One of them deals with petitions which are not in conformity with the normal format. They are not to be dealt with in the main part of the day. I have no real problems with dealing with those in a different way. But I do have a problem with losing that short part of each day which allows for the Clerk to make an announcement of the petitions lodged, indicating in respect of each petition the senator who presented it, the number of signatures and the subject matter of the petition. It is proposed that those details will not be read out.

Some people will say: `For the non‐broadcasting days, that does not make any difference.' I say that ignores the reason for which petitions are written. Often it takes a great deal of effort for people to collect signatures in this way. A petition is an awareness mechanism. It is one of the few means by which the community can have a direct voice, small as it is, in the parliamentary process. The most important thing is not necessarily that a petition is read out, though I believe that should continue to happen as it does not take up a large part of the day; it is that the message in a petition is to us, the elected representatives.

As for petitions to the House of Representatives, what they do with them is up to them. But the ones sent to the Senate constitute a message from the community to the Senate. I wonder, in reality, how many honourable senators pick up the list of regulations, after it has been tabled each day, and read it and have an idea of what is in it. I would say very few. I think this is what will happen if we have a tabled list of petitions. That voice, small as it is, will be stifled. I do not think that is good enough. Petitions constitute an aide‐memoire for us of the issues that are important to the community. With petitions, we know what the issues are. We know how many people are supporting a petition. If the same issue comes up day after day in large numbers, it is important—not just that it happens and not just that it gets written down somewhere—that we know, because we are the people to whom those people are sending the message.

I do not think this change is good enough. I do not think it is just a matter of time management. I think we are taking away that very small voice in the community, and therefore I wish to amend the motion. I hope my revised version of the motion is now in the hands of honourable senators. If not, I will read it out. It is not very long.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's here.

—So you have got the revised one. It is two paragraphs long. It simply amends the first statement and also amends the appendix to the Procedure Committee report so that it allows the Clerk to continue to read out the name, subject and also the name of the senator who has lodged the petition. I think these changes are important. I do not think it is a trivial thing. I like to think that other senators will be mindful of the importance of this tiny process whereby the community can have a voice. I move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) Paragraph (b), omit "that a summary of petitions be circulated at the commencement of each sitting day with a general announcement by the Clerk and".
(2) Appendix to the Procedure Committee First Report of 1997, omit paragraph (2) of standing order 69, substitute:

EMPHASIS.TAB: "(2) At the time provided the Clerk shall make an announcement of petitions lodged, indicating in respect of each petition the Senator who presents it, the number of signatures, and the subject matter of the petition."

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Margetts's amendment. I agree with her that it is very important, because petitions represent the one area where Australians on the street can actually have a voice in this chamber. They put their signature to a petition and at least the subject of that petition and the number of people who have signed it are read out by the Clerk some time during the day. The reading out of the number of signatures and of what is in the petition does not take very long. It is less than five minutes a day. For the time that we would be saving by not reading that out, we would be losing something important.

SPEECH.PARA: I am a member of the Procedure Committee, but I regret to say that I was not at the meeting where this issue was discussed. I am sorry that I have only just caught up with it. This is something that we should think about again. I am not too fussed about petitions not being in conformity; I would rather that they were in conformity. However, as Senator Margetts has said, spending something like two to five minutes a day to announce what petitions have been lodged and how many people have signed those petitions is a very important part of this chamber.

Over the years that I have been involved in the parliament—which is nearly 20—it has been cut down and cut down to this point. I think this is the point at which we should stop cutting it down. This is the point at which we should maintain a two‐ to five‐minute announcement per day to let everybody listening in the chamber and those listening on radio know what issues people feel so strongly about that they are prepared to sign a petition and send it into parliament. I will be supporting Senator Margetts's amendment to this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I totally agree with the two previous speakers. Senator Margetts is to be commended for bringing forward this amendment. I am greatly troubled by the fact that hundreds of thousands of Australians sign petitions to the Senate each year and, in the main, the Senate totally ignores them. The best that happens at the moment is that petitions are read out detailing the number of people who signed them and the senator who brought them in. They then go onto the record. But the reality is that most people who sign petitions do not know how little notice we as senators take of them.

SPEECH.PARA: Petitions rate so lowly in the business of the Senate and in the thinking of people who are distracted by the issues we are dealing with every day. In some way or other, I think we have to be honest with the populace and say that petitions are not a good way of lobbying parliament. An enormous amount of effort goes into signing petitions, some of them with tens of thousands of signatures. Yet at the end of the day they have little above zero impact on the thinking of we senators.

Petitions are read out at the beginning of each day, but let us all be honest: we are not listening much of the time because we are distracted by the business of the Senate. I tell community groups to put their energy into other modes of lobbying their parliamentarians—directly in the electorates and through other methods of public debate. I think there is a very strong feeling in the community that, if people petition parliament, it is really going to have an impact. That is not the case.

Petitions have been a part of parliamentary procedure since the Magna Carta. They are an institution. However, as both Senator Margetts and Senator Bourne have indicated, they have been reduced to a thread of their former power simply by the passage of time. I think it behoves all of us to tell people who are campaigning to have their point of view registered with us that there are other more powerful ways of doing it. The very least we could do is acknowledge that 60 people in Echuca or 600,000 people in Queensland or, with the Franklin campaign, 30,000 people in Tasmania have signed petitions to the parlia ment because they have felt strongly about an issue.

There is a responsibility on the Senate and on senators to let the public know just how little petitions weigh. It is a very sad factor in life, but it is a reality and we should not duck that. The least we should do is acknowledge that those petitions have been brought to the Senate and that there are people who want their point of view heard. If citizens have gone to the trouble of signing petitions, we should acknowledge them. I very strongly support Senator Margetts's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not disagree with virtually anything that Senator Brown has said. When I was in opposition, I was responsible for some huge petitions coming into this place. Honourable senators who were here at the time would recall what I did in relation to the former Ambassador to Ireland, Mr Brian Burke. Many Western Australians signed petitions on that matter. There was the petition that Senator John Herron circulated in relation to the Carmen Lawrence Cleo sex guide. There was a big public campaign out there and petitions were part of that.

SPEECH.PARA: I am reminded of what Senator Brown said in relation to the fact that, when the clerk reads the short version of the petition, we do not tend to listen. We are usually preoccupied with what is going to happen with formal motions or when a certain order of business is going to come on, and we do not pay it much recognition. It is a shame that Senator Bourne was not at the meeting of the Procedure Committee. I was informed by the whips that the Democrats had agreed to this motion being made formal and that they would support it. But I fully recognise that they have the right to focus on issues and change their mind.

The Procedure Committee has come to the conclusion that all that is added by the current procedure is the clerk standing up and reading the short title for two, three or four minutes a day. This motion changes only that. Senator Brown has admitted that that does not give a lot of weight to the petition. I am reminded of former Senator Fred Chaney's views on this matter: that is, the forms, the standing orders and the powers of the Senate are very strong. The Senate has enormous powers as a political institution. It is one of the most powerful upper houses on the globe. It is incumbent upon individual senators to use all of the processes of the Senate to assist their constituents, the people and democracy. When it comes to petitions, they can be used effectively.

I think you have asked senators to ensure that petitions are more important in the Senate food chain. They are already forwarded to Senate legislation committees for their consideration. It is quite possible for a Senate legislation committee to have a petition from 30,000 petitioners in Western Australia or Tasmania or somewhere else on an issue. In fact, Senator Brown, I remember when I first attended a committee and petitions turned up, and I asked the chairman or clerk of the committee, `What do we do now?' He said, `Oh, I think we just table them, or note that we have received them.'

It reinforces your argument. It would have been incumbent upon me, if I had thought that was an important issue, to say, `I think this is a very important issue and this committee should do more than that; it should look into this matter, or have an inquiry into the matter, or take it further.' It should be part of the political process, and it can be. This motion does not interact on this process. All it stops is the Clerk going through the perfunctory task of reading a short version of the petitions daily into the Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the numbers of people who sign it; that's important.

—Senator Margetts, on a day like today when we are not on broadcast, the full details of the petitions and the numbers of people who sign them will still be recorded in full in the Hansard . The only difference is that the people in the gallery will not get to see Harry Evans, the Clerk of the Senate, stand up and read the petitions.
—And us.

—And we won't. No‐one out there in voter land or citizen land of Australia will hear it because we are not on broadcast, but it will be fully in the Hansard . You can write to your petitioners—which I always do when I table a petition—saying, `I would like you to know that I have tabled the petition you gave me on this day, and here is an extract from Hansard .' I always do that to petitioners so they know that it has been received. None of that will change.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator Bob Brown on everything except on how I am going to vote on this motion and that is, that petitions can be used as a part of the democratic process—it is important that they are—but it is not really helped by the clerk standing up every morning and saying, `These are the petitions today'. It is all going to be in the Hansard; it is all going to be recorded. It is all going to go to a legislation committee, then it is up to the senators to say that petitions should be an important part. When it comes to that, Senator Brown, I am on your side. I will help to make them part of that, but having the clerk stand up every day does not assist that. I commend the report of the Procedure Committee and this motion to the Senate.

That the amendment (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.
