That the provisions of the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill 1997 and the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge (Application to the Commonwealth—Reduction of Benefits) Bill 1997 be referred to the Select Committee on Superannuation for consideration in conjunction with the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge (Assessment and Collection) Bill 1997 and associated bills, and that the committee report by 20 March 1997.

DEBATE.TITLE:
INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1996 INCOME TAX (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1996
INCOME TAX (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 October 1996, on motion by Senator Campbell:

BREAK.PARA: That these bills be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a correction to the revised explanatory memorandum relating to these bills.

—The Income Tax Assessment Bill 1997 amends the Income Tax Assessment Act. The opposition will make the most succinct speech on this subject that this chamber has heard in some time. We are pleased to support the government on the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak a little less briefly than Senator Cook in relation to the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1997. The government is selling this bill as a simplification of the Income Tax Act. It is more than this. It is also a bill which formalises many of the exemptions given to the Australian mining industry and extends those exemptions to even more activities associated with mining. Currently, exemptions are given for activities such as exploration, prospecting and feasibility studies into economic viability of a proposed mine on a discretionary basis.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill will `bring the law into line with established practice'. The bill will also extend existing deductions for site rehabilitation to include dams and levees. This is something to which we object strongly. The mining sector already gets massive subsidies from the public purse, both directly and through favourable tax treatment, the $900 million diesel fuel rebate being a notable example.

Through this tax bill, the government, with the support of the opposition, is allowing the mining sector to write off even more of its costs. The cost of rehabilitating mine sites is something which mining companies should have to wear. Why should the public purse fund mining companies to repair land which has been damaged by their profit making activities? Surely the mining companies make enough money so that they can fund the cost of rehabilitation unassisted, or is this another example of `privatise the gains, socialise the losses'?

I am also very concerned that, by giving deductions for the building of dams and levees, they will end up encouraging the use of these rehabilitation methods, despite evidence that they are not a satisfactory answer to the problems of tailings. It seems that the government is determined to minimise any costs that mining companies incur. By doing it through tax deductions, they are effectively doing so at the expense of the rest of the population. The continuing deductions given to mining companies cut into government revenue, reducing the amount of money available for spending on community services, health and education—sections of the community which, unlike the mining sector, are already operating on insufficient budgets.

I will relate to the Senate an account of attempts by my office to get a figure from the government on how much the tax deduction for rehabilitation would cost. It is very revealing of the extreme generosity shown to the mining industry. When I first attempted to get a figure on the cost of the deduction, I was told that it would be `minimal', but that an exact figure would not be given. I asked, `What constitutes minimal? Could I at least have a range of figures?' Apparently not. I could get nothing more than the fact that it would be `minimal'.

The first question that poses itself is: if the cost is so minimal, why grant the deduction in the first place? If it is so minimal, it is clearly not something that is going to make or break the profitability of a mining company. I cannot help getting the feeling that the deduction is being given by this government because it shares the mining industry's outrage at having to engage in any form of rehabilitation. This, the mining industry believes, is an unnecessary cost imposed by minority political pressure groups. Apparently, the government agrees and is thus going to relieve them of the unfair burden!

But I have to say that there is also a dangerous precedent here in one bill in calling the construction of tailings dams and construction of levees rehabilitation. Which other bill will we see this in? Perhaps one day in the future we will see things such as Natural Heritage Trust funds going towards environmental rehabilitation. Could that be the case in the future—that we could see some funds from the Natural Heritage Trust going into the building of dams for mines? It is not beyond the realms of possibility. If we start redefining these in tax bills, maybe that is the logical extension of what we will see in the future.

My inability to get an exact figure also raises another issue—that is, the government's alleged fiscal responsibility. This government has shown an extremely parsimonious attitude towards government expenditure of some sorts. No amount of spending is too small to escape vigorous scrutiny, provided it is to the community and such groups as the unemployed, Aboriginal people and community groups. Yet here we have the government claiming that it is going to allow a deduction for the mining industry despite not even being sure how much it will cost. I am sure those sectors of the community and public sector who suffered such deep cuts in funding will be impressed by this generosity. Despite this deduction being `minimal', I am sure those whose funding was slashed will be eager to get on the same gravy train as the mining industry is riding.

There is another part of this bill which represents the mining industry getting a tax exemption which the rest of the community is denied. A prospector who on-sells a tenement will not have to pay tax on the income which they make from that sale. Why not? This is the standard real estate sale on which tax is usually payable. Why not in this case?

I will finish by posing a question which these new deductions raise. If the mining industry did not get these massive subsidies and the benefits of these tax deductions, how profitable would it be? Or, to put it another way, how profitable would the renewable energy industry sector be if it received only a fraction of the subsidies that mining receives?

We must look at the real costs, the community costs and the environmental costs. It is well overdue. It is also very important that the mining industry missed out on scrutiny in the much lauded report, which was written by the federal Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, on costs of resource extraction. The mining industry missed out. It has not been done. If it has been done, I would be pleased to see it. What is the real cost? What are we actually paying out of taxpayers' funds to support this industry? Why can we support an extension of that without any real explanation for doing so?

I will be asking questions in the committee stage of the bill. I hope the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) will be able to provide adequate answers to those. I would like to briefly mention that Senator Harradine has amendments to this bill. They do, on my initial investigation, appear to be reasonable amendments to the bill. I will be listening carefully to Senator Harradine's contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President Ferguson, I am sure you, and every member of this chamber, are concerned about taxpayers. We are all concerned about taxpayers. However, it does not appear from the attitude that has thus far flowed from the government or the opposition that they give a damn about taxpayers. Here is a piece of legislation that is likely to affect every single taxpayer in this country, yet the government and the opposition wanted to let this bill through on the flick as a non-controversial item. What a disgrace! It is a sell-out on the taxpayers of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The moment I see a piece of taxation legislation come before this chamber and being regarded as non-controversial should be the time that I should leave this place. I have not yet, in my 21 years of `service' in this place, seen any tax legislation—let alone a piece of tax legislation that is 366 pages long—that is non-controversial.

It has been suggested that this is a rewrite of the taxation law. The problem with that, as honourable senators know, or should know, is that there is a body of judicial precedent that applies to the wording of the previous tax law that does not apply to this. I hope the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) can tell me what the word `idea' means in the beginning of this legislation. But we will get that at the committee stage.

I make it clear at the outset that I have no philosophical objections to the rewriting of tax laws. Indeed, we could do worse than go back to Sir Robert Garran's 1915 Income Tax Assessment Act, which was only some 30 pages long. I am also cognisant of the amount of money and effort that has gone into this bill, and I note the restrictions on the redrafting process in terms of `no policy changes' that have cost us dearly in terms of what might have been achieved. For example, Hong Kong has surpassed Australia's per capita income on the basis of a simple colonial Inland Revenue ordinance. A world-class tax law need not be the most elaborate—quite the reverse.

I am thus deeply concerned that the process of tax law redrafting must be made transparent to the public and not involve unnecessary loss of judicial precedent, especially where it is not intended to change the law. I therefore have profound reservations about proceeding with this bill at this time, and I am not alone on that.

I understand that there is considerable unhappiness amongst the professionals and industry, in particular the mining industry, in relation to some of the provisions of this bill. Indeed, the Taxation Institute of Australia, the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants, in their joint submission of 18 February 1997, have gone so far as to state:

There is concern among the members of the combined professional bodies, that, far from achieving the tax simplification and easier compliance goals of the Tax Law Improvement Project . . . taxpayers may be worse off if current TLIP legislation is enacted to become effective from 1 July 1997. This legislation is TLIB and the early instalment, the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996 . . .

So you say to those people, `Go and jump in the lake.' These are the people that are dealing daily with taxation matters. They say that the taxpayers of Australia could be worse off because of this legislation, and you are prepared to go through with a flick. You should be ashamed of yourselves.

The basic problem with this rewrite of the tax law is that you cannot make a silk purse out of a sow's ear. Unless there is to be a change of policy, there is not much point in changing the words—is there? Indeed, it may be much worse than that. If you change the words, the courts presume that you intend to change the meaning. In the case of the Bank of England v. Vagliano Brothers, in construing a far more elegant codification in 1882 by Sir Mackenzie Chalmers of the law relating to bills of exchange, the House of Lords observed that you start with the words of a codifying statute uninfluenced by the previous law. So a rewrite in different words inevitably means a loss of precedent. A rewrite for the sake of rewriting may thus be worse than useless.

I know the bill tries to avoid this logical problem by declaring in proposed sections 1 to 3 that ideas are not to be taken as different just because different words are used. But you are left to the subjective judgment of the courts to decide what idea was meant and whether it was different. There are dictionaries of words the courts can look to, but there are no dictionaries of ideas, unless you can come up with some during this debate, Senator Kemp. Ideas and words cannot be so easily separated and the danger of resulting ambiguity is real.

The problem with the income tax law is not its basic concepts. Section 25, dealing with assessable income, and section 51, dealing with general deductions, have been extensively considered by the courts and there is a huge body of case law which exists to guide taxpayers. The problem with tax law is the continued excrescences being pushed onto it by successive generations of bureaucrats. For example, we just had the debt forgiveness rules pushed into the act. We are about to have rules on trust losses thrust in front of us. If there was a genuine commitment by the tax office to tax simplification, complex legislation like this would not be put in front of us at the same time as we are asked to approve a simplification of the tax law.

It was admitted on 19 February this year before the Joint Committee of Public Accounts that it may be up to 20 years before taxpayers have the benefit of the courts resolving some of the ambiguities of this bill. It was said that in some cases you could ask 10 QCs a question and get five opinions one way and five opinions the other way. I do not have time at the second reading stage to quote verbatim what was said and, significantly, who said it. Some eminent experts—notably Geoffrey Lehmann, co-author of one of the leading texts on Australian taxation law—have condemned this bill as being badly thought out and full of technical errors. Again we have the government and the opposition as one. Do you deny that this is the case; that this expert has said that? Remember the taxpayer. Do nothing that is detrimental to the taxpayer in a rewrite situation.

Lehmann has pointed out that in some cases the guides to the act, which are printed in the text but are not part of the act, are not clearly separated from the operative provisions of the act and are in some cases inconsistent with the act. Given such warnings from persons of the highest eminence in their field, I think it would be most imprudent for the parliament to pass this bill at this time.

If you are prepared to proceed, at a bare minimum, the commencement date in section 1.2 should be changed from 1 July 1997 to 1 July 1998. There are good reasons for doing so. First, technical problems can be identified and corrected before the act starts to operate. Second, this bill and the Tax Law Improvement Bill were meant to operate together and the latter bill will need extensive consultation—you will admit that, won't you, Senator Kemp?

Third, this bill, unless amended, will operate retrospectively in respect of early balancing companies whose fiscal year starts before 1 July this year. Retrospective legislation is repugnant at the best of times and is quite unnecessary here. It may help if I give the Senate an example of the sorts of technical problems which may emerge.

Senators will remember that last year the Senate had to amend the law in respect of section 120(1)(c) on tax deductions for repayments of loans by cooperatives because the tax office put out a nonsense ruling which the Senate had to override by amending the law so that the word `or' in the act was not ignored by the tax office. Taxpayers cannot do that and we do not have the time to correct every silly ruling put out by some tax officials. I have nothing personal against taxation officers; some tax officials are among my best friends, I might say.

BREAK.PARA: Take another example. Hundreds of thousands of workers were potentially adversely affected by a Tax Pack instruction that work related expenses should only be deducted when the money was spent as opposed to the law and the High Court's view that expenses were deductible when incurred. After representations, the tax office finally put out a ruling which restored previous practice.

Take a third example. Section 960-100 in the bill declares that a partnership or trust is an entity for the purposes of the tax law. How will this affect capital gains tax on changes of partners? Is a contribution under a will from a deceased's estate to an existing trust a new trust or the same entity as the first trust? Will a variation of a trust deed create a new entity? I do not know the answers to these questions. I will be interested to see whether the minister does and on what basis. Such questions may end up affecting hundreds of thousands of small businesses, so I am inclined to great caution.

The sorry saga of amendment after amendment to capital gains tax being backdated to 20 September 1985 should make us extremely cautious about how broad, simple concepts in apparently simple words can end up as legislative and compliance nightmares. It took years for Hepples's case on restrictive covenants to get to the High Court. When it did, the judges could not agree on what the capital gains tax provisions meant.

Hence, if this bill proceeds, it is essential that it be amended so that there are safety ropes for taxpayers. There should be a general provision stating that, if a taxpayer would not be liable for tax or pay less tax under the pre-existing law, then he or she should have no further liability under this bill. That is fair, is it not? After all, this bill is supposed to be a rewrite of the existing law, not a tax increase bill. The government is committed to a policy of no new taxes, so I am sure the government will accept an amendment to this effect.

As a further precaution, after section 950-150 on the interpretation of the act, a new section should be added to declare the normal rule for construing legislation potentially adverse to the subject—namely, in the case of ambiguity, the act should be construed in favour of the subject and not derogate from common law rights.

Just as the courts construe tricky fine print in insurance contracts against the insurance companies which put them forward into the hands of consumers, the same principle should operate here. It is a basic consumer protection principle that ambiguous legislation should be construed against those who draft it. No parliament should hand over the liberties of the subject through obscure or ambiguous legislation into the hands of non-elected bureaucrats.

Given the controversy which has accompanied this process of tax law redrafting—and I am not sure it can be always called an improvement—the parliament has to insist on fail‐safe mechanisms and basic protections for the taxpayer. To do less than that is for us to fail as legislators. I am vitally concerned that taxpayers not be jeopardised in any way by unintended consequences. Unless this bill has such safety mechanisms built into it, I would find myself unable to support it.

At the moment this bill is only controversial in areas of the tax consulting professions and some industry associations. But I can guarantee the parliament that, if we let it go without safeguards, taxpayers will be affected by so-called unintended consequences—and that is admitted. If there are no safeguards for such cases, the resulting controversy among the public at large will make the furores over fringe benefits tax and substantiation rules look mild indeed.

In conclusion, this is the Senate. This measure was rubber‐stamped through the House of Representatives. There was no debate, virtually. There has been no offer of debate here. I challenge the Senate to consider the matters that I have raised in the light of the Senate's functions as a house of review. Much has been said about this of recent times. But we are a house of review, and here is a most important piece of legislation that is likely to affect every single taxpayer in this country.

Does this legislation not deserve more than the cursory treatment it has been given by the government and, to this stage, the opposition? Is it not legislation in relation to which we, not only as legislators but specifically as senators, have the job of protecting the rights of individual citizens? That is one of our jobs. If we do not do that on this occasion and specifically give some guarantees and safeguards to those persons whose rights may well be affected as a result of this legislation, then we are failing in our duty as senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senators for their remarks on this package of income tax legislation. Senator Margetts was kind enough to provide my office with notice of some questions. Senator, we certainly appreciate your courtesy and will respond to those in the committee stage of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: To the remarks made by my colleague Senator Harradine: Senator, it was a good and powerful speech. However, many of the issues you raised do not relate to this particular package of legislation but are general issues which will apply to any tax bill, regardless. Of course there will always be challenges in courts to legislation which is passed by this chamber.

Senator, this legislation has a very long history of public exposure. I note your concern to protect the rights and interests of taxpayers, and on our side we welcome that. That is why this government in its budgets has tried to reduce the constant burden on taxpayers. No-one needs to speak to this government about the rights of taxpayers and the need to protect taxpayers' interests.

Senator, you felt that in some way the rights of taxpayers—and I think this debate will continue in the committee stage—were somehow being impinged upon. I do not agree. The passage of this legislation in many ways will mark a new era for all those Australians who need to know under tax law what their basic rights and obligations are. That is why the legislation has been written in a way to make it easier for people to understand. That was one of the bases upon which this project commenced. Senator, to that extent, we are in blazing agreement with you: taxpayers need to know and understand their rights and obligations.

Just to get the history clear, the bills that are before the chamber today have been subject to close review and extensive consultation. Their content was exposed for public comment and there was a series of consultative documents in August 1994 and April and June 1995. We believe that the quality of these bills has been significantly enhanced as a result of that consultation. It has been an extremely valuable process, and the government is keen to ensure that all stages of the tax law rewrite benefit from a wide range of views.

These bills were introduced by the previous government in December 1995 and referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for review—which is most appropriate and should happen in these cases. The committee held public hearings on these bills but, before the calling of the general election, was unable to report on them.

The government introduced the present bills in June 1996, some nine months ago, and referred them to the JCPA, which again held public hearings. The committee, made up of people from all sides of the parliament, reported in August and commended the bills as a significant improvement on existing law. It also recommended some finetuning changes in response to public submissions.

Senator, in relation to your proposal for deferral, the committee proposed deferring the start date of the bills until 1 July 1997 so that there would be ample time to prepare for them. So, in that sense, they have already been deferred once. No-one is trying to dump these bills. Of all the bills that have come before this chamber, these bills in particular have been exposed for public comment over a long period of time.

Senator Harradine raised comments that these were somehow being flicked through the chamber. It would not surprise him that we felt these were well drafted bills and we were quite happy—if other senators shared our views—that they would go through that quicker process. As soon as Senator Harradine raised an issue we were more than happy, as we must—

TALK.START.PARA: —As you usually are.

—If Senator Harradine feels that they should be exposed for greater public debate in this chamber, we are happy to oblige, as we should and as senators would expect us to do. The government has agreed to adopt all the JCPA's recommendations and has amended the bills in the House to that effect. I also note that the tax law improvement project has prepared and distributed notes and responses of professional bodies on all significant issues raised in the bills.
—And what do they say?

—You have raised some issues. In this world, as you know, it is very hard to keep all people happy. If there is one thing that you and I have learned it is that it is exceedingly difficult to do that. As you well know, many of those bodies are not at all happy with the current laws as they stand. They raise issues. This government is a constructive government and it looks to see where it can constructively respond to the concerns raised.

SPEECH.PARA: We will now go into the committee stage of this debate. Senator Harradine plans to move three amendments and I will respond to them. Let us get this clear and on the record—these bills have been around for a long time. There has been extensive consultation on these bills. The government has responded where it can to the consultations which have occurred and I urge the Senate to support these bills. Some of the issues raised by Senator Harradine will be further exposed in the committee stage of the debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1996
The bill

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to advise the committee that I was most disappointed in Senator Kemp's response to the second reading stage. He had indicated that people were so happy about this.
—I didn't say that, Senator. That's not fair for you to say that. I didn't say that.

—Yes, but here is the unanimous view of the three peak bodies, the Taxation Institute of Australia, the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants, all of whom are opposed to this legislation proceeding at this point of time and for very valid reasons. Senator Kemp has not gone to those reasons. Surely he knew that that was the case. Did he know that they were opposed to this before he was going to flick it through in a non-controversial time?

SPEECH.PARA: These organisations are there to serve the taxpayers in Australia. Of course, Senator Kemp's response is that these people are always concerned about tax. Of course they are concerned about tax law, but we are talking about a rewrite, and the unintended consequences that taxpayers could all be worse off as a result of this piece of legislation.

Then Senator Kemp will find out. The government stood and said, `No new taxes,' but this legislation has the potential of exacting new taxes. That is what it is all about. I am putting to Senator Kemp in moving an amendment later—and he should think about this—that there is a way to overcome this if the government would only adopt my amendments. The proof of the pudding will be in the eating when it comes to that.
I will quote what those three peak bodies say in their introduction about this piece of legislation:

There is concern among the members of the combined professional bodies that, far from achieving the tax simplification and easier compliance goals of the tax law improvement project, taxpayers may be worse off if the current TLIP legislation is enacted to become effective from 1 July 1997.
I hope the government adopts my amendment because that will mean that the rights of taxpayers will be protected.

TALK.START.PARA: —How will they be better off if it is from 1 July 1998?
—I will deal with that in specifics directly, but I am making a point in the committee stage as a preliminary to this particular question. In the executive summary these three peak bodies said:

BREAK.PARA: 1. The proposed start date of 1 July 1997 is ill-conceived. There is no benefit to Australia of rushing new tax laws on unprepared taxpayers. Indeed, such action would appear to be contrary to the stated project goal of simplifying and improving tax law for taxpayers, particularly where such law contains errors and unrecognised changes in the tax law.
2. The proposed start date will be 1 January 1997 for some taxpayers and is retrospective.
Let us not get into any argument over that. The government is proposing to put forward retrospective legislation.

This is a breach of the fundamental principle that laws should not be retrospective. Australian parliaments have only made laws retrospective where there were extreme circumstances, which is not the case here.

The proposed date is also contrary to the recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. There is a wide level of confusion in the community involving the tax law improvement project. Although it is widely recognised that Australian tax law needs to be improved, there is scepticism as to whether the stated goals of the tax law improvement project are being achieved.
And so it goes on. I would like to hear the minister's response to that, or isn't he interested? I am sure he is interested.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are being very unkind today. Did you get out of bed on the wrong side?
—No. I get hot under the collar when it comes to taxes. Don't we all?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the first matter you raised, happiness and taxation rarely go together in my view. The record will show that people are not often happy with taxes. But taxes must be seen to be fair and equitable. We believe the result of this bill before the chamber will be that people will better know their basic rights and obligations. So people will not be worse off. We believe that people will be better off because they will better be able to know their basic rights and obligations under the tax law.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator, I am well aware of the matters that you have raised from various professional associations, and their views have been taken into account. This government works closely with all organisations. We listen to their views and, where we can, we respond to them. But those organisations do not have a veto power over what this government does. We listen and we listen carefully. Where we can respond in a constructive way and where real issues are raised, this government is always responsive. Senator, again, underlying your comments that somehow this bill has been rushed out into the community—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I didn't say that. In fairness, I didn't say that.

—Senator, in relation to your remarks, you asked for a delay. I am going to address that particular matter you raised. I remind the Senate that these bills have had extensive public exposure, including two CPA reviews. As the Joint Committee of Public Accounts notes, busy professional and business people tend to operate on a just-in-time basis. It may be not desirable, but it often happens in the real world.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been considerable promotion of public awareness throughout Australia wide seminars and other public forums. Commercial publishers are geared up and training materials produced by the ATO will be available in May. There is no rush at all in this. The first draft of the bill was around in mid-1994. No-one has been rushed; no-one has been sprung. Many accountants have already anticipated commencement of the legislation in relation to their staff and clients. Of course, that also applies in universities with their teaching aids. Preparedness for this bill is substantially, we believe, an advance of the usual case for other tax legislation, which often contains much more substantial change.

The bills have already been deferred by a year. The JCPA, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, has listened to the submissions of the tax practitioners, the associations and those that had a view that they should be further delayed. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts came to the conclusion, which the government accepts, that they should not be further delayed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This document says 18 February.

—We have responded, Senator. There has been an ongoing debate; there have been ongoing discussions; there has been an ongoing review. If people listened to your remarks, they may have felt that somehow this government had not been responsive to the particular concerns. The issues that the accountants and the associations have raised have all been before the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. They have all been exposed in the public arena and, where the government has been able to respond, the government has responded. We will continue to have discussions with those bodies in a most constructive manner. So, Senator, I think I have responded to the particular concerns that you have raised in a constructive manner, but I am sure you will have some more questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I indicated to the minister that I have a series of questions which I need to ask for clarification. In the particular area that I am looking at, there is a great deal of need for clarification. This is leading up to a proposed amendment, which I will be seeking to move depending on how the government answers the questions. Firstly, how much will the deduction on dams and levees cost per year?
—I thought you were going to read through them, and I could respond to them all, if you like. That may be easier.

—I am happy to do that. The first question is: how much will the deduction on dams and levees cost per year? Does carrying out eligible mining activities include construction and operation of tailings dams, dump leach pads or vat leach pads and, if not, why not? Does rehabilitating a mine site include the removal of topsoil from a mine surface, the construction of a waste dump, the construction of a tailings embankment or the recovery of economic tailings?

SPEECH.PARA: Can the minister provide an example of a dam specifically constructed for no purpose other than to provide water for rehabilitation? To the best of our knowledge, no such dams are constructed in Western Australia. I believe that has been confirmed. We have sought information from the West Australian Department of Minerals and Energy and that seems to be the case. No dams in WA mining have been built for anything other than tailings, so what are you talking about?

Does rehabilitating the mine site include expenditure on site assessment, monitoring, compliance reporting and changed land uses—and this includes wildlife habitat—which do not increase the residual market value of the rehabilitated area? In other words, if you change the use which actually makes it more beneficial for the environment do you lose your tax deduction if other people get it? Does it include expenditure on recovery of contaminated seepage or erosion products?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for those questions and I appreciate the courtesy you showed in providing those to us so that we can respond more fully. In answer to the first question, I am advised that the extension of deductions on mine site rehabilitation to expenditure on levees and dams necessary for rehabilitating a mine site will not have any significant revenue cost.

SPEECH.PARA: The second question, which senators will recall, was: does carrying out of eligible mining activities include construction and operation of tailings dam, dump leach pads or vat leach pads? If not, why not? The answer to that is: the tax treatment of expenditure on the construction and operation of tailings dams and similar activities is unaffected by the rewriting of the mining provisions by this bill. I am advised that such expenditure, if incurred in a commercial mining venture, would expect to qualify as allowable capital expenditure or as plant.

In relation to the third question, the answer is: the tax treatment of expenditure on rehabilitating a mine site is unaffected by the rewriting of the mining provisions by this bill. Whether particular activities qualify will depend on their own facts. I am advised that the activities referred to would appear to be associated with mining operations rather than rehabilitation. They could expect to qualify as allowable capital expenditure under the mining provisions.

In relation to the fourth question, Senator Margetts asked whether I can provide an example of a dam specifically constructed for no other purpose other than to provide water for rehabilitation. `To the best of our knowledge no such dams are constructed in Western Australia,' I think was the point you made. The answer to that is: I have no specific example in mind of a dam built solely for providing water for rehabilitation. However, an example could be where mineral sands require vegetation as part of the rehabilitation process and a dam is built at the site to facilitate that process.

In relation to the fifth question, Senator Margetts asked whether the rehabilitating of the mine site included expenditure on a variety of matters, including site assessment, monitoring and compliance reporting. The answer to that is: again, the tax treatment of expenditure on rehabilitating a mine site is unaffected by the rewriting of the mining provisions by this bill. Whether particular activities qualify as eligible will depend on their own facts. I am advised that the activities listed in the question would appear to be associated with rehabilitation and therefore deductible under those provisions. An alternative deduction may also be available under the environment provisions. That responds to the matters raised by Senator Margetts.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to question four was a little unclear. I asked: can the minister provide an example of a dam specifically constructed for no other purpose than to provide water for rehabilitation. It might have been the way you read it out, Minister, but I wonder if that was actually the question you answered? There were two other questions I asked within the fifth question: does rehabilitating the mine site include expenditure on changed land uses, for instance, wildlife habitat, which do not increase the residual market value of the rehabilitated area and does it include expenditure on recovery of contaminated seepage or erosion products?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I answered the fourth question. The wording I have is the wording that you have given me: `Can the minister provide an example of a dam specifically constructed for no other purpose than to provide water for rehabilitation?' That was the question you gave me.
—No—`other than'. You have missed out the word `other' and that's important.

—`for no other purpose other than to provide'—sorry, I may have missed that out in my rereading. The answer tackles that question. I have no specific example in mind of a dam built solely for providing water for rehabilitation. I then went on to say that an example could be where mineral sands require revegetation as part of the rehabilitation process and a dam is built at the site to facilitate that process.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the fifth question, the answer I gave covered those points you raised. In my summary of your question I did not mention the two matters which were in the original question. But the answer applies to those two matters—that is, the changed land use and the recovery of contaminated seepage or erosion products.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answers. It would seem that there has not actually been any explanation of why this amendment has been put in the bill. If the indication is that there is no significant revenue cost, one wonders why this has been put in the bill. I will still oppose this. I was hoping that I would be enlightened as to why it has been put in the bill. Perhaps the minister can tell us now.

SPEECH.PARA: If it means that in reality dams will not suddenly be considered to be rehabilitation if they have not been in the past, it does seem rather odd as to why it is here. Therefore, I think for clarity that part of the bill should be removed. If there is some reason in the future where the government can argue that there is a good reason for putting it there, I would be happy to hear it. I have not heard it yet. Therefore, I oppose clauses 330 to 435, page 307, lines 18 to 25.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the amendment that has just been moved and to put the opposition's view of that amendment. Before I do so, I draw attention to the fact that Senator Harradine made what I thought was a reasonable point when he said that this bill should not be just flicked through. It is more important than that. All taxpayers are affected by it. I am mindful that perhaps that was a stinging aside to my party, among others, because we had not spoken in this debate. I thought that was a reasonable point and that just one or two points should be put on the Hansard record from the point of view of the opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is a Labor initiative. It was commenced in 1994. It sprung from a basic, fundamental principle of taxation. If we go back to first principles here, one of the fundamental principles of taxation is that tax ought to be simple and it ought to be able to be transparently understood by individuals who are subject to that taxation. That is a fundamental first principle in our view, and it is one that I am pleased to acknowledge the government shares.

If you look at the tax act in Australia, you do not just look at a document; you actually look at a whole shelf of documents, as the tax act has grown like Topsy since 1936, when it was first brought down. There is a clear case here to simplify that. It is often asserted by tax experts that no‐one knows what the meaning of the entire act is. It is just too complex. This is often asserted by cynics who find these things, with justifiable cynicism in this case. They cite provisions of the tax act which sound like gobbledegook and confuse people and even, indeed, raise a laugh as to the supposed real meaning of that provision. When you have that type of complexity, it is a chance for lawyers to dine out on defining different meanings.

All I am saying is that we recognise—I think this is generally recognised—that there is a clear case to simplify this legislation, reduce it in size and make it as transparent and as accessible as possible to ordinary mortals so that you do not actually have to engage a high class lawyer at a fat fee in order to understand what your taxing obligations are.

Broadly, we support this initiative, having initiated it in the first place ourselves. I acknowledge that the process has been going for three years. A thing like this has to be approached with care. This has gone through several filters and over several hurdles to ensure that it has been properly scrutinised—the minister has recognised some of those—and it has been before the Joint Committee of Public Accounts of this parliament.

That committee broadly endorsed the bill but made some recommendations which have been picked up by the government. One of the important ones is the prospective operational date of this bill, which would be, if this chamber supports it, 1 July this year. That is still some months off, so that is a prospective operational date.

I will deal with a couple of the points that have been made. One is that because you change the words you change the meaning. That, on its face, is a point that appears to have some logic to it. But if one turns to section 1-3 in the bill, a section headed `differences in style not to affect meaning', a section in the bill that is taken from the Acts Interpretation Act to guide judges, law makers and mortals like me as to what the meaning should be, then you will see a provision there that says that, just because the words have changed for greater clarity, that should not infer that a different meaning was intended by that change in words.

To put that another way, as I comprehend it, section 1-3—`differences in style not to affect meaning', the copy of the Acts Interpretation Act provision—simply says that the jurisprudence of the old tax act stands behind these new words presented to us now. I think that ought to be clearly understood because that is a key element as to whether, in simplifying complex legislation, you lose the meaning and you lose the case law that has defined or refined the meaning over time. By virtue of that provision, we do not.

The second point that concerned me in particular—a point that was dwelt on with some force, passion and at length by Senator Harradine, all of those things being quite proper in advocating a view—was that there is some retrospective legislation here. In the chamber, retrospective legislation is to be avoided, certainly in tax matters where possible, although I would assert this for myself and indeed, I think, for my party: the only way in which you can be absolutely certain of preventing tax avoidance is if avoiders know that when they are unmasked and caught the legislature is prepared to retrospectively wipe out their ill‐gotten gains. Then there is no percentage in avoiding. If you can write legislation that does that while protecting legitimate uses, then that ought to be open in the area of tax law.

Having put that caveat on it, though, Senator Harradine is right that, apart from that avoidance issue, broadly one ought to steer clear of and not introduce retrospective legislation in this area. My understanding of what he may have been referring to—if he wishes to join the debate again and spell this out I would be pleased, but I am not necessarily inviting it—is that there is a provision in this act where companies engaging in early balancing of company accounts may be affected by an operational date of 1 July of this year. I understand that point. I do know that the JCPA considered that point at length and did not think it was necessary for any special consideration on that issue. That was a unanimous joint parliamentary committee report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recommendation 5.8?

—Of the JCPA. I do not have that report immediately in front of me, Senator, but when I relinquish the call and resume my seat I will check on that, and I reserve my right to come back and join the debate later if I think I have improperly presented the view. However, if that is the case of retrospectivity that is being referred to, I think I can adopt the view of the JCPA.

SPEECH.PARA: That leads me to comment briefly on the amendment moved by the Greens. So I do not delay the consideration in this chamber of this legislation, I also take the opportunity to comment on the circulated but not yet moved amendment from the Australian Democrats. Both relate to mine site rehabilitation. In the case of the Greens, I have heard the questions and the answers and I understand that the intent of this amendment would be to remove deduction for mining companies for mine site rehabilitation. Frankly, I do not understand how such an intention, if I comprehend it accurately, is consistent with an environmental viewpoint.

I would have thought that great strides have been made in the mining industry over recent years in mine site rehabilitation and that in fact Australia boasts some of the best examples of mine site rehabilitation in the world. I have in mind Alcoa in the Darling Scarp east of Perth, where they mine bauxite and have been able to recover the area and regrow native vegetation, including jarrah and marri trees, which are the natural vegetation of the area. I think that anyone with a concern for the environment is rightly concerned about mining activity because that does disrupt the natural environment as a direct and obvious consequence of mining. But these decisions are made on balance. The key issue is that at the end of the process it should be rehabilitated, and a tax concession to help provide that is a guarantee of the environment being returned as near as possible to its natural state at the conclusion of mining. I do not see that removing this provision is in fact answering the point about the need to protect the environment.

In any case, I make the observation that what we have here is an amendment that is not related to the purpose of the bill. The bill we have is a bill to simplify the meaning of the tax act. This amendment is to change one of those meanings. In other words, given that we have a simplification bill here, it is an opportunity for some honourable senators to want to change the meaning of the tax act. I do not think that is the purpose of this at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you change a word from `partially' to `fully', does that simplify it?

—No, that qualifies it. It enlarges the option if you go from `partially' to `fully', it would seem to me. It would not seem to me to be a simplification but a qualification in definitional terms. I just make the point that we are not here trying to change the tax act, or at least that is my comprehension of the purpose of this exercise today, yet this amendment would do that—
—I thought we were here to make better laws.

—Yes, we are here to make better laws, if I might take that interjection, but it is always open for senators to move these changes in other ways than by going against the purpose of this legislation. Therefore I will not be supporting the Margetts amendment. For similar reasons, I do not support the Democrats' amendment, although I think the Democrats' amendment is far more palatable. Their amendment removes `partially' and goes to `fully' and therefore is a direct incentive to engage in rehabilitation in full, not in part. I comprehend that, and in ordinary circumstances I would support that. But I say that we are not here to amend the act, we are here to simplify it, and therefore today I am voting for simplification.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude on the point that it is true that all taxpayers are affected by this. Of course all taxpayers are affected by any change to the act. I hope they are affected, and I believe they are affected, in a positive manner. A complex piece of legislation that occupies a shelf in a library and has grown like Topsy since 1936 is made more simple and accessible, and that is, as I said at the beginning, a key principle of what taxation law should be about. That is what we are about here and I hope we support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I again indicate that we will not be supporting the amendment moved by the Greens. I am frankly at a loss to understand the reason why that would be moved, particularly if you are interested in environmental outcomes. Perhaps Senator Margetts will enlighten us on that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Retrospectivity is a big issue. There is no question that whenever this issue comes up in this chamber people are rightly very concerned. This has been raised by a number of speakers, and I welcome the remarks that were put forward by Senator Cook. In relation to the issue that Senator Harradine raised relating to retrospectivity, I again make the point that the bills have been out since December 1995. Since then there has been a vast amount of notice.

In relation to the issue of some companies balancing early, and I think that was the substance of the point Senator Harradine made, this issue was very carefully considered by the JCPA and they did not see a case for special treatment for these companies. They noted that the usual case in all tax legislation is not to do so, and that occurs in budget legislation as well. In the report that I have before me, report 345 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, on page 39, section 5.11, it says:
The Committee does not believe that special allowances should be made for entities with early balancing SAPs.
It goes on to say that they would be:

. . . aware that by being out of sequence with most other taxpayers, they may be advantaged or disadvantaged by provisions designed for those using a standard income year. By convention, neither Budgets nor other tax law amendments make allowances for entities with SAPs and the Committee does not believe the 1996 Bill should set a precedent.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 February, on motion by Senator Ian Macdonald:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are pleased to be supporting this bill because we believe it is enshrining an important principle of the separation of powers, which I will make mention of further when I speak to the Family Law Amendment Bill later today, That important principle is the arms‐length distance of the executive from the judiciary, particularly as it pertains to decisions to prosecute for criminal offences.

SPEECH.PARA: At the Commonwealth level the Director of Public Prosecutions will now, as far as we read these provisions to operate, make all decisions to prosecute criminal offences under Commonwealth law. This is a welcome development. Those acts which will now have ministerial discretion removed in the decision to prosecute are the Australian Bicentennial Authority Act 1980, the Banks (Shareholdings) Act 1972, the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980, the Financial Corporations Act 1974, the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975, the Insurance Contracts Act 1984, the Prices and Surveillance Act 1983, the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951 and the Public Works Committee Act 1969.

BREAK.PARA: The Victorian Public Prosecutions Act was passed in 1994. It repealed that state's previous DPP Act. It did not contain many of the changes originally mooted. For example, it did not establish an officer of Deputy DPP. It was said by Bernard Bongiorno to preserve the independence of his office and to ensure that decisions were made honestly. The power of courts and petitioners to initiate contempt proceedings is fundamental to the effective administration of justice and goes to the core of judicial power in this country. Halsbury Laws of Australia defines contempt proceedings as:

Traditionally, contempt of court is divided into two categories. Criminal contempt involves acts or words which interfere with or tend to interfere with the administration of justice, and which amount to a public wrong. Sanctions imposed are punitive in nature. Civil contempt (also known as contempt in procedure) involves disobedience of the judgments, orders or other processes of the court and amounts to a private wrong. As the purpose of civil contempt is to assist enforcement for the private benefit of a party to proceedings, sanctions imposed are primarily coercive or remedial rather than punitive. Wilful disobedience of a court order constitutes a criminal contempt (especially if an element of public defiance is involved), as it involves a public injury that calls into play the courts's penal or disciplinary jurisdiction . . . Nevertheless, civil and criminal contempt share the same rationale, that is, the protection of the effective administration of justice.

This must be contrasted with the coalition government in Victoria which, under the stewardship of Mr Kennett and Ms Jan Wade, the state's Attorney‐General, has attacked the office of the DPP. In 1993 it was revealed that the Victorian Attorney‐General proposed to curb the DPP's independence by, among other things, appointing a deputy DPP who would report to the A‐G and have the power to veto decisions of the DPP. The Director of Public Prosecutions at that time was Mr Bernard Bongiorno, a person of considerable talent and repute in the legal profession and wider community.

A chronology up to December 1994 is as follows. In August 1993 the Victorian DPP, Mr Bongiorno, angered the Kennett government when he indicated that he considered contempt actions against Premier Kennett over comments about the arrest of the Frankston serial killer Paul Denyer. Denyer eventually pleaded guilty making possible contempt irrelevant. Mr Greg Craven, the Victorian Crown Counsel and the Attorney‐General, Ms Wade, began speaking confidentially to other crown prosecutors about `problems' in the DPP's office.

The Public Prosecutions Act 1994, referred to above, did remove the power of the DPP to initiate contempt proceedings. Under the 1994 act, only the Attorney‐General acting on the advice of the Solicitor‐General can initiate contempt proceedings. This must be contrasted strongly with the inherent power of federal courts to prosecute for contempt as well as the power of ordinary individuals to petition court for contempt orders, and by any analysis is a breach of the civil liberties of Victorian citizens.

In mid‐April 1995 the Victorian opposition leader, John Brumby, attacked Jan Wade for refusing to hold an inquiry into allegations that her office conspired to force Bernard Bongiorno from his office. The Victorian Society of Labor Lawyers also condemned the Kennett government and asked for a full disclosure of the government's rationale for wanting to limit the DPP's powers. After a Four Corners program, the Melbourne Age, on 12 April 1995, said:

The need for impartiality in these posts requires absolute independence from Government tampering but Victorians cannot be sure that complete detachment was exercised in the Bongiorno case. As a result, public respect for the legal process has been diminished and the blame for this must rest with Mrs Wade.

On the Four Corners program, allegations were made that a bill to reform the office of DPP had been drafted because the view was held that Mr Bongiorno had been a megalomaniac who had considered suing the Premier.

In September 1995, the Victorian Labor opposition called for a return of powers to initiate contempt of court proceedings to the DPP. There had been a contempt of court case against BHP. By engaging in an agreement with the PNG government about the Ok Tedi mine which would have made it a criminal offence for landowners to take action for compensation arising from mining, a single judge in the Victorian Supreme Court said that BHP was in contempt of court. This finding was overturned by the full court of the Victorian Supreme Court on appeal by BHP and the Attorney‐General because the Public Prosecutions Act 1994 had given the Victorian Attorney‐General the sole right to bring an action for contempt and because the plaintiffs—the PNG landowners—had therefore no standing to bring an action for contempt of court. This judgment was appealed to the High Court but the High Court found the provision of the Public Prosecutions Act valid, although three judges called for it to be reviewed.

The importance of the independence of the DPP is that, as an independent statutory office holder, it protects the public interest and gives confidence in the proper administration of criminal justice. Many criminal matters necessarily involve allegations of serious infringements of the law. It is thus doubly important that all citizens—of whatever status—are equally subject to the processes of the criminal law.

Impartiality in decision making about prosecutions is also important because of the characteristics of crime. Some of these are: crime has public implications—that is, the behaviour involved in crimes is viewed as having such an impact on the public interest that it should be punished by the state and not seen simply as a matter to be determined between individuals in a civil court; crimes have victims other than the defendant and the injury they cause to the defendant is such that criminals deserve punishment and perhaps incapacitation, through imprisonment, and not simply remediation in a civil court; some commentators believe that there is also a moral dimension to what is a crime, that crime involves behaviour that offends morality.

Decision makers, especially if they are not independent of government or are ministers of the Crown, may be or may be seen to be acting for party political reasons and no‐one should be above the law on those grounds. Under the Australian version of the Westminster system, there is a separation of powers between the executive, the legislature and the judiciary. The independence of those exercising judicial functions is important so that they can act independently from the other two arms of government and so that they can apply the law without favour and carry out their functions free from fear that a decision or action that is unpopular with the government will lead to their removal from office. Thus, it is important that politicians are removed from the control of the prosecution process.

It can be said that giving the power solely to the Attorney‐General to initiate contempt of court proceedings could lead to a potential conflict of interest between the responsibilities of the A‐G as the chief law officer and his or her political allegiances or the influence of big business—for example, in the case involving BHP and the Ok Tedi mine. In general, it can also be said that citizens should have a power to initiate proceedings for contempt. Contempt of court can occur when action is taken to intimidate a plaintiff.

The rule of law and adherence to democratic principles is bolstered by the effective separations of power. Ms Wade and Mr Kennett, by diluting that separation, made a substantial attack on those democratic rights which are the birthright of Victorian and Australian citizens. The Australian Democrats are pleased that the coalition, at least at a federal level, accords with those ideals. We believe that the passage of this bill will serve as a beacon and an example to people such as Ms Wade and Mr Kennett that certain tenets of our democracy—such as the independence of the DPP to initiate contempt proceedings—are not to be toyed with, particularly for the purpose of their political expediency. The Democrats and I commend to the Senate this bill and the principles it contributes in defining the contempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the legislation.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Minister, how many projects has the Australian Army commenced in the government's program to assist remote Aboriginal communities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that at this stage no projects have commenced. As I hope Senator Evans would realise, a long period of consultation was provided so that ATSIC, Aboriginal communities and the defence department would ensure that whatever work was undertaken by the defence department was consistent with the needs and wishes of Aboriginal people. I understand that that process is still continuing.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Minister, Saturday, 8 March is International Women's Day and falls just after the first anniversary of the election of the Howard government. Can the minister outline what the government has achieved for women in its first 12 months of office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to have the opportunity to extend my answer beyond the five‐minute limit, but let me get started on outlining all the things that we have done. We made commitments to women at the last election. During these last 12 months we have been busy honouring those commitments to women. Women of course are interested in the broader issues that relate to the economy, health and education, et cetera. After all, they voted for us in spades at the last election. They knew that we would do the job and they have been endorsing the effort we have made.

ANSWER.PARA: There are specific measures which we have undertaken to improve women's status in our community. They include economic security, blending work and family responsibilities, safety on the streets and in the home, the lack of women in decision making roles, women's health and women in regional Australia. Obviously in the time I have, I will have to be quick.

In my own portfolio, for example, our priorities have been: to develop opportunities for Australian women to participate in developing policy and programs; I have introduced a comprehensive consultative program for women's NGOs to have access to and to influence government; extensive consultations around Australia by myself and my staff; the establishment of a parliamentary advisory group; an annual two‐day round table; the publication of an annual report of the women NGOs of Australia; and an information booklet on the women MPs and the parliamentary committees and how to access both the MPs and committees. That is important because women need to be able to get their voices heard in the policy development and decision making process.

It is interesting that in 13 years of Labor they did not seem to know what the issues of importance to women were. In the 1993 election they had to import Anne Summers from New York to tell them what policies to put in place for that election. In the last election they had to spend $65,000 doing a poll on what issues women need to know and were concerned about.

We are keen to have women's input into policy making. We are keen to have more women in decision making and leadership positions. Of course, we already have a record number of women in the parliament and in the ministry and in the cabinet. Perhaps the Senate would not know that in the last year we increased the percentage of women on Commonwealth controlled boards and committees from 30.5 per cent, which we inherited on coming into government, to 31.5 per cent. I am not saying that that is terrific, but it is an improvement. The trend is up. You would be complaining if it was down. Tomorrow I intend to announce a pilot program to improve those figures even more.

BREAK.PARA: Women have been appointed, including in my own portfolio, to major positions in government. Sue Vardon will be heading up the new Commonwealth Services Agency and Anthea Tinney will be heading up the Environment Protection Group. They are just two. The Treasurer appointed two very senior and capable women to very important boards the moment he gained office. There have been many others.

Our workplace relations act will help women in the workplace by ensuring equal remuneration for work of equal value, by ensuring anti-discrimination and establishing the employee advocate. Permanent part‐time work will be protected and encouraged. Working women's centres are established and protected. The Work and Family Unit will be re‐established to promote government policy and to assist employees balance their work and family responsibilities.

Other measures include: agreement between Commonwealth and state governments to work together on work and family issues; superannuation and retirement incomes; the establishment of retirement savings accounts; opting out provisions for those on low incomes; an 18 per cent rebate on contributions made on behalf of a carer spouse; an ability to contribute to superannuation beyond the age of 65; and an examining of the treatment of superannuation on divorce. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. The minister has outlined a very impressive array of achievements. Are there any other government initiatives which are promoting the interests of women in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a great opportunity to give you some more information. Women are very concerned about their families. Thirty-four new community based marriage and relationship education services will be established this year. The family tax initiative is in the pockets of nearly two million Australian families. The national carer action plan will allow carers, 67 per cent of whom are women, an additional 10 days of respite a year and an additional 10 hours a week that they may spend in employment, voluntary work, education or training.

BREAK.PARA: We have addressed the hard issues, such as gun control. The national campaign against violence in crime will aim to increase women's safety and prevent crime in our communities. We had a two-day domestic violence forum, which is leading to a domestic violence summit between the leaders of all the governments in Australia. We are determined to do what we can as a government, as leaders, to prevent and respond to domestic violence. Some of the other portfolios that have been taking action in this area are Veterans' Affairs, Attorney-General's and small business. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Can you assure the Senate that any new Medicare or pharmaceutical benefits scheme arrangements you plan to trial, say, over a four-year period, are not a sneaky and underhand way of capping or restricting access to services available through Australia's universal Medicare system, thereby undermining the Prime Minister's more and more non-core commitment to preserve Medicare?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I utterly reject any suggestion that this government would do things in any portfolio in a sneaky way. Therefore, the basis of the question is false.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Having cut $500 million out of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme last year, is it not true that the minister and this government, with the knowledge of the Prime Minister, are planning to cut a further $800 million from pharmaceuticals in the upcoming budget, thereby increasing the amount of co‐payment that everyone will have to pay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

I utterly reject any attempt by the Labor opposition to try to go back down that route of scaring people that they went down last year prior to the budget. It is no good, Senator. —My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy, and concerns the Hunter Valley, the energy powerhouse of New South Wales. Coal in the Hunter has given the region a tremendous economic base over the past 80 years and it is essential that we encourage and support its development. Would the minister please inform the Senate of the future potential for the growth in exports of Australian coal and the significance of this growth for the Hunter Valley region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to respond to Senator Sandy Macdonald, who has his electorate office in the heart of the Hunter Valley coalfields. Senators are hopefully aware that the Hunter Valley is the cradle of the coal industry in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: We are not the biggest coal producer in the world. There are other much greater producers than Australia, including: China at about 1.4 billion tonnes of coal; members of the European Union at about 1.2 billion tonnes; the United States at about 900 million tonnes; and India at about 450 million tonnes. We are, however, the largest exporter of coal, as we supply low ash, low sulfur coals to foreign steel mills, power utilities and general industry. This represents an export income in the order of $8 billion a year.

As forecasted at the APEC energy ministers conference last year in Sydney, there will be enormous demand for energy infrastructure between now and the year 2010 if the projected growth rate in the Asia-Pacific region is to be realised. It will not, however, just happen. We have keen competitors in countries such as Indonesia, South Africa, the United States and Canada. It is vital that our competitiveness be maintained and any impediments to expansion and new developments be addressed.

The Hunter Valley, with its resources, infrastructure and ports, is well placed to take advantage of the anticipated demand for semi-soft and thermal coals. Following discussions I had last year and representations I made to the Indian minister responsible for mines, both here and in New Delhi, I am pleased to advise the Senate that I have been informed by the Indian High Commission that tariffs on all coals have been significantly reduced. The coal tariff reductions announced in the Indian budget are: coking coal with ash of less than 12 per cent has been reduced from five per cent to three per cent, coking coal with ash greater than 12 per cent has been reduced from 20 per cent to 10 per cent and non-coking coal has been reduced from 20 per cent to 10 per cent.

Australia is already the major supplier of imported coking coals to India. India takes about 98 per cent of its coking coals from Australia, with plans to increase its steel making capacity from the current level of 22.5 million tonnes to about 40 million tonnes over the next five to six years. The market for imported coking coal is expected to grow from almost 11 million to 18 to 20 million tonnes.

For steaming coals, the gap between supply and demand in India is currently estimated to be 10 to 15 million tonnes. With prospective growth in power production, this is expected to grow to as much as 50 million tonnes by the year 2000. This change in tariffs will be of benefit to both Australia and India. Indian coals are around 45 per cent ash, so we have the opportunity to blend with the Indian coals to improve their quality and also to supply coals into their thermal power stations for independent power producers. This offers enormous opportunities for the Hunter Valley which has particular expertise in the values that are important—low ash, low sulfur.

Because of interest from Thailand and the emergence of independent power producers, I have sponsored a trip to the Hunter by environmental journalists. Clean Australian coals will replace lignite in Thailand, which burns with a much higher emission rate than our coals. This, again, opens opportunities for the Hunter and for the rest of the Australian coalfields. I have moved to remove export controls on coal which remain a longstanding impediment to a greater reliance on Australian coals in the Asian region. Provided the condi tions I have outlined are met, we will see an expansion of the industry in the Hunter and Australia. (Time expired)

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women
