ANSWER.PARA: The minister for health is doing his upmost to try to restore the situation which occurred after 13 years of mismanagement of the health portfolio by his predecessors. If you want to start to study health, you might go back and have a good look at what your Labor government did in the health area. All Australians understand that there is a job to be done and Dr Wooldridge is busy doing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. I refer to my question two days ago which revealed that an oil and gas exploration permit had been granted for world heritage listed Shark Bay. I ask two groups of questions. Firstly, is there any way you can have this permit now rescinded and this decision reversed? Can you, for example, insist that a full environmental impact statement is done before any seismic activity goes ahead? Secondly, looking to the future, how can we prevent state governments, or in this case one state minister, bypassing their own environment departments, the federal environment department and the federal minister and issuing such permits? If we cannot protect Shark Bay—with all the natural beauty that it has, with the stromatolites, the seagrass beds, the dolphins and turtles, and indeed Monkey Mia, a major tourist attraction—what can we protect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that in effect this permit that has been given is to allocate a block for exploration, but that any seismic exploration of the type you refer to would actually require a full EIS under Western Australian law before it could proceed. We are still trying to ascertain the full ramifications of the type of permit that has been given, but that is the best advice that I have got at the moment.

ANSWER.PARA: It is still the position of my department that in fact we were not advised of the intention to issue this permit before it was issued. Of course, as you are hinting at, at the moment there is no legal obligation on Western Australia to do so. One might reasonably have expected them to do so however, bearing in mind that they would appreciate our responsibility under the international arrangements to protect the world heritage values for which Shark Bay was listed. Nevertheless, we were not advised and we think that that is regrettable.

BREAK.PARA: I will take the opportunity, before I answer the second part of your question, to reaffirm what my colleague Mr Warwick Smith said in the other place yesterday—that is, we are committed to maintaining those world heritage values, very special values, that apply to Shark Bay which you have mentioned. As I recall, Shark Bay was in fact listed under all four of the criteria for world heritage listing, which is really quite exceptional. It is a wonderful place. Subject to hearing the Western Australian government case, I find it very difficult to imagine how mining exploration of this type could be consistent with those world heritage values.

The second part of the honourable senator's question related to what processes can we put in place to ensure that this does not occur again, that such permits are not issued without the Commonwealth having the opportunity to provide input. I regret to say that we were handed the Shark Bay world heritage listing with very few of the appropriate mechanisms for administration in place. There was no ministerial council. There was no agreement between the Commonwealth and the states setting out the basis for administration. There was no management plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was responsible for that?

—That was Senator Faulkner's job, but he was not able to achieve that. I am pleased to say that we have made some progress in the short time we have been in government. I believe we have now settled the boundary issue, which I gather was holding up previous negotiations. We have agreed to set up the ministerial council, which I expect to meet before the end of this financial year.

BREAK.PARA: We have a draft agreement with Western Australia—this is the key point for Senator Lees—which in fact would have obliged Western Australia to have informed us before they had of issued such a permit. We trust that that draft will be settled and that agreement will be in place soon. We have also a draft management strategy, which we intend to progress to finalisation as a matter of urgency. So these proper mechanisms for administration are being put in place by the new government. It is a matter of some regret that they were not in place at the time we took office, because then this would not have occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. But, Minister, can you understand the ramifications of this? Basically, what you are saying is that no world heritage area in this country is protected unless a full management plan is in place. Is it not correct that the majority of world heritage areas do not have a full management plan? Can you give us some details as to how many management plans are still outstanding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —As you are suggesting, some have them and some do not. We are committed to completing management plans on those that are outstanding. Coincidentally, this morning I was working on the issue of the management plan for Fraser Island. We do not have one for there as such. There is a Queensland government management plan that covers Fraser Island and the adjoining mainland.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth still maintains mechanisms to protect against action by any party that would be inconsistent with those world heritage values. The real criticism in this instance—and it is a criticism that I make—is that we should have been informed of an activity that might ultimately damage those world heritage values, so at least we would have had the opportunity to provide input before that first permit was given. Preventive action is obviously much better than action taken after the event. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. In light of your recent answer to Senator Tierney on the benefits provided to women by your government to commemorate International Women's Day, can you say how, as a result of your 1996 budget cuts, child-care fees, which are now increasing by $20 to $25 a week, are helping women and their families? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

Opposition senators interjecting—

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. I refer the minister to the forthcoming joint military exercise codenamed Tandem Thrust, which will take place off the Queensland coast. Is the minister satisfied that the activities to be undertaken as part of that exercise are consistent with all Commonwealth environmental legislation? In particular, could the minister indicate if he is satisfied that any discharge of waste into the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park by US or Australian navy vessels does not breach the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975?

—I would say that I have been impressed with the efforts made by both the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the Department of Defence to assure us of high environmental standards during this important defence exercise. I believe that all provisions of the act are being complied with. We have already, I think, tabled quite a lot of material on the environmental agreements that have been reached in relation to the exercise, and there is some further material that I intend to table for Senator Reynolds at the end of this question time. So I believe that both the detail and spirit of the legislation are being complied with.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for the answer, inadequate though it is. I refer the minister to the government's own words in relation to section 38J which basically allow the discharge. Obligations are imposed in relation to the discharge of waste, in particular to avoid an unintended result. At present, discharges from defence vessels and aircraft for the purposes of combating pollution incidents or saving lives are not lawful under the operation of section 38J. Would the minister care to comment on whether or not that is the case?

—What I have said is that I think all permits that are required for the defence exercise have been granted. The authority has advised me that the Department of Defence marine headquarters applied for a permit for a number of small vessels to discharge sewage. Those permits were granted on 18 February 1997.
—They have not got any legal basis, have they, Minister?

The situation is, as I have already said about four times in here today: there is not going to be any attempt to speculate on budgetary matters, whether they are in, whether they are out, or whether they are even being considered. —My question is addressed to the Minster representing the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice. Senator, a recent special AGB McNair poll shows that 77 per cent of surveyed respondents were in favour of the Prime Minister's stance on gun control. Can you advise the Senate of what progress on firearm law reform has been achieved by the government since the tragic events in Port Arthur last year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coonan for her question. Already more than 330,000 prohibited firearms have been surrendered throughout Australia as part of the Australian firearms buyback scheme—over 330,000. About 12,000 semiautomatic rifles and pump action shotguns are now being handed back in Australia each week—12,000 each week. Now that Queensland has begun its buyback, it can be anticipated that this rate will increase substantially. More than $163 million has been paid to firearms owners in compensation.

ANSWER.PARA: All jurisdictions have amended existing legislation or passed new firearms laws to give effect to the Australian Police Ministers Council resolutions. All states and territories, with the exception of South Australia, now have compensation schemes in place. The South Australian buyback scheme began on 9 September last year and concluded on 28 February this year, with more than 60,000 firearms having been handed in in that state alone. The firearms amnesty will continue in South Australia and in all other jurisdictions until 30 September this year.

The Commonwealth is conducting an Australia-wide public education campaign to inform the community about the new laws and to inform gun owners of their rights and of their responsibilities. The campaign is tailored to the needs, and has the full support, of each jurisdiction. Each jurisdiction is consulted by the Commonwealth on every step taken. This is in marked contrast, I might add, to the sorts of activities undertaken by the previous government which basically behaved like a thug towards the states.

This coordination is done by a state and territory's campaign coordinating group which meets regularly and is in constant contact by phone. Independent research has shown that phase one of the public education campaign has been most successful.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators opposite might wish they were in government and handling this as well as this government is, but they were tipped out and they lost that opportunity. No doubt they do look at how this matter has been handled and wish that when they were in government they displayed the same competence on a whole range of other issues.

ANSWER.PARA: The campaign has achieved a high level of awareness of the new laws among gun owners and the community generally. Awareness amongst gun owners has risen from 30 per cent in July last year to 48 per cent in December. The awareness has led to a high rate of compliance amongst gun owners with the new laws. Phase two of the advertising component of the campaign is currently under development and the television advertisements are expected to go to air in April of this year.

The public education campaign is both on time and on target. The firearms law reforms have multi-partisan support of the overwhelm ing majority of the Australian people—that is, about 80 per cent support for the new firearms law; 60 per cent being strongly in support. The government is committed to seeing the continued successful implementation of these reforms across Australia and, with the cooperation of the states, territories and firearm owners across the country, the Commonwealth looks forward to seeing Australia become a safer place for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the minister representing the Minister for Health, Senator Newman. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

When you see the sort of leadership that they have got, you can understand it. After a whole year of wallowing in their sorrows at losing government, you would think they would be starting to be interested in policy now. All we get is game playing. TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps the minister could answer this question: does the fact that the department needs to spend at least $4.4 million over the next four years on private health insurance policy development mean that the Howard government has conceded that the much‐trumpeted private health insurance rebate—the centrepiece of your policy to get more people to take out private health insurance—is a complete and utter failure even before it starts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I reject the premise altogether.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, you would be aware that the national landcare program is currently under review following a highly critical report into irregularities in funding allocations which were found by the Commonwealth ombudsman who investigated the allocation of landcare funds through the Boorowa community in New South Wales. Also, at additional estimates hearings last week, the assistant secretary of the community and regional branch of the national landcare program agreed with my concerns about the opposition from the Yungaburra community to the Eacham Shire Council's use of landcare funds for a sewerage project for that township on the Atherton Tablelands. What steps has the government taken to fix the problems at Boorowa and Yungaburra? What will the government do to ensure that landcare funds are allocated for genuine environmental purposes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Woodley for his question. On behalf of Mr Anderson, I wish to express the government's support and admiration for the work of the landcare movement. Australia is currently celebrating national landcare month and it is important that all citizens recognise the magnificent commitment that voluntary landcare groups have made to natural resources management over the last 10 or 15 years.

ANSWER.PARA: There are currently 3,250 landcare groups in Australia with an estimated membership in excess of 25,000 people. In late 1996 the ombudsman, while recognising that landcare funds provided to the Boorowa New South Wales landcare group in 1992 had been expended for the purposes for which they were granted, it highlighted some areas were landcare project submissions and assessment processes could be improved. A plan of action is being implemented to address those processes.

The Yungaburra case is an excellent example of where the Commonwealth has exercised care and responsibility in ensuring that environmental and community endorsement processes are followed before projects are finally approved for expenditure. Since 1993-94 the Commonwealth has withheld funding until those clearances are obtained. Currently, the project is with the Queensland government and relevant local government authorities for completion of environmental and community clearance processes.

While the Commonwealth and state governments contribute significant funds to landcare, landholders themselves make a contribution many times over in terms of their own funding, materials and labour. Australia has established an enviable reputation in relation to its level of the community participation in landcare activities and I believe their efforts should be fostered and encouraged at all times.

Landcare encapsulates the true Australian spirit of tackling seemingly insurmountable problems head on through strong individual commitment and effort. Their efforts have certainly made a big difference, but there is still an extremely big challenge out there and a lot more work still to be done. I urge the community to get in behind the many thousands of individuals who are out there doing their bit, planting trees, protecting areas of remnant vegetation, fencing off rivers, creeks and wetlands, repairing areas of erosion, reducing sedimentation of rivers and a myriad of other activities which will leave future generations with a greatly enhanced environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer and the assurance of support for landcare. I think we all endorse that. Minister, I am still a little concerned. Given the examples of the irregularities in landcare funding, which I have detailed and you have answered, and in light of the weaker guidelines for the National Heritage Trust Fund and the imminent appointment of a former government member to chair the National Landcare Advisory Committee—instead of your minister's preferred nominee—how will the government prevent the national heritage trust from becoming a slush fund?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the latter part of your question has been adequately debated ad nauseam. It is not going to be a slush fund. Senator Hill has made that very clear. In regard to the second part of your question about who is going to chair the landcare commission, let me say that the minister, Mr Anderson, had discussions with a number of people, including Mr Farley. He is the one you mentioned yesterday, but there were others as well. At that stage no decision had been made about who is going to be the chairman of the landcare committee. With regard to the follow-up question that I think you raised about Yungaburra, I pointed out that the Commonwealth had withheld funding on that particular area. I might also point out that sewage reuse—(Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, you would recall that in a Senate estimates hearing last night there was a discussion on the description `Third World' in respect of Aboriginal living conditions. In dismissing this description, you said—and I will quote from Hansard —`It is a term that is used almost colloquially to suit the person's position that is making the statement.' When I drew your attention to the fact that the Prime Minister himself had used precisely this phrase in his third headland speech in describing the living conditions of many indigenous Australians, you said—and I quote again from the Hansard —`I have to educate him, Senator Collins. He is as ignorant as you are.' Minister, in fact you said you were going to have to educate him on three separate occasions. Minister, when is your education of this `ignorant Prime Minister' about to begin?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins was the one who drew attention to the fact that Hansard could not show a shrug of the shoulders. We were joking at the time. He well knows that. His colleagues at the back laughed when he asked that question. It is a classic example of dredging through things. He will well recall that the committee had almost finished. We were joking across the chamber. It was a joke. Doesn't he recognise a joke? Senator Collins will have to ask Hansard to put the word `joke' in the record, because he has made a joke of himself by bringing this question up here.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Collins, are you seriously asking me to discuss the semantics of conditions in Aboriginal communities? That is what you are doing. Maybe you should ask your colleagues behind you. You were in government for 13 years. Collectively you are responsible for the conditions in Aboriginal communities. This sort of ridiculous and petty questioning demonstrates where the ALP is at at the moment. They are reduced to squabbling about degrees of deprivation in Aboriginal communities.

It is absolutely irrelevant whether two years ago the Prime Minister said that living conditions `are akin to those of a Third World country' when I said, comparing conditions in Rwanda, that they were technically not Third World conditions. It is irrelevant. In the context of last night, it was a joke.

We all acknowledge that conditions are appalling. I am surprised that Senator Collins wants to keep drawing attention to that fact. If that is the only question he can ask, then he should be ashamed. There are so many other issues of much greater importance than the textbook definition of Third World conditions. To quote George Campbell—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are reading this.
—I am going to quote, Senator Cook. Recently on a Four Corners program, George Campbell said:

ANSWER.PARA: I don't think the party knows or has a clear perception of what it stands for or, more importantly, what it wants to achieve in terms of development of our society.

As I said, it would do more good to explain the definition of the Australian Labor Party and what it stands for, because there seem to be many more discrepancies there than any other discrepancies that Senator Collins has alluded to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. As anybody who is interested enough—and a few will be, I know—to look at the Senate Hansard will see, it was no joke. The matter was pursued at some length. Minister, if you are uncomfortable about going back two years in respect of this expression `Third World' and about people who need `re-educating', let us just go back to the last year. Minister, could I remind you that in an answer to a dorothy dixer on the living conditions of Aboriginal people in Australia—from your own colleague, the late Senator Panizza—last year you stated, and I quote from page 1688 of the Senate Hansard , `Many indigenous people are living in Third World conditions.' Minister, if you consider that the Prime Minister and I are `ignorant' and need your `education' to correct us for making these statements who, Minister, is going to educate you?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like a lot of people, believed that phrase then. I would draw Senator Collins's attention to A Dictionary of Modern Politics by David Robertson, where he says:

ANSWER.PARA: The label Third World is probably too deeply entrenched to be avoided, but in fact very few statements using it can be made with any reliability (as, increasingly, with the other two worlds), and any degree of precision requires so many qualifications as to render the tripartite categorisation largely useless.
I would also draw Senator Collins's attention to Safire's New Political Dictionary: the definitive guide to the new language of politics . It states:
The `Third World' urgently needs to be renamed . . .

I would also draw his attention to Roger Scruton's A Dictionary of Political Thought . I would ask him to go and read that too, as I did. I would ask the gallery to read that so that they get some idea of it as well. We really are scraping the bottom of the barrel when there are so many problems out there that they—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I ask the minister whether she is aware of the legal action being planned by four university graduates in New Zealand against the Victoria University in Wellington, seeking damages from the university, alleging that the teaching and services they received and for which they paid fees were substandard and poorly planned. Could the minister please comment on this very important issue of principle and advise the Senate whether students in Australian universities may be able to use the Trade Practices Act to launch class actions based on similar grounds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for her question. Yes, I am aware, in a very general way, of the case before the courts in New Zealand where post‐graduate fee paying students have taken a university to court for alleged breach of contract and negligence. As with any other customer service, a student has the right to take legal action if the product purchased is not satisfactory. While the Trade Practices Act, as I am advised, does not apply in these circumstances, the state equivalents—that is, the fair trading acts or whatever name they go under—may well have application to universities.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian higher education institutions are well aware of the importance of their reputation and one would hope that none of them would let their reputation fall to such a point by offering courses of such a low level that Australian students felt obliged to take action. That would be a most regrettable situation, but it is not a situation that one forecasts as being likely to happen at all.

The reputations of universities are gained and maintained by consistently providing quality courses, teaching of the highest standard and a wide range of services to their students. It was the Labor government that introduced fee paying post‐graduate places in Australian universities and in last year's budget we extended that to undergraduate places. However, it must be understood, because some senators opposite would like to create some flack on the air waves in respect to this matter, that the flexibility to increase funding to universities is of course available to them only after they have filled their government funded places. The government is very much looking to the expansion of the sources of income to universities, such as through the provision of fee paying courses, to enhance the quality of higher education in Australia.

Both the government and the universities are aware that to offer a substandard course simply to pursue additional revenue would in fact in the medium to longer term be very counterproductive for any university that sought to take that on. I have no doubt that Australian universities will continue to offer both their Australian and international students an education which is world class.

It is very important to understand the difference between the people on this side and the people on that side with respect to additional charges to students. On this side of the chamber, we believe that higher education students get a lot more than the 75 per cent who do not go to higher education. It is fair to ask them to pay a higher contribution. People opposite do not think that. They think if you are academically bright you should get everything and they do not worry so much about the other 75 per cent.

We also believe that if you pay for something, if your dollars are going into it, you demand a better service. By having fee paying students and higher contributions on government students we believe the student population will become more demanding of universities, and by the student population becoming more demanding they will themselves increase the quality of education for future graduates.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, is it true, as claimed by John Short in an article in the Australian newspaper on Monday this week, that the Prime Minister has `effectively had his department, or private staff, "shadow"' you? What does this actually entail? Is this person a departmental officer or a staffer in the Prime Minister's office? How much, Minister, does this exercise cost the taxpayer? Does it impinge on your privacy? I would also be interested to know, Minister, in view of the answer you have just given to Senator Collins's question, whether this person shadowing you reported to the Prime Minister on your performance at last night's estimates committee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Robert Ray, come down to the front bench and raise the IQ of both benches please. He needs to. Madam President, you will remember Senator Ray asking me about the figure that was accompanying me around Australia—this shadowy figure that was coming with me and being seen on television. We eventually tracked that figure down and—
—That was no shadow; that was my wife!

—It was my wife. I even got the Federal Police involved to track this person down because I was concerned that there was a shadowy figure coming around with me that I was unaware of. Senator Ray asked me about it and it was followed up in questions in the same way as the fellow on the string at the front there is being led from the back bench.

ANSWER.PARA: This shadowy figure is like the other shadowy figure that was around with me—a figment of their imagination. I suggest that they ask that correspondent, because he never rang me. I have never met him; I do not know who he is. Perhaps he is another shadowy figure. I suggest you contact that person because I am totally unaware. If there is somebody, would you please let me know who it is so I can find out myself, Senator Faulkner? It is a shadowy figure and a figment of your imagination, as I suspect it is of the correspondent's.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. This article outlines Mr Howard's adoption of Mr Fraser's style of dealing with ministers he has lost confidence in and does indicate that he has `effectively had his department or private staff shadow' you. Minister, how can you be sure there is no basis to these reports that the Prime Minister is in fact having you shadowed? I ask you, as a result of that newspaper article: have you checked with the Prime Minister that he is not shadowing you and not spying on you?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I can be absolutely sure, because we have a Prime Minister now who does not go behind people's backs, who stands up for his ministers and who speaks to them directly. Look back on his predecessor, that fellow they decided to bury the other day. I saw that on the front page of BRW magazine: they are burying him now. They do not want to know he exists. I am proud of our Prime Minister. I think he is the first Prime Minister this country has had for many years, certainly of the series of Prime Ministers you have had in the past—
—Too late to crawl.
—Order! Senator Faulkner.

—Senator Faulkner has just demonstrated how they get on in the Labor Party. They crawl. He has just admitted it. We on this side do not have to crawl. We are appointed by the Prime Minister. We do not have to crawl to factions, as they do on the other side. They have to crawl up certain orifices that we don't have to. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I think it was yesterday that Senator Faulkner took a point of order and was tongue in cheek, I think in his mind at least, claiming that the dignity of the Senate, or words to that effect, were offended by false points of order. I ask you to consider that if you are going to listen to that kind of insincere rubbish from Senator Faulkner, then you should not allow him to sit over there the next day and behave in complete contrast to the manner in which he told you people on this side should behave. If you let him sit there and keep interjecting and interjecting, next time he stands up and puts a point of order, claiming that the place ought to be run as the people of Australia expect it to be run, he should be sat down or chucked out.
—Order! I will consider it.
—Madam President, has my time expired?
—Yes, it has.
—I was going to ask about the shadowy figure on the back bench that Senator Faulkner should be asking about.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—I table a response to matters raised by Senator Reynolds in her notice of motion No. 454 in relation to Operation Tandem Thrust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) to questions without notice asked by Senators Neal, O'Brien, Crowley and Lundy today, relating administration of the health and family services portfolio.

When this government was elected, we thought it would mean pain for the community, but particularly for young families with children in child care, for the elderly and for the sick—particularly for the sickest and the frailest, those in nursing homes. We did not know how horribly right we were.

In last year's budget pain was inflicted. This pain was inflicted by net cuts of $1.7 billion to the Department of Health and Family Services; $800 million in cuts to public hospitals, leading to longer waiting lists and a reduction in the quality of service; cuts to states grants in areas of public health; abolishment of the Commonwealth dental health program; increases in the pharmaceutical co-payment, both for concessional and general patients; the closure of 84 Medicare offices over three years; and cuts to a variety of procedures in terms of the Medicare payments, which means that patients are paying more out of their pockets.

BREAK.PARA: There were cuts in aged care; the introduction of an entry fee for nursing homes, an average of $26,000 up to $88,000; resident fees of $24 a day, which approximately 35 per cent of those in aged care facilities will have to pay; removal of the exemption for deeming on the first $2,000 of pensioners' bank accounts; and the increase in the user charges for HACC services.

There were cuts in child care—cuts to the operational subsidy meant that families had to pay an extra $35 a week—the introduction of a means test for the child‐care rebate and a tightening of the means test for the child‐care allowance, which meant again that families had to pay more. It also meant that 5,500 child‐care places that should have been built were not.

But this is not where the pain ends. We know now that in the Department of Health and Family Services a committee led by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has decreed that a further $1.365 billion will be cut. That means that families with kids in child care, the elderly and the sick get slugged once again.

The minister might say that she does not know about this, but certainly this is not surmising. This is not guessing. This is not predicting. This is not scaremongering. A document we have been provided with shows that this is the case. It shows that $800 million of that money is going to come out of pharmaceutical. That means bigger co-payments, more money being paid by pensioners and families for their prescriptions. Four hundred million dollars is coming out of child care—again, higher costs for families with kids.

That is not all. We don't know the exact figures, but the balance is made up of things like reducing the rebate for medical expenses for those who are in aged care facilities. Do we see that as fair that those who are sick and elderly and have to go into a nursing home cannot get any rebate for their medical expenses, even though everyone else can?

We also know that the government is looking at reducing the income threshold for the private health insurance levy. Over time, more and more people in the community will have to pay the additional levy if they do not compulsorily take up private health insurance.

We also know that there is going to be a reduction in money going to the states for public hospitals—so don't you pretend that you do not know what this is about, because you are inflicting pain and you are doing it willingly. I know that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Senator Ellison) is well aware of this. The document has been provided to him. It seems to me a little bit peculiar that a document should be provided to the parliamentary secretary, who only did his first piece of legislation yesterday, when in fact the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services in this place (Senator Newman) seems to be completely ignorant of what is taking place. But let me assure you that I am well aware, and very shortly the whole community will be aware that you have planned for them a further cut of $1.3 billion for the Department of Health and Family Services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed the height of cheek for the opposition to come in here and criticise this government, which has been in power for the sum total of 12 months, when we bear in mind that the opposition had 13 years to fix the disastrous situation in relation to health care that we have in Australia today. This is the government that has taken the initiative to give incentive to people to privately health insure.

SPEECH.PARA: Just recently, legislation was brought forward in this chamber and the opposition, grudgingly, agreed to it. They agreed to it because they could see the merit in it. But, even then, they had to put forward an amendment which indexed the thresholds which applied to the incentives bill and to the levy charge that the government brought in.

This is what the government was saying to the people of Australia: `If you privately health insure, we will give you a benefit. We will make it more attractive for you to privately health insure, and thereby take the pressure off the public health system.' At the other end of the scale were those who were well off and who did not privately health insure. We said to them: `If you keep doing that, we will impose a levy.'

Remember that the previous Prime Minister, Paul Keating, said that he did not have private health care. I think Carmen Lawrence, the former health minister, did not have private health care despite being able to afford it. I ask this chamber and the people of Australia: is it fair that people who can afford to look after themselves do not do so? Should they be a burden on the public health system when the public health system is there to catch those people who are concessional card holders and those people who are unable to afford private health care? That is what it is there for—to catch them. That is the safety net which this government is going to provide.

This government is going to take the pressure off the public health system and it is going to wean people back on to private health. We heard Senator Neal say in the debate the other day that the rate of decline of the exodus of people from private health had gone from 0.45 per cent per quarter to 0.25 per cent—almost halved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under us.

—That was quoted in the last 12 months, Senator Crowley. That was a result of the announced policies of this government, so I say to this chamber that the people of Australia are getting the message. There is an incentive to go into private health, and we will see a turnaround in the rate of decline. In the last three years, the rate of participation in private health has declined by some three per cent. That is disgraceful. I ask the opposition: what did you do for 13 years in relation to public health care? You presided over the biggest exodus from private health care that this country had ever seen. You presided over the greatest overburdening of public health that this country had seen. That, in turn, increased hospital queues, increased the pressure on public hospitals and produced the situation that we have today.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has said that this initiative is not the total answer. Indeed, it is not. It is the first step in a strategy to achieving that total answer. We are not saying to the people of Australia: `We have got the answer overnight.' Certainly we haven't. But we do have the first step in a well thought out strategy to get this country back on track in relation to health. That will entail a system where people who can afford to privately insure themselves for health do so, and take themselves off the public health system. That, after all, is what we are all about. We want to see the burden on the public health system alleviated and it can only be done as I have said.

So all these furphies that the opposition trots out are just that. Just 12 months ago, we put our policy before the people of Australia and they endorsed it overwhelmingly. The polls still show that if we were to have an election today we would have the same result. I say to the opposition: you ought to take note of that because the fact is that the people of Australia are still behind us 12 months on. I bet you that in two years, when we go back to them, they will still be supporting us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ellison, you are a brave man for getting up with that rhubarb.
—Rhubarb's good for you.

—I think it is fantastic that you would appeal to the people in the gallery, asking them to support you on a presumption that they would. You ask those folk what they voted for. They voted for Mr Howard's saying he would support Medicare. They did not vote for Mr Howard to white‐ant it—to undercut it, to pay money to private health insurance instead of to our public hospitals.
—We're helping it.

—No, he didn't, Senator. The people of Australia also thought they were voting for preservation of child care, because you promised absolutely that you would not cut child‐care dollars. You promised that you would not attack the community based child‐care sector; that you would not means test the child‐care cash rebate and that you would not stop the growth in community based child care. You have broken every one of those promises. What it comes down to is that families in Australia now pay $20 to $25 a week more for their child care than they did last year. Why are you leaving, Senator Ellison? Don't you like the facts?
—I'm not; I'm going over there.

—Very good! We can keep at you as you keep walking along. You tell me how it is that the families of Australia are better off paying $20 to $25 a week for their child care when all you are going to give them is a $4 tax rebate—and, provided one parent stays at home, they will get a bit more.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of Australia are not stupid. They do not buy those kinds of silly arguments, and they do not buy broken promises. Don't hold your breath on how long families will stay with you once they understand the full facts of what you have been doing. They will now have to find extra money. Your government's document shows that you intend to add much further pain in the child‐care area. We do not know how much you will increase fees again, but we suspect it will be another $20. This document states:
The balance of child care savings to reach the proposed Department of Finance child care figures of $315 million in total by introducing the least awful of the Department of Finance lists.
That sounds like a very authentic document from the Department of Finance, and so it is.

We want to know from you, Senator Ellison—because Senator Newman has not stayed to defend herself—what we can say to the families of Australia about what you say you are doing for them. Senator Newman got up in this place and talked about the benefits to Australian women this International Women's Day of having the coalition in government. This is a government that has removed equal pay for women from the Industrial Relations Act. This is a government that has removed award protection for part-time workers. Mr Howard was talking in the other place about flexibility. Yes, women have flexibility: they no longer have protection; they no longer have the same kind of assurance that they had before; they no longer have a commitment to equal pay. They are now going to be casual, part-time and underpaid.

If women do get a job, they will have to pay much more for their child care. Whether it is private child care or community based child care, increased fees of up to $20 or $25 a week are coming into existence. How can you say to the families of Australia that they are better off paying $25 a week for child‐care costs when they only get $4 a week from their tax payment? Families do not take too long to work out the benefit of that sum. It is not a benefit; it is a big loss for them.

The ABS figures that show people cannot find jobs because of child care should be of great concern. Instead, by way of an answer, we have a minister who says, `You did not do anything in child care.' That is rubbish. We dramatically increased child‐care services. To give Senator Patterson her due, she has often said that.

We took the child‐care investment from $68 million when we came into office to $1 billion when we left—12 months ago. You have broken your promises and your commitment to child care, and Australian families are just beginning to feel the pain. Add to that what many families will have to pay for increases in Medicare, for dental services for which they previously did not have to pay and for increased costs for pharmaceuticals. All of those things will make families already reporting that they do not feel secure and comfortable increasing anxious about living in this country with the government that we now have.

In the next little while families will be much less comfortable than they are now, Senator Ellison. They will be feeling that because you are introducing policies which are not family friendly and which, as we approach International Women's Day, are certainly not kind to women. They are insulting to women because you are presuming that women cannot do the sums. They can, and they do not add up for Australian families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it amazing that Senator Crowley gets up and goes on about changes that we have made to the health system when the one that we inherited from Labor was in an absolutely appalling state. One example of an initiative that has been undertaken by the government is in the area of vaccination. Senator Crowley failed to say today that about 53 per cent of Australian children are vaccinated. There are children in Australia dying of preventable diseases. It was a record that compared appallingly with most other Western countries. It was something that the Labor Party when in government could have done something about. They stood by and did nothing.
—We did. The vaccination program was started two years before you came to office.
—Mr Deputy President, Senator Neal could have a chance to get up and speak later but she feels that she has to interrupt me because I have touched a raw nerve.

SPEECH.PARA: Fifty‐three per cent of children were vaccinated. We have children dying of preventable diseases. Dr Wooldridge has introduced a policy which has been accepted by a wide range of people in the community. It enables people who have a conscientious objection to having their children vaccinated—once they know and understand the ramifications of not having their children vaccinated, which includes a risk to their own children and the possibility of their children passing on a disease to other children—to choose not to have them vaccinated and not be penalised. It is a very smart carrot and stick approach to encourage people to have their children vaccinated.

When the hard decisions were required, where were the Labor Party? They were nowhere to be seen; nothing happened. Why were the hard decisions not taken when we saw the private health insurance system bleeding? Senator Crowley said today that Mr Howard did not tell people that we were going to give money to the private health system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you miss the parliamentary secretary saying that spending $1.7 billion would not make any difference; that it would only maintain the level of 32 per cent?

—I thought I had the floor, Mr Deputy President, but Senator Neal seems to think she has it. She is shouting almost as loudly as Senator West was yesterday. Maybe now she is a little deaf after having Senator West shout in her ear yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crowley said that Mr Howard did not tell the Australian public that we were going to give money to private health. It was very clearly stated in our policy that we would be assisting families to take out private health insurance. Mr Beazley got it absolutely wrong when he said that we were targeting the wealthy at the expense of the poor. Dr Wooldridge said that, if the Leader of the Opposition had bothered to read our policies let alone his own, he would see that this is not the case. Our incentives will be available to single people on incomes of $35,000 and to couples and families on incomes of up to 70,000. Those opposite do not even know what they are talking about. Mr Beazley got it wrong: we are not taking money to pay wealthy people.

The other thing that I want to say is that people are voting with their feet. The health system was left in such disarray by the former Labor government that people are actually going to private hospitals and paying. There was a report yesterday on the radio about people having operations: about 70 per cent of cataract operations and minor knee surgery is now being undertaken in private hospitals by people who are actually paying for themselves to have the operations done. People are saying that they have to wait so long for this elective surgery because the system was left in such disarray that they are now choosing either to pay for themselves or to go through health insurance. Many of these people cannot afford to do this.

The other thing that Senator Crowley did not talk about was the fact that the pharmaceutical benefits scheme was growing at something like 17 per cent per annum, which is something like $2.3 billion. This was not sustainable. We could not continue to have the pharmaceutical benefits scheme exploding at that rate. It was unsustainable. But no, Labor did not take the hard decisions. They left it and kept borrowing. They sold the Commonwealth Bank and used that money; they sold Qantas and used that money. Borrow, borrow, borrow. The Australian people realised that we had to take account, that we had to be responsible. We are doing that, and we are doing that in the health system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak on the issue of child care. What we have heard today from Senator Patterson, Senator Ellison and others is really quite astounding in its hypocrisy. Only last year, prior to the budget, we heard Senator Newman say, `This is all just scaremongering. You are concerning the parents of Australia on child care. You will have to wait until the budget to see exactly what our position is.' Well, Senator Newman, we waited and we saw exactly what this government's position was on child care. You cut half a billion dollars out of it and families right around Australia are paying the price for those cuts right now. Child care has increased by $20 to $25 per child. You have implemented a whole raft of measures that have made child care more inaccessible and more unaffordable for parents, whether it is in community day care centres or in association with family day care, with some of the cuts and restrictions to child‐care assistance relating to hours and the number of children, and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: So you can expect us to stand over here and understand why we are asking exactly the same questions, when it is quite clear, from the documents that we have spoken of this afternoon, that this government intends to cut another $400 million out of that child‐care budget—nearly the same amount as last year. We are going to see nearly a mirroring effect of those restrictions on access and affordability of child care. We are going to see it all over again. It causes me—and all of us on this side of the chamber—to speculate as to where you are going to find these cuts.

Last year you left family day care alone in terms of the operational subsidy. Is that going to be the government's target this time around? You engineered the strategy and we heard the plaintive cry from Senator Newman and others, `You are scaremongering; you are scaremongering.' Well, family day care managed to hang on to its operational subsidy last year. Is this government prepared to come in here and say once again that family day care operational subsidy is going to be preserved? We have a very real fear that it is not. Our fears are justified by the fact that the words that we heard prior to last year's budget are exactly the same words that we are hearing now in the lead‐up to this year's budget.

You will have to excuse our cynicism on the Labor side of politics. We understand and we know how necessary it is for women and families to have access to child care. It is not just a family welfare issue or an entitlements issue. It is about jobs, and it is about access to the work force that women in particular have. What happens if women cannot feel secure about their child‐care arrangements and cannot afford to put their children in care? My nature, as a parent, suggests that I do not have any other option. I would stay at home to look after my children, and not go back into the work force.

What you are doing is manipulating the situation that working parents are facing by making it tough for them. You are forcing them to take on hard decisions such as: can I afford to work; is it worth the psychological hassle of going to work if I cannot provide the sort of child care that I want to provide for my children?

The policies that have come forth to date from this government have reinforced this view and it is with the most bitter irony that this paper has exposed this government's policy at a time so close to International Women's Day. This government has no record to speak of when it comes to women entering the work force or having accessible and affordable child care. There is no record there. There is no claim. And it disturbs me greatly to hear Senator Newman stand up so boldly and so blatantly and say that the coalition has actually done something for working families in this area. It is not true. The proof of the pudding was in last year's budget, and I am gravely concerned that this will only be reinforced in the coming budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —It is difficult to believe that the opposition actually believe that there is any community support out there for their attack on health care initiatives and on child care. What the community really wants is leadership, and that is what it has got with a range of reforms on both health and choice in child care. Today, I asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) a question about the incredible success of Australia's firearm law reforms and buyback scheme, and that is really just another example of peace of mind for Australians and health and safety in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Gun control and the push for gun control was a response to the tragedy in Port Arthur and, to give the opposition credit, there was multipartisan support that assisted the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to take a lead in this very important matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, is this on the same matter or is this on the question to Senator Vanstone?

—I am just coming to that. It is a pointer to what the Australian public likes about John Howard, and that is all about leadership. There can be no doubt that the gun reform and gun control has made all Australians feel a little safer, a little more confident in their communities and healthier in the outcomes that they are now able to point to that the government has delivered. You only have to look at what reforms have taken place so far. For instance, just look at the pharmaceutical benefits services—

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. My concerns may have been allayed. I was concerned that the senator did appear to be delivering the wrong speech in terms of the preoccupation with gun control when the debate is about child care.

—The pharmaceutical benefits service shows, firstly, that outlays grew from $2.433 billion in the 1995-96 budget to $2.637 billion in the 1996-97 budget, so it is still increasing. It is simply nonsense to suggest that there have been cuts in the pharmaceutical benefits service.

BREAK.PARA: If you look across the initiatives and benefits in health reform you find, for instance, that the government has corporatised and is corporatising the Australian Government Health Service to make it more efficient. The government has pledged—it is very difficult not to say that this has been said ad nauseam, but apparently it is necessary to keep on saying it, Senator Ellison—to retain Medicare. It is difficult to know why there are so many doubts about this on the other side. The community has accepted that Medicare is being retained. I think I have to say it again: it will be kept.

The important thing about health strategy is that the government has actually looked at the real health needs across Australia. The previous government did absolutely nothing substantial about the appalling needs of health in rural Australia. At least this government has looked at the appalling lack of medical services in rural regions. It has looked at the fact that no doctors seem to want to go there. Few doctors who graduate want to do the hard yards out there in the bush—out there where the problems are great and where people have little ability to access proper health care. The rural doctors strategy will at least try to ensure that people in the bush get access to proper health care.

The other matter of great significance that has arisen is that the appalling lack of immunity amongst Australian children is actually being attacked in a way that will minimise the number of children who are not immunised against preventable diseases that cause huge outbreaks and problems in a population that is not immunised. This is being done in a way that encourages parents to see the great value of vaccinating their children. There is absolutely nothing forced about this; it is still voluntary. The great good sense of having children immunised ought to be clear to all concerned.

Senator Lundy spoke about child care. There is absolutely no doubt that the whole of the health care initiatives have been directed to delivering to families a tax initiative that will enable them to actually take out private health insurance. You do not have to be a genius to realise that with community rating, which this government supports, you cannot have everybody getting health care without some people making a contribution if you want to keep Medicare.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Outcome of the Board of Inquiry into the Black Hawk Training Accident

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Minister for Defence on the outcome of the Board of Inquiry into the Black Hawk training accident of 12 June 1996, to incorporate the statement in Hansard , and to move a motion to take note of the statement and a related document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable Senators will recall the sadness and dismay with which the nation heard the news of the accident at the High Range Training Area near Townsville shortly after dusk on 12 June 1996.
The accident occurred during an exercise to practise the recovery of Australian citizens held hostage by armed terrorists.
Six Black Hawk helicopters and 24 aircrew from the 5th Aviation Regiment and 43 soldiers of the Special Air Service were conducting a live-fire airmobile assault on a simulated terrorist position.

As the formation reached the target zone, two helicopters collided. The lead helicopter crashed to the ground upside down and was consumed by fire. The second helicopter entered a flat spin before crash landing in an upright position. It too was destroyed by fire.
Eighteen Australian servicemen perished and a further 12 were injured—some critically. Equipment worth $37 million was destroyed.

There were heroic acts in the face of this terrible accident. The reaction at the crash scene was cool headed, courageous and swift. Despite the confusion of the collision and the crash and the danger of flames and exploding ammunition, those at the scene acted quickly and decisively to evacuate the injured.
I am advised that the Army will be proposing a number of awards to recognise brave and conspicuous service in the immediate aftermath of the accident.
The professional response of local ADF units, the Queensland Emergency Service, the Queensland Police and staff at Townsville General Hospital undoubtedly saved further lives.

The Defence Department acted swiftly to ensure that the injured survivors and the families of those who lost their lives were paid such compensation and provided with as much ancillary support as existing legislation allowed. This was done as quickly as was possible.

I know from letters which have been sent to me that the sensitive assistance of family support bodies and the overwhelming support of the Australian community were of great comfort to the families of the victims, to their comrades and to those close to them.
This was the largest peacetime disaster to strike our armed forces since the Voyager collision of 1964.

Nevertheless, the training activities which so unfortunately culminated in this accident are essential to our national security. This is particularly true with just three years remaining before the Sydney Olympic Games.

Training for counter terrorism operations is inherently dangerous. It takes our forces to the cutting edge of capability. It demands degrees of speed, stealth, precision, accuracy and lethality beyond those required of any other element of the Army.

But such training also demands a careful balance between safety and realism. This can only be achieved through meticulous military preparation and planning and the execution of a staged progres sion of training which reflects the difficulty and danger of the task to be achieved.
This need to balance safety and realism is at the heart of the report which I will table today.

Following the accident, the Chief of Army, Lieutenant General John Sanderson appointed a military Board of Inquiry. The Board was required to establish the primary and contributory causes of the accident and to make recommendations to prevent another tragedy.

While it was also to make recommendations in relation to possible disciplinary action, the Board was not constituted as a court and had no powers or authority to make findings in relation to offences under the Defence Force Discipline Act.

With the exception of matters concerning national security, the Inquiry was open to the public. The survivors and the next of kin and families of those who lost their lives were provided Commonwealth funding to attend the hearings and received legal representation as required.

The Board of Inquiry was extensive and thorough. It conducted hearings in Perth, Townsville and Sydney over a period of three months. It took evidence from 144 witnesses, accepted 215 written exhibits and considered numerous instructions, correspondence and statements.
The Board's Report, which was submitted to the Chief of Army on 20 December last year, reflects this thoroughness. It comprises more than seven thousand pages in seventeen volumes.
Since submission to the Chief of Army, the Board's finding and recommendations have been studied in detail by technical and legal experts within the Army and the Department of Defence.
These experts have confirmed the adequacy of the Board's Report and advised on corrective action to minimise the probability of further accidents.
These recommendations form the basis of the Chief of Army's Report which was submitted to me last week.

In his report, General Sanderson addresses the findings of the Board of Inquiry, the advice of the panel of experts and, most importantly, the steps to be taken to reduce the risk of further accidents.

The Board found that the immediate cause of the accident was that the lead helicopter, Black 1, turned right and converged on an adjacent helicopter, Black 2. As a result, Black 1 struck Black 2 with multiple rotor blade strikes causing both aircraft to crash and be destroyed by fire.
But, as is almost always the case with accidents of this nature, the events immediately preceding the accident do not stand in isolation.

The Board found that while there was no single reason for the tragedy, there was a chain of events that successively and cumulatively led to a situation where the accident became what the Board describes as the inevitable outcome.

During the early stages of the Board's proceedings, there was a good deal of speculation about the causes of the crash. At that time and until today, the Government took the position that it would not comment on matters before the Board.
The findings of the Board clearly dismiss some of the more widely speculated causes.
It found:
. There were no mechanical defects in the Black Hawk helicopters involved. In fact the aircraft's design unquestionably prevented a greater death toll;
. The accident was not caused by unserviceable night vision goggles; and
. No shots were fired in or at any aircraft which were causal to the accident, nor was there any ordnance explosion prior to the collision.
The Board identified 16 directly causative and a further 26 contributing factors. It found a linkage between these factors, although it did not place a separate weighting on each of them.
The Board found a number of long term systemic factors which contributed to the accident.
Among them:
. The Black Hawk aircraft had a high rate of unserviceability in the two years leading up to the accident.
. High pilot separation rates over a similar period had further eroded the bank of experience at the 5th Aviation Regiment.
These factors clearly affected the experience levels among Black Hawk crews and prevented them from gaining sufficient flying experience for special counter terrorism operations.
More immediate factors arose from the planning, preparation, rehearsal and conduct of the exercise.
Among these:
. The planning for the air mission on the night of the accident was found by the Board to be inadequate.
. There was inadequate information about the objective.
. There was a failure on the part of aircrew adequately to resolve conflicting understanding of the location of specific targets.
. The conduct of the night mission differed from that of the day mission and there was no rehearsal of those changes.
. The Flight Lead in Black 1 lacked experience in leading special recovery missions.

On their own, none of these factors directly caused the accident. But the Board found that as a train of events, they, in addition to other causes, cumulatively contributed to a situation where the accident became inevitable.

The function of the Board was not merely to determine the cause of the crash, but also to identify areas for remedial action to reduce the risk of further accidents. This aspect is of the greatest importance.

The Board made 79 recommendations, many of which require the Australian Defence Force to implement and adhere to best practice procedures. These recommendations will help ensure a safer environment and assist in preventing a recurrence of the circumstances which led to this accident.

At the time of the accident, I made clear our determination that all possible measures were to be taken to ameliorate risk without compromising capability. Accordingly, the Chief of Army has developed a plan to implement the Board's recommendations.
The plan addresses systemic and equipment issues, and proposes measures to improve command, control and exercise planning as well as changes to training.

To stem separation rates, the Army is reviewing the employment and conditions of service of its aircrew. Measures so far taken include the introduction of a Pilot Retention Bonus, increasing return of service obligations and increasing the numbers of trainee Army pilots.
In addition, the Army is ensuring that qualified flying instructors can be better employed in operational units by contracting out some of the less demanding pilot instruction.
Action has been taken to place all counter terrorism and special recovery elements within the same command structure, with all outcomes now being the responsibility of the Land Commander.

The Army is reviewing the training requirements for counter terrorism and special recovery operations. This will establish a training sequence to overcome the erosion of combined skills which had previously occurred between biennial special recovery exercises.

New directives will be issued to ensure that the command and control, planning, intelligence gathering, orders and briefings, conduct of missions and training requirements which were recommended by the Board are specified for future Special Forces operations.
The acquisition of proximity warning devices, improved night vision goggles and redesigned fast roping and rappelling devices is being evaluated.
Crash data recorders will be fitted to all Army aircraft as a matter of priority and to Black Hawk helicopters as a matter of urgency.

I have directed the Chief of Army, as the responsible commander, to provide me with monthly reports on the progress of the implementation plan and on the status and safety of counter terrorism training.
In addition, I have asked the Chief of the Defence Force, General John Baker, to establish an overarching Defence Force Flying Safety Authority, under the Chief of Air Force.
This authority will be responsible for the supervision of all flying safety issues for the Defence Force, regardless of the Service operating individual types of aircraft.
I turn now to the issue of whether disciplinary action is to be taken against any individual.

In accordance with its Terms of Reference, the Board recommended that disciplinary action be considered against five members in relation to negligence, deficiencies in the exercise of command and errors of judgement.
The Chief of Army has considered these recommendations and has taken advice from the Army's Legal Branch.

As a result of advice to him, the Chief of Army has referred the Board's Report and the legal advice to the Land Commander Australia, whom he has appointed as a Convening Authority, to consider whether or not to prefer charges under the Defence Force Discipline Act against three persons.
In addition, the Chief of Army has decided to take administrative action against two other personnel.

Until the matters of military discipline are properly determined by the Convening Authority, it would be quite inappropriate to disclose the names or appointments of any persons facing administrative action or referred to the Convening Authority, or to disclose details of offences which might be pursued against individuals.
For this reason, some of the findings and recommendations which could lead to possible disciplinary action have been expunged from the Report which I will table today.
It is the responsibility of the Convening Authority to decide whether military charges are to be laid. I expect the Chief of Army to announce the decision of the Convening Authority within a month.

I can inform the House, however, that as a result of requests for advice by the Department, separate advice has been received from the Queensland and Commonwealth Directors of Public Prosecutions that, based on the Board's Report, no criminal charges would arise from the accident.
Madam President, for some time the Government has been considering the issue of the adequacy of the compensation and rehabilitation benefits available to members of the ADF.

Military service is distinctly different from civilian employment. It often involves considerably more dangerous activities which may result in severe injury or death. It therefore warrants distinct rehabilitation and compensation arrangements.

The need for a review of military compensation was brought into sharper focus by the Black Hawk accident. In particular, it has become quite clear that parts of the existing peacetime compensation and rehabilitation scheme for ADF personnel are inappropriate.
Consequently, the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel ordered a review of existing rehabilitation and compensation arrangements for military personnel.

The review was to investigate compensation arrangements for military personnel including the adequacy of the lump sum payments, ancillary benefits and supporting services for dependants of deceased personnel.

It was to also examine the different entitlements that accrue to members of the ADF for death or severe injury suffered during peacetime service under the Veterans' Entitlements Act or the Military Compensation Scheme as well as the administrative arrangements involved when members are covered by both schemes.
This review is to report to Mrs Bishop very shortly and will be subject to consideration by Cabinet.

Nothing we can do will fully compensate for the loss of those 18 Australian servicemen. All of us have been affected by this tragedy. But I hope some consolation can be found in the knowledge that those who perished did so in the service of their country.

The Australian Defence Force has set in train sound, logical and decisive steps to ensure that counter terrorism and special recovery operations can be conducted for the protection of all Australians.

The training and preparation of our counter terrorism forces will continue to be as demanding and realistic as is safely possible. We must maintain our cutting edge capability in counter terrorism operations.
Those lost in this terrible accident would have expected nothing less of us.
Madam President, I present a copy of my Ministerial Statement and a copy of a Report by the Chief of Army on a Training Accident at High Range Training Area, Townsville on 12 June 1996.
