PARA.EMPHASIS: The speeches read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1996-97

In Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1996‐97, appropriations totalling $363,000 additional to those made in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act 1996‐97 are sought for recurrent expenditures of the Parliamentary Departments.

The increases sought relate primarily to an increase in the `Provision for Running Costs Borrowings' for each of the Departments of the Senate and the House of Representatives from $50,000 to $200,000 to enhance their access to the borrowing arrangements under the running cost rules. In addition, the appropriations for the citizenship visits program for both the Senate and the House of Representatives have been supplemented by slightly more than 5 per cent over the provision made when the Budget was prepared.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1996-97

Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1996‐97, together with Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), which I shall introduce shortly, comprise the Additional Estimates for 1996‐97.

In these bills, Parliament is asked to appropriate moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures additional to the appropriations made for 1996‐97 under Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1 and 2) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act.

The additional appropriations in these three bills total some $1,402 million; $930 million is sought in Appropriation Bill (No. 3), $471 million in Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and less than half a million dollars in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2).

These amounts are partly offset by savings in the appropriations made by Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1 and 2) 1996‐97. Reflecting the Government's determination to improve the efficiency of continuing programs, these savings, amounting to $343 million in gross terms, are detailed under the relevant appropriation headings in the document "Statement of Savings Expected in Annual Appropriations", which has been distributed to Honourable Members.

After allowing for prospective savings, the total appropriations sought represent a net increase of $1,059 million in appropriations for 1996‐97, an increase of about three per cent on the amounts made available through the annual appropriations at the time of the 1996‐97 Budget.
I turn now to the main areas for which the Government seeks additional provisions in the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1996‐97 to meet payments for the ordinary annual services of the Government.

Running costs appropriations provide for the recurrent and minor capital costs of agencies in providing Government services. The total supplementation for running costs for all departments and agencies (including Defence military and civilian personnel) of $111 million represents an increase of less than one per cent on the funding for running costs included in Appropriation Act (No. 1).
A principal factors contributing to this increase are:
borrowings against the forward estimates and some additional funding for departments associated with workload changes provided for under the running costs arrangements; and
a change in the funding arrangements for the Australian Customs Service as a result of the decision to implement some trade related charges through taxation legislation rather than user charging.
Gross additional estimates of some $93 million are sought for the Defence Portfolio in Appropriation Bill (No. 3). This figure includes:
$29 million for compensation and legal expenses which comprises:
$17 million for compensation associated with the Cockatoo Island Dockyard; and
$12 million for a range of other claims;

$40 million for Equipment and Stores largely related to increased purchases of fuel for joint exercises with the United States. This increase will be offset by recoveries of costs from the United States; and
$10 million for Facilities Operations reflecting an increased provision for repairs and maintenance and minor new works activities.
The increases have been partly offset by reductions elsewhere in the Defence annual appropriations, giving a net increase of some $76 million.
In addition, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) includes provision for:

$42 million for medical services for veterans reflecting an increased demand for those services together with the clearance of a claims backlogs associated with the transfer of claims processing to the Health Insurance Commission in December 1995;
$12 million for pharmaceutical services for veterans attributable to a delay in the introduction of a two (from four) card treatment entitlement system;
$14 million for increased lump sum and pension payments for former State railways employees;

$39 million for capital assistance for residential facilities for older people reflecting an acceleration in building activity in this area and the Commonwealth's obligation to make progressive payments as projects are developed;
$27 million additional funding for the Health Insurance Commission largely reflecting:
increased funding for the Double Dipping Initiative; and

higher administrative costs associated with changes to the Child Care Cash Rebate payments to higher income families as a result of the decision to reduce the rebate payments for families above the Family Tax Initiative income cutoff; and

$510m associated with the assumption of the debt of the Australian National Railways Commission preparatory to its sale. This payment to the Australian National Railways Commission. is classified as an advance and it will be offset by an equivalent receipt by the Commonwealth in 1996‐97 of a debt repayment from the Australian National Railways Commission. There will therefore be no impact on either the headline or underlying deficit as a result of these transactions.
The balance of some $84 million in the amount included in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) is made up of minor variations across a range of programs in most departments and agencies.
These additional appropriations are required to meet undertakings made by the Government since the Budget, as well as economic parameter changes since the Budget was prepared.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1996-97

In Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1996‐97, appropriations totalling $471 million—additional to those made by Appropriation Act (No. 2) 1996‐97—are sought for capital works and services; payments to or for the States, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory; advances and loans; and for other services. The proposed appropriations are required to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures for which provision was not made in the Budget appropriation measures.

The additions are necessitated by certain cost and price increases which have occurred since the Budget, together with other commitments that have been made by the Government. Areas where significant increases are sought over amounts provided in Appropriation Act (No. 2) 1996‐97 include:

provision of $49,776 included in a specific appropriation entitled "Legal costs incurred by, or on account of acting for, Dr Carmen Lawrence for or in relation to the Marks Inquiry". The amount included in the additional estimates has been assessed as fair and reasonable by the Australian Government Solicitor;
$12 million for payment to the States and Territories for the supported accommodation assistance program to fund the movement in award wages and superannuation guarantee charges;

$30 million for a package of alternative assistance to Howe Leather following the agreement reached with the United States to remove automotive leather from eligibility under the TCF Import Credit Scheme and the PMV Export Facilitation Scheme; and
$347 million attributable to the costs associated with the sale of Australian National comprising
$7.0 million for the Australian National Railways Commission for the payment of interest bearing advances;
$347.0 million to the Australian National Railways Commission to meet the costs of restructuring; and

$10.0 million for regional assistance to ameliorate the impact of the Australian National Railways Commission restructuring payment to the Northern Territory for the provision of water and sewerage facilities for indigenous communities.
The remaining $82 million included in Appropriation Bill (No. 4) comprises minor increases in a number of programs across a range of portfolios.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Robert Ray, I move:

BREAK.PARA: That the Senate congratulates the Premier of Queensland, Mr Borbidge, for his quintessential summary of the political philosophy of the National Party of Australia into 12 words: `there are some little tricks that can be played around the edges'.

This comment of the Premier of Queensland, Mr Borbidge, is to do with his now infamous statement that, if there was a casual vacancy created in the Senate by the resignation of the Deputy President, Senator Colston, he would not stick to the spirit of the constitution of Australia and appoint a Labor senator to fill the vacancy.

His quite infamous remarks have been criticised and condemned across most sections of Australian politics. Even in Queensland the Liberal coalition partners led by Mrs Sheldon have refused to confirm that they would be party to such a breach of the constitution. Mr Howard has made it clear that he believes that if a vacancy was caused by the resignation of the Deputy President, Senator Colston, the person filling that vacancy, in accordance with the amendment of the constitution of 1977 as well as in accordance with the spirit of it, would be from the Labor Party.

Every editorial in Australia written on this issue and every commentator who has talked about this issue since Mr Borbidge made those infamous remarks last weekend have strongly criticised him and pointed out in various tough words that he is either a constitutional vandal or just a dill or a dope.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or all three.
—Or all three. He may have got the lot. You are right, Senator Mackay.
—Order! I think there might be a standing order preventing such language being used. So just be careful about how you refer to the Premier of Queensland.

—I was referring to the premier of another state. I accept, Mr Deputy President, your advice and I will be cautious about my remarks. But, as you would be fully aware, there has been almost universal condemnation of the views of the Premier of Queensland on this matter. That has led Senator Ray, on behalf of the opposition, to put this motion on the Notice Paper and for us to seek to debate it today.

BREAK.PARA: The National Party—and its predecessor, the Country Party—has a long history of ripping up conventions and twisting the rules whenever it wants to get a political advantage. That has been the case over its history, since it was formed in the early 1920s in Australia.

When you look at the history of this party and its role in Australian politics, you see that other people have made comments about it that sum it up. Billy Hughes, a former Prime Minister, during his 50 years in the federal parliament, from 1901 to 1951, had been a representative of the Labor Party; the Conservative Party, called the National Party in the 1920s, which has no connection to the present National Party; the United Australia Party; and the Liberal Party. That is four parties.

When he was near his retirement, he was asked, `Billy, you've been in every party in Australian history except the Country Party. Why didn't you join the Country Party?' His very famous retort was, `You've got to draw the line somewhere.' Billy Hughes had been in every other political party—the Liberal Party, the Labor Party, the National Party and the United Australia Party. That sums up his view of the old‐style Country Party, now the National Party.

Another very famous remark about the role of the National Party, the then Country Party, in Australia was in 1974, when there was a suggestion floated that the then DLP in its decline may merge with the Country Party to form a new third party. Mr Snedden, the then Leader of the Opposition, was quoted as saying, `Who's churching the old whore now?' He was clearly referring to the description of the church in relation to the history of the DLP and its strong support from sections of the Roman Catholic Church. That leaves no-one in any misunderstanding that the party he was calling `the old whore' was in fact his then coalition partner, the Country Party, which subsequently became the National Party.

So this party has a dreadful history of being opportunistic and of walking around like a bunch of old boys with a gladstone bag full of money to hand out to its supporters, its friends, and to bribe people. That has been the style of that party. Of course it came to its apogee in the period of the National Party government of Queensland under Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen from the late 1960s to when it was finally chucked out in 1989.

In fact I think in Western politics the only analogy to the performance of the National Party in Queensland and that period is probably the Hughie Long democrat party in Louisiana. Certainly Joh Bjelke-Petersen in every way fitted the populism of Hughie Long in the 1920s and 1930s. Hughie Long was assassinated. He was replaced some years later by another `Long'—Earl Long—as governor of Louisiana. I think Earl Long probably is more on a parallel with the performance of Mr Borbidge today.

Earl Long of course recently got some late fame when Paul Newman made a film called Blaze, which is the story of Earl Long as governor of Louisiana falling in love with a stripper and being tried to be committed to an insane asylum while he was governor. I think the performance of Mr Borbidge last weekend, trying to rip up the constitution of Australia, is the equivalent of Earl Long ending up in an insane asylum by falling in love with a stripper. That is the level of this party and Mr Borbidge in Queensland.

It will be interesting to see how well some of the Liberal Party members from Queensland will want to defend Mr Borbidge, if they are game to. Their own Liberal leader in Queensland, Mrs Sheldon, has not supported Mr Borbidge on this issue of trying to rort a vacancy if it were caused by the resignation of Senator Colston. I point out that Mr Borbidge has just ignored Mrs Sheldon's lack of support and has gone on with his business of saying, `We're going to look at every trick in the book,' as the motion says, `to try to rort the constitution.'

It has been an absolutely astonishing performance. As I said before, he is either a constitutional vandal or just stupid in not understanding what is in the constitution. The constitution was amended in 1977. That amendment was overwhelmingly carried, as I understand it, by every state and was sup ported by all the major political parties. Section 15 of the constitution says:

Where a vacancy at any time occurred in the place of a senator chosen by the people of the state and at the time he was so chosen he was publicly recognised by a particular political party as being an endorsed candidate of that party and publicly represented himself to be such a candidate, a person chosen or appointed under this section in consequence of that vacancy or in consequence of that vacancy and a subsequent vacancy or vacancies shall, unless there is no member of that party available to be chosen or appointed, be a member of that party.

You do not have to be a lawyer to understand that section of the constitution. That amendment was overwhelmingly voted for by the people of Australia in 1977, after the disgraceful performance of Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen and the National Party in Queensland in 1975 when they did not follow the 75-year convention in Australia that a senator, for whatever reason they have left the Senate, should be replaced by a senator of the same political party. Senator Colston, you were an absolute victim of that process of ripping up the convention by Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen in 1975.

It is interesting that by 1977 even the Fraser government—the beneficiary of that vacancy being created and not being filled by the Labor appointee, Senator Colston—was willing to put this in the constitution to make it clear that it could never happen again. There was another attempt to get around this constitutional requirement in 1987 when the Groom Liberal government of Tasmania refused to appoint a replacement for Senator Don Grimes when he retired. Senator Devereux subsequently became a senator. Senator Devereux was nominated by the Labor Party and refused to be appointed—

TALK.START.PARA: —Get your facts right—Robin Gray.
—Robin Gray, you mean?
—By Robin Gray, sorry. I am sure Senator Calvert would not want to be lumped in with Mr Gray's faction of the Liberal Party, so I understand his agitation.

BREAK.PARA: On that occasion the Liberal Party in this Senate gave a permanent pair so that there would be no advantage accidentally given to the Liberal Party in this Senate while Robin Gray refused to fill the vacancy. Senator Colston issued a very strong statement on 10 May 1987 pointing out that, if necessary, there should be a further referendum to stop people like Robin Gray trying to circumvent the constitutional amendment of 1977. Mr Deputy President with the Senate's approval, I seek leave to table the statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear what Senator Schacht was wanting to table. Whatever it is, I have not seen it.
—I want to table a press statement by Senator Colston issued in 1987 criticising Robin Gray for not taking arrangements to fill a Labor vacancy at that time.
—Leave is not granted. It is a bit of paper with some typing on it. I do not know what this is and what it is supposed to be. I do not give leave.

—Mr Deputy President, it is your press statement that the Liberal Party is now traducing and saying it is not worth the paper it is written on. We note that they are doing that to your press statement.
—I don't take your word on what it is.
—If you read it properly, you would see that it is clearly Senator Colston's statement.

BREAK.PARA: I also want to point out that, since the infamous words of Mr Borbidge last Sunday when he was told he could not break the constitution, he is now suggesting that, if there is a casual vacancy caused by your resignation, Senator Colston, he would leave it vacant for a while. He would not necessarily be forced to fill it. Yesterday, Mr Terry Mackenroth, the Acting Opposition Leader in Queensland, pointed out that, under standing order No. 331 of the Queensland parliament, they have just two weeks to vote on a nominee for a casual Senate vacancy from the time the parliament is notified of it.

Mr Borbidge is even breaking up his own rule book, the standing orders of the parliament of which he is Premier. If a vacancy occurs, he is trying not only to subvert the constitution of Australia, which is illegal, but to subvert the standing orders of his own parliament. This man goes to no ends and that is why it is most appropriate that Senator Ray moved a motion relating to those 12 words—`There are some little tricks that can be played around the edges'. If he is going to play around the edges, he is giving an example that he wants to break the rule book everywhere—not just convention but the full rule book.

It is quite clear. Section 15 of the constitution is explicit. The standing orders of the Queensland parliament are quite clear. If by some chance you resign, Mr Deputy President, your vacancy should and must be filled by a Labor nominee.

The next thing I want to point out about Mr Borbidge is that there has been some press speculation over the last two or three weeks up until last weekend that you, Senator Colston, may resign from the Senate. However, this was raised by Mr Borbidge, not by us. It was raised openly by him. He is actually suggesting that it is an open and shut case that you, Sir, will have to resign from the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does he know?

—Does he know anything that we do not know. He has raised the issue as the National Party Premier of Queensland. That is the thing that ought to be noted, not that we raised it, in the way that he did.

BREAK.PARA: We have put questions on the Notice Paper, Mr Deputy President, that you are aware of. We have asked questions in estimates committees quite appropriately. He went for the king hit. Basically, I think he is starting to agree that you may have to resign or you would resign. I do not know what he knows. But, if it happens, he says the Labor Party cannot fill the vacancy. It is a disgraceful performance by Mr Borbidge. It is in line with the good old boys in the 70-year history of the Country Party-National Party in this country.

From preparing my remarks for today, I have to say that consistency has never been a great trait of the National Party in Australian politics. Senator Colston, when you resigned from the Labor Party, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen said on 22 August 1996 that he and Lady Flo had respected Senator Colston for a very long time. `He was a very good citizen. I respect Mr Colston very much. He has played a very quiet but very important supportive role over the years,' Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen said. `He has completely won my confidence.'

However, way back when Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen was Premier on the 7 October 1976 and when Senator Colston raised a matter in the parliament about the share dealings of company structures in Queensland that could affect the then Premier Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, Mr Bjelke-Petersen said, `Senator Colston had literally picked up his information out of the gutter by quoting from an anonymous pamphlet circulating in Brisbane.'

So we see Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, who stopped your appointment in 1975 to this place, in 1996 saying what an outstanding citizen you are. That is not what he said against you in the Queensland parliament in regard to why you were not a suitable appointment.

The hypocrisy of the National Party in Queensland in this area is appalling. I think that ought to be noted. I do not want to go through all the quotes against Mr Borbidge that are in various newspapers, editorials and comments by people over the last four or five days. They are all well known and are now on the record.

It is disappointing that only two days ago the Liberal‐National coalition would not support a motion guaranteeing the convention of pairs in the event that Mr Borbidge somehow got his way to delay a replacement. That is very disappointing, and it is something we will remember and take to the Australian people on every occasion possible.

I believe that we have seen an extraordinary series of events. Mr Borbidge clearly is a National Party leader in the worst traditions of the white shoe brigade of Queensland—in the worst traditions of that group of support ers of the former Premier of Queensland Sir Joh Bjelke‐Petersen. I have used the nickname that they quite happily applied to themselves: the white shoe brigade. They got into every corrupt practice, destroyed good government in Queensland, ruptured everything to do with government tendering and convinced the Premier to pay money to his mates.

We finally had the royal commission in that state and got evidence of brown paper bags being delivered by the white shoe brigade to the Queensland Premier. Of course, he then was charged with perjury and to be convicted needed a unanimous decision of the then jury—a jury of which, it has now been exposed, one if not two members belonged to the National Party and, having not declared themselves, used their numbers. So the vote was 10 to two in favour of conviction of perjury against Joh Bjelke‐Petersen because he had lied to the royal commission. He got off on a 10 to two vote. In my state and a number of others, on 10 to two he would have been convicted and would have received, I hope, a major sentence.

This is the Premier who on evidence could not remember receiving brown paper bags with cash in them in the Premier's office. These were the good ole boys of the National Party/Country Party operating just as they have for 70 years, collecting money, dishing it out and being bribed to do certain deals for the favoured in their own political party. I would hope that the National Party members in this chamber do not defend that activity. No politician of any party should be able to get away with that. Sir Joh got away with it for 20‐odd years, until finally it got so rotten, so corrupt, in Queensland that his own party had to have a royal commission—and then it all spilt out. This is the party of the good ole boys, as I have described them.

When you go back in the history of the Country Party/National Party, that is the way they have always operated in Queensland—and not only in Queensland but in Australia. When they get half a chance, they will fiddle the system, corrupt the system and bring good government and the political system into disrepute. Fortunately, I think in the federal parliament the National Party is under some control. But give them unlimited control, as they had in Queensland, and they will just take the lot and distribute it amongst their favoured supporters.

It is quite appropriate that we debate Senator Robert Ray's motion here today on behalf of the opposition. It is a very simple motion of 12 words which, as he says, quintessentially sum up the political philosophy of the National Party of Australia, formerly the Country Party of Australia. We should remind the people of Australia from time to time that that is not good in the national interests. I will conclude on those words from Mr Borbidge: there are some little tricks that can be played around the edges. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —What an absolute and abject waste of time is this debate.
—You hate the National Party, Ian.

—You will be very interested in what I have to say, then. But what an absolute waste of time. Here we are, sitting extra hours, sitting an extra day to get through the business of the Senate, and we are wasting an hour to an hour and a half on this absolutely puerile debate which has gone absolutely nowhere. I think it really shows the sort of regard the Labor Party today have for this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that there was a big change overnight. Yesterday, Senator Ray was in full force. He was going to come in here and take Senator Colston to the cleaners, because that is what the Labor Party is all about—revenge and personal vilification. But Senator Ray quite sensibly saw the pasting, the absolute pasting, he got in the papers today, and he scuttled out backwards as fast as he could. And what have those opposite done? They have put in poor old fall guy Senator Schacht, getting down towards Z on their speakers list. That just demonstrates what the Labor Party think of this today.

Yesterday they were doing everything. They had all these scurrilous allegations in the form of questions on notice and notices of motion. They had all this sort of stuff, with a bit of mud here and a bit of mud there—it does not matter much, but just throw it around and try to put as much pressure on as you can.

The media have done what we and the rest of Australia, I might say, have done and seen it for just what it is. I cannot help but quote the first paragraph of Piers Akerman's excellent article in the Daily Telegraph. It says:
The rank stench of foul hypocrisy which normally blows from Canberra has billowed to new and historic levels.

The source of the bulk of this nauseating odour is not, however, the porcine form of Queensland Senator Mal Colston, no, the seat of this putrid pustulation is firmly located within the ranks of his former Labor colleagues.

Come on, Senator Carr. You get a bit of a mention here. There is a very good description of the shrill pitch of Senator Ray's henchman. But, Madam Acting Deputy President West, as you would well know, the Labor Party are:
out to wound, to gore and to maim through a shameful campaign of vilification that ignores the basic right of every person to be presumed innocent until proved guilty...
Where are your civil rights now?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you defending him?

—Come on, you are the great human rights man. Why are you prosecuting, determining as judge and executing anybody—it does not matter who it is—without a fair trial? Madam Acting Deputy President, as you well know, Senator Robert Ray is a man whom a lot of us used to have a lot of regard for, and I think a lot of the press did. But have a look now at what the press is saying. Senator Ray has done the right thing and scuttled out of this as quickly as he possibly could.

SPEECH.PARA: I sympathise with Senator Schacht. He was thrown into this at the last minute. He was leaving it to Senator Ray to come out with all the bile and vilification that we have seen from the Labor Party. Senator Schacht was thrown in at the last minute and ran this pathetically weak argument about an alleged breach of the constitution.

For a start, it is entirely a hypothetical matter. There is no vacancy from Queensland whatsoever. I certainly hope that ill health will not cause any vacancies. I suspect you would like ill health to do it, wouldn't you? You want to hound someone until you cause health problems for that person. Is that your style?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you seek some medical reports?

—It is your style, you are saying, Senator Carr. You want to damage someone's health to get them out of this place. I certainly hope that that does not happen and I hope that this question remains completely hypothetical. What Senator Schacht has been talking about is obviously a hypothetical question, which is not doing anything for this parliament, which is wasting the time of the parliament and causing the taxpayers to fund this parliament to sit more hours and extra days to do the serious business that we have to do.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Schacht, before he scuttled out of the chamber, made an allegation about me. He said, `Senator Macdonald, you are not one of these people who love the National Party. You don't like them.' I can tell you this: back in the bad old days, I was one of the ones that stood up to them, for historical reasons that are long since gone. So my record is clear about those years. Let me tell you this: the National Party that is in control in Queensland today is an excellent party and one that I support absolutely 100 per cent. I have the very highest regard for Mr Rob Borbidge. I think he will go down as one of Queensland's best premiers. He is certainly a very caring and compassionate person, a person who is particularly learned and intelligent and understanding and who understands what needs to be done. He leads a very good party in the National Party and he leads an excellent coalition of the Queensland National and Liberal parties.

I don't see any Queenslanders among you people over there. Where are all the Queensland senators? Where are they? I'm sorry, Senator Gibbs, but you are too nice to be here. It is tremendous to see the Borbidge‐Sheldon government in Queensland because for the first time in a very, very, very long time we have an honest, open and accountable government that is doing decent things, good things, for Queenslanders. It is a government that has got Queensland moving again after six years of Labor holding it back.

I might say in response to Senator Schacht earlier on that Mr Borbidge, when there was an allegation made about a poor deal between his police minister and the police union, was the first one to insist it go to the CJC. By way of historical result, the CJC has completely cleared Mr Cooper. But it was Mr Borbidge who insisted that it go there because that was the honest and decent thing to do. So I have the greatest respect for Mr Borbidge and for the job that he is doing in Queensland.

If you want to talk about rorts, what was this about the Labor Premier of Western Australia? He was offered $300,000 by Yosse Goldberg. He, a Labor Premier, sent it back and said he wanted $100,000 in cash. And you have the hypocrisy to talk about Mr Borbidge, an honest, god‐fearing, Christian man, when $100,000 was given—

TALK.START.PARA: —Three hundred thousand.

—Well, $300,000. But he sent the cheque back. He wanted $100,000 in nice, crisp green notes—and we know what that was for. I do not want to vilify a politician in any other chamber, but I might say that the Western Australian Supreme Court has indicated that that was a bribe; it was a pay‐off; it was daylight robbery. I think it even found it was robbing the Labor Party. You fools support him robbing your own party! And you have the hide and hypocrisy to come in here. What happened in Western Australia with the $100,000 worth of crisp green notes in cash is nothing new for the Labor Party. Their history is one litany of those sorts of things. I do not want to go back into history, but we can just go back to `Red Ted' Theodore. Remember `Red Ted' Theodore, the old Labor Premier of Queensland? He was prosecuted for getting a bit of the old stuff from mining back when he was Treasurer of the state. So it is nothing new for the Labor Party in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: It is pretty obvious what the Labor Party are on about. They want to vent their hatred, their rage, their venom and their spleen on this vile campaign that already has backfired on them. All of us knew it would happen. There are many decent Labor people over that side who have been mumbling amongst themselves. There is no need for you to look down, Madam Deputy President. I will not name you or anyone. There are a lot of decent people over there. You should look behind you now, Senator Carr, as you giggle away. There are a lot of people over there who just do not really like the venom that is coming out of the Labor Party. Certainly Kim Beazley does not like it.

I do not for a moment accept anything that is not proved, because I have some respect for people's civil rights. Obviously, you do not, Senator Carr. I do. If for one moment there were any truth in the allegations that Senator Ray has been making, then how hypocritical he would be, because all of the allegations relate to the time when Kim Beazley—Mr Beazley—was in charge. What did Mr Beazley do about it? What did Senator Ray do? He is still the boss of the Labor Party in spite of who sits down the front filling that seat temporarily. He was then a senior member. You have gone silent, Senator Carr. Don't you and Senator Ray get on? Oh, I see.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order, Senator Macdonald!
—I will talk about Senator Ray more. Perhaps you want me to up it a bit on Senator Ray because you want to use this to get into him.
—Order, Senator Macdonald and Senator Carr! I will have order on my left. Senator Macdonald, please address your remarks to the chair.

—Certainly, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator Ray was a senior member in the government at the time of all of these sorts of allegations—which I do not believe. They were flying around and splattered around everywhere. He says that they are true, yet he was in charge. He was there. He could have done something about them at the time, and he did absolutely nothing. What hypocrisy!

SPEECH.PARA: The people of Australia have understood that. The respected journalists have under stood that. I do not think I need to quote Michelle Grattan. I am sure all of the Labor Party people read with shame and with falling hearts what Michelle Grattan said in her article today, because they know that what she says is absolutely true. She says things such as `less wise', `wild bitter rhetoric' and `his over the top performance'. We all know that. Some elements of the Labor Party want to inflict that rage and hatred and bile on what was one of their own.

I enter this debate because it is really time that we stood up to the bullyboys. You will notice there are a couple of them on the other side. They have disappeared from this debate, but they are big people. They have loud voices. When they cannot win on their argument, they shout you down like the bullyboys of old. You have only to look through history to see what happens when good men do not stand up to those sorts of bullyboy tactics. Look through the history this century in Germany, Russia and Italy—and even Uganda in recent times—and see what happens when good men remain silent.

We have to stand up to those sorts of bullyboys. It is all about freedom and democracy. If a parliamentarian in this chamber wants to vote in a particular way or feels that he can no longer support a proposition or a principle, then it is his democratic right to vote in some other way. If it happened on our side, I cannot say I would be happy about it, but I would acknowledge that that person has every right to do that. They should be allowed to do it without being vilified, without being threatened, without being overborne.
Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you enter into this, Senator Cook. You know what I am talking about. Remember that memorable occasion that Graham Richardson wrote about, when Senator Ray gave you that riddle: What's black and flies through the air at 140 kilometres per hour? And you said, `I don't know.' Senator Ray responded, `You, Senator Cook, you f. . . ing mongrel, when I throw you out that window.' So you know what I am talking about when I talk about bullyboys and bullies in the Labor Party. If you do not know anything about it, read Graham Richardson's book. In fact, there is a whole chapter on that, Senator Cook, as you well know.
—Is that a direct quote?
—It is a direct quote. I have learnt that off by heart. I have been waiting for Senator Cook.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate, which is really nothing but a farce, talks about little tricks around the edges. I want to tell you about not some little tricks around the edges, if you are talking about Queensland, but some big whopper tricks around the edges. They are not perpetrated by the current honest, open and accountable Queensland government. They are perpetrated by the Labor Party. I must say I am enjoying myself so much that I am going to run out of time, so I will have to curtail my remarks.

I wanted to mention some things about Mr Keating, Mr Griffiths, Dr Lawrence and Centenary House. Where is Senator Bolkus? Are you still getting that—what is it now?—six per cent increase from the audit office on Centenary House every year even though inflation under this government is down around one per cent now? What an absolute rort. That is just money being transferred from the taxpayers' coffers through the parliament and into the Labor Party bank accounts. I do not have time to talk about Mr Hawke. I want to talk about Queensland and a few things that have happened there.

I see that Senator Reynolds is on the speakers list. I hope she speaks because boy, oh, boy, she and I know all about the rorts and the bribes and the allegations and the threats and the corruption in Townsville at the present time—the place where my electorate office is.

Madam Acting Deputy President, as you are from New South Wales, you probably do not know that the Townsville Bulletin reports that there is, at this very time, a federal police investigation going on into allegations not about branch stacking—because that happens all the time now with the Labor Party—but about fraud on the electoral roll perpetrated by people associated with the preselection of Labor candidates Mayor Mooney, who wanted to run for the state seat of Townsville, and Councillor Ehrmann, who wanted to run for the state seat of Thuringowa. They were gazumped by former mayor Mike Reynolds. He is no relation to Senator Margaret Reynolds, although I think they are in the same faction. They all switch about over there so much that I am not sure which faction it is. It does not matter.

There is a police investigation into suggestions that someone associated with that preselection has moved names, without the knowledge of the people involved, from the electoral role in Brisbane up to the electoral role in Townsville for sufficient time to allow them to become ALP members to vote in this particular preselection. There is a deathly silence now. Perhaps I should have started on this a little—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course you do not. You are not from Queensland. Let us hope Senator Reynolds will tell you about that. Upon that pretty dirty, vile and sleazy allegation by Labor people against Labor people, which was reported in the Townsville Bulletin , there are also the very highly publicised claims by the former member for Mundingburra, Mr Davies. He claims he was offered a $100,000 bribe by the Labor Party, and also a Pacific Islands holiday to be taken at the time the Mundingburra election was on, so that he would not stand. What a disgraceful suggestion by a Labor man of the conduct of the Labor Party. I want to clarify that in case my words were wrong. What is disgraceful is the suggestion that the Labor Party might have been involved in that—a bribe of $100,000.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to be that $100,000 is the going rate amongst politicians, although I have to say that Graham Richardson came much cheaper, and I say this more in humour. Graham Richardson reports in his book that he was able to be bought off by an entry to the Golden Wing lounge by Sir Peter Abeles, so he came cheaply. These days it seems more like $100,000 in the case in Western Australia and $100,000 plus a Pacific holiday, all expenses paid, in Queensland for a job for Mr Davies.

BREAK.PARA: This is the sort of thing that comes from a party that is in here labelling an honest, open and accountable coalition government in Queensland as being not a good one. It is an excellent government in Queensland. I am very proud of my association with Mrs Sheldon and Mr Borbidge and of the tremendous job that they are doing in Queensland. It is a real pleasure. It is a refreshing change to have that sort of government in Queensland, a government that is open, honest and accountable, so unlike what you get from the Labor Party. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an interesting debate this afternoon. As a Queenslander I thought it would be useful to put on the record some of the experiences of the 1970s and 1980s that actually brought me into the political arena. In the 1970s and 1980s I was very happy being a Methodist minister. I really had nothing to do with politics.
—We would be happy for you to be that again.
—Senator Macdonald, I must say that last night you made a speech that I agreed with every single word of, but today there were a few things you said that I found a little hard to take.
—Flattery will get you—

—Everywhere. I was very happy being a Methodist minister in Queensland until I began to find that people in my congregations were being affected by decisions and actions of the then National Party government.
—Is that when you were a member of the National Party?
—We booted you out.

—The National Party never boots anybody out, but that is another story. So let me tell you some of the story that will illustrate the motion we have before us this afternoon. It does illustrate the political philosophy of the National Party in Australia. That is why I think it is worth going back in history. Although obviously in Senator Robert Ray's mind there is the issue of whether or not there should be replacements of senators by people from the same party, there is a whole lot of other history besides this issue which I think is useful to put on the record. In 1975 I was the Methodist minister at Mount Larcom in Central Queensland.
—A good National Party seat.
—Oh, yes. There were a lot of National Party members there who were members of my church at Mount Larcom.
—There is no church there now.

—No. That is exactly right. The church is not there because of what the National Party did. That is the point I want to make—exactly the point, because they will oppress anybody who gets in their road. Not only were they members of my church; they were members of the National Party as well, but they happened to be in the road. They were dairy farmers. But the National Party decided that it was going to remove dairy farmers because it wanted the area to be mined for limestone. So the dairy farmers tried for months to get somebody to listen to them and nobody would. Finally, the minister for mines, Mr Camm, came to Mount Larcom and I went to the meeting. Those dairy farmers simply copped an hour or two of abuse from him. I was amazed because I really had not had much to do with politics before. I thought, `These are people who belong to the National Party. What is going on?'

SPEECH.PARA: Anyway, after some more months of trying to get someone to listen, they were told that they could appeal to the mining warden's court. So these National Party members, dairy farmers, got together about $9,000, which in 1975 was a considerable amount of money. They were told they could go to the mining warden's court, so they did. They spent a week in the mining warden's court telling their story. The mining warden said, `I reserve judgment.'

About three or four weeks later the day for judgment was about to arrive but, the day before, the mining warden was told by the National Party government, `Sorry, the advice that you have given and taken is only for the government. We are not going to let you tell all those people who appeared before the court the result of all the effort they put in. We are simply going to issue the licence to mine and you can go jump in the lake.' I can tell you that that is what they had to do. That is how the National Party treat their people and people who were members of my congregation. All of these people have gone but I can tell you this: none of them vote National Party any more.

Let me tell you about a current issue, the Wik issue. Let me give you some of the story of the Wik people, people who live mostly in and around the township of Aurukun in Far North Queensland. In 1975—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's recent?

—I have a lot of stories to tell. Stop interrupting. At midnight, the National Party government passed an act called the Aurukun Associates Act. This act was to enable Comalco to take over thousands of hectares of Aboriginal reserve land. That act was challenged in the Supreme Court of Queensland by the Aboriginal community, the Wik people. Their appeal was upheld. The Queensland government took them to the High Court. The appeal of the Aboriginal people was upheld once again.

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland government then took them to the Privy Council in London and, on a legal technical matter, which was that the minister for Aboriginal affairs had absolute authority to do whatever he liked, with no appeal—that was the act in those days—despite the fact that the Supreme Court of Queensland and the High Court of Australia had found in favour of the Aboriginal people, the Privy Council upheld that appeal. These are the people who have tried every way to get justice. That is the kind of justice the National Party government delivered to them.

In 1977, when I was Uniting Church director for social responsibility, I went with Rev. Gordon Coutts to see the director for Aboriginal and islander affairs, Mr Killoran. We had heard that, in one case after 70 years and in another case after 100 years, the Uniting Church was going to be kicked out of administration of Aboriginal communities in Queensland, despite the fact that those communities had voted overwhelmingly to retain that administration. I went to see Mr Killoran with Rev. Coutts and we said, `Are these rumours true?' They said, `Oh, no. We wouldn't do that. Of course not! No way would we do that.' A couple of months later, in March 1978, the minister wrote to the Uniting Church. Although the church had administered those communities for almost 100 years, they were given three weeks to get out. These are the kinds of tricks this government gets up to. That is how it treats churches that get in their road. That is how it treats dairy farmers who get in their road. That is how it treats Aboriginal people who get in their road.

Let me tell you about Bob Katter, whom some people ridicule. He was the best Aboriginal affairs minister that the National Party ever had in Queensland, and that is saying a lot. The reason he was the best is that he got rid of Mr Killoran—
Senator Boswell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —With the help of Senator Boswell. I have heard your story, Senator Boswell, and I have heard Mr Katter's story, and I put them both together. But he helped to get rid of Mr Killoran, who had run Aboriginal affairs in Queensland for decades—and run it down, I must say.
—Update us.

—All right. Let me come into the early 1970s and early 1980s, because this history is worth telling. It tells us that the little tricks played around the edges under the previous National Party government actually affected the lives of Queenslanders so much that I think you will discover at the next election they will remember the present National Party government is no different. The injustices perpetrated against the Wik people in the 1970s and 1980s have continued today. The National Party government, for electoral gain, is prepared to ride over the top of them, because it really does not care.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me tell you about Johnny Koowarta. In the late 1970s and early 1980s, Johnny Koowarta was a head stockman on the Archer Bend cattle station. He and a number of other Aboriginal people from Aurukun—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. It is an interesting history lesson, but I think in terms of relevance you would have to rule it out of order.
—Look at the terms of the motion. How much broader do you want it?
—The history of the National Party is interesting and varied and has its ups and downs—

—I really do have to say that I never was a member of the National Party.

—I was a member of the Liberal Party for a year in 1974 until I realised that they were not exactly liberal. Getting back to Johnny Koowarta, he applied with some other Aboriginal people to buy the Archer Bend cattle station. The vendor was very happy to sell it to him. It was a pastoral lease. I forget the fund from which the money was drawn, but the loan was approved and all was about to go ahead, because the vendor knew what a good cattleman Johnny Koowarta was, as were the other people who were forming the company that was to take it over.

SPEECH.PARA: When the change of lease came to be registered with the National Party government, they objected. The Uniting Church received copies of letters from the vendor. These letters were from the government to the vendor telling him that they had arranged with Comalco to take over the lease for a cattle property or for mining—or for whatever, as long as the Aborigines did not get it. The vendor was amazed at this and sent the letters to the Uniting Church. As a matter of fact, I have got them here.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember it well, Senator. As long as the buyer wasn't black.

—Yes, that is right. So the government said, `No, we are not going to register this lease.' Why? `Because we are not going to allow Aboriginal people to own land in Queensland. There is no way that will happen.' Then the Human Rights Commission were called in and the National Party government decided it would challenge the Racial Discrimination Act in the High Court. This business went on for some years, but, when the National Party government realised it was going to lose in the High Court, what did it do? It changed the pastoral lease for Archer Bend into a national park so that when the High Court found in favour of Johnny Koowarta and threw out the appeal by the National Party government in Queensland, it was no longer possible for Johnny Koowarta to buy that property because the lease had been changed, out of pique and spite, by the government to prevent him from getting any title. When finally at the end of the process of about 10 years everything was cleared for him to buy it, by that time he had died.

SPEECH.PARA: These are the kinds of tricks at the edges that many of us have had to put up with in Queensland. I agree with Senator Ian Macdonald. I really did believe that when Premier Borbidge became Premier we were going to see a new kind of government. I thought, `He appears to be a decent bloke.' But I am afraid these last few months have really shown me that nothing has changed, that he has reverted to type and we have got the same kinds of tricks, not only at the edges but, I have to say to you, at the centre as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —In this wide ranging debate this afternoon on the tricks that the National Party of Australia gets up to, senators have been recounting their experiences of the tricks of the National Party in their own states. I want to take up my time in the debate this afternoon by recounting one of the more extraordinary tricks that the National Party's rump in the Northern Territory has been up to in recent times. The National Party rump is represented here by the now Hon. Grant Tambling, former esteemed National Party whip and now National Party frontbencher as a parliamentary secretary.

SPEECH.PARA: This is what the National Party has been up to in the Northern Territory. This involves a very well publicised trick that involved the grant of a very large amount grant of money, over a quarter of a million dollars, to a company owned by a person who was closely connected with a member of the CLP—they still have the `Country' in their title in the Northern Territory, Senator Boswell; you should have kept it in yours.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that advice. I will bring it up at the next conference.

—Yes, Senator Boswell. This is best encapsulated and laid out in the dissenting report of the Northern Territory parliament's Public Accounts Committee, which I will quote from. I will not quote the report in its entirety but I will quote from the relevant sections of the report that lay out this story. The report says this:

SPEECH.PARA: DISSENTING REPORT
Introduction

The Northern Territory Parliament Public Accounts Committee has again failed to carry out its duties. It is disappointing that CLP members of the PAC have again demonstrated their partisan participation with this committee.

In this case when the issue of grants totalling $343,361 were made to a company owned by the then Speaker, now member for the Northern Territory's wife, the Committee refused to deal with the following issues;
1. What were the procedures and processes behind the grant application.
2. What were the procedures and processes that led to the grants being approved.
3. What conditions and or outcomes were in place in relation to the awarding of these grants.
4. What procedures were in place to monitor the financial accountability of both the transfer of funds and the acquittal of funds.
5. What assessment was made into the quality of the product and what was the outcome and or benefit to the Northern Territory for this significant donation of taxpayers funds.

It must be noted that while $82,000 was disclosed in DID's annual report the $261,361 was never made public in any annual reports, budget papers or press release. It should also be noted Mr Dondas and his wife had previously come under scrutiny by Parliament in relation to their financial dealings with the NT Government.

In December 1993 a motion of censure was moved against Mr Dondas, the then Speaker of the Legislative Assembly. An action never before brought against a Speaker in the NT. The motion related to Sovereign Gold Enterprises Pty Ltd, a company owned by Mr and Mrs Dondas that had produced a coffee table book about the NT. The point at issue was the admission by Mr Dondas that not only was there a large amount of government advertisement in the book, around $200,000 to $300,000, he also admitted personally to soliciting advertising from government departments. This admission was only outdone by the admission that he not only then turned around and sold the book to government departments, he also used his position as Speaker to buy the books off himself to give away as protocol gifts! The faster he could get rid of a print run the quicker he could go back and collect the advertising money for the next edition.
As would be expected, the censure motion was defeated on party lines.
It should be noted that the grant of $343,361 had occurred at around the same time as taxpayers' funds were going to the Dondas book.

You would therefore expect that when this second issue arose that potentially raised questions involving at least abnormal procedures in the approval of the grants through to potentially public corruption, you would expect the Committee to deal with it seriously. While Mr Dondas was not a shareholder or Director of North Australian Film Corporation (NAFC) the property he lived in was owned by NAFC and he did declare he had a beneficial interest in the property. With this in mind you would expect the PAC to undertake a thorough investigation of the issue so as to assure Parliament, and territory taxpayers, that what was a very unusual situation was in fact carried out in an appropriate and accountable manner. Only by carrying out a detailed investigation and reaching clear conclusions can the issues of favouritism and corruption be laid to rest one way or another. Mr Dondas is now Member for the Northern Territory, and it is a shame that the CLP members of the PAC have failed to pursue this issue to a clear resolution—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: BOSWELL

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy Speaker: there is a standing order that does not allow a member of this house to reflect unfavourably on another member of parliament. INTERJECT.PARA: There is another point of order as well, if you want to consider another one, and that is relevance. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: COLLINS

TALK.START.PARA: —On that point of order: it has no validity at all. There is no allegation of impropriety against Mr Dondas whatsoever. Can I repeat the last words that I read out from the report:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . members of the PAC have failed to pursue this issue to a clear resolution so . . . can either be laid to rest once and for all; or proven.

It makes no allegation against Mr Dondas. It simply raises the issues and says that they should have been pursued. In respect of quoting from the committee report, we do that all the time. For your benefit, Madam Acting Deputy President, and committee members, I will be finished in about 30 seconds. I will go straight to the conclusions of the committee report. I do not intend to read out the intervening pages.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rule that there is no point of order. As Senator Collins said, the report was drafted very carefully. It did not reflect but was very carefully crafted. —I suspect that the opposition members did not draft this themselves. The final paragraph states:

SPEECH.PARA: The only reason I can see why CLP members would not want to reach a conclusion is that this would prove the impropriety and corruption in relation to these grants.
The Investigation—
and these are the facts relating to these tricks—

On 28 March 1996 the PAC held a public hearing, one issue discussed was that of the International Project Management Unit (IPMU). The committee had requested IPMU to provide details of all projects that had been managed by IPMU. This was requested in order to give the committee an overview of IPMU's activities. During the hearings, questions were raised about a certain project involving IPMU and NAFC. The witnesses had not provided any information on this project, their excuse was that they had not considered it a project that fitted their specific definition of "managed" even though it would seem obvious to any reasonable person that the PAC's request for a briefing on all projects of IPMU was a wide ranging request and not a restricted request.

The specific omission of this particular project from the briefing raised Opposition concerns as this project involved grants to a company owned by the wife of the then Speaker of the NT Legislative Assembly and now member for the Northern Territory. The committee sought assurances that information regarding IPMU and NAFC would be provided, while this assurance was given in actual fact it never occurred.

Following the March hearing the committee sought information from IPMU on a number of occasions. The committee seemed to be progressing very slowly and any attempts to reconvene the public hearing were resisted by government members. The committee did finally agree to call in the Auditor General to get advice on what documentation and evidence would be required to clarify the issues raised by the committee.

The Auditor General gave clear information on what was required and what should be available to settle concerns about the propriety, process and outcome of a government decision to give over $340,000.00 in what could easily have been seen as a potential conflict of interest situation at least, and at worst outright political corruption.
Following the briefing
"The Committee resolved to write to the Department of Asian Relations, Trade and Industry requesting the following;
1. Submissions, documentation and correspondence from North Australian Film Corporation to Department of Education in relation to the two grants
2. A divisional business plan for 1994/95 for IPMU.
3. Proposals developed by the Department for Cabinet approval of grants
4. Departmental recommendations to Cabinet.
5. Departmental assessment of the proposal
6. Paper trail of payments of grants (claims, authorisations, documentation, acquittals).
7. Post evaluation of the project.
8. Annual plan submitted to AIDAB.
9. Documents showing receipt and distribution of funds from/to the Indonesian Education Project Trust Account and the acquittal of funds.
At the committee's next meeting on the 11 October Mrs Braham—
the chairman—

attempted to have the minutes changed in relation to the list of items required from DARTI. This was not successful, however the committee was then informed that the letter to DARTI requesting information, as agreed at the previous meeting, had not been sent, the Chairman informed the committee "that he had some difficulty with its content."
Mrs Braham then moved that only items 1, 2, 5, 7, 8 & 9 be now requested, after debate and some slight variations, government members passed the motion with dissent from Opposition members.
Finally, on 18 October the list of questions were sent to DARTI. The questions and their answers are as follows . . .

What then follows in the dissenting report is 15 questions and the answers to those questions. They form the core of the dissenting report which I am quoting from today. They clearly show that cabinet gave its approval to $340,000 worth of grants first and that proposals were developed afterwards for the project.

The answers also reveal that all documentation held by the government relating to the receipt of funds for this project was no longer available. I add that this is contained in the majority report and has been published in the Northern Territory News. So I can allay your concerns, Senator Boswell?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you doing it here? Why don't you send us the paper?
—Senator Boswell, I will send you a complimentary copy of the Northern Territory News . Thank you for your interest.
—Are you on commission?

—No, I am not, Senator O'Chee. The answers also reveal that all documentation held by the government relating to the receipt of funds for this project was no longer available. As the report points out, this is hard to believe given that Northern Territory Treasury is meant to retain accounting tapes for seven years and departments are required to wait six years before destroying accounting records.

SPEECH.PARA: The report also points out that the public accounts committee, which is dominated in numbers by the CLP government, never gave any consideration to calling any principals of the film corporation before the committee and that no attempt was made to call in any of the accountable officers re the destruction of government records.
The conclusion of the dissenting report, which is quite short, states:
CONCLUSION
At the beginning of this report I outline what issues needed to be addressed I now detail those issues and the answers, to the best of my knowledge.
1. What was the procedure and process behind the grant application?
There was no procedure, at the most a direct verbal request.
2. What was the procedure and process that led to the grants being approved?

Within the confines of the Cabinet room CLP ministers gave $261,361 to the then Speaker's wife's company, illegally from the Trust Account, in such a way as to avoid any public or parliamentary scrutiny.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 3. What conditions and or outcomes were in place in relation to the awarding of these grants.

SPEECH.PARA: None. Even after the pilot program was shown to be a waste of money they approved a further $82,000.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 4. What procedures were in place to monitor the financial accountability of both the transfer of funds and the acquittal of funds.

SPEECH.PARA: None. While a single paragraph audit statement was provided, you would have to question the adequacy of this in light of the fact that this project was 100% taxpayer funded to a private company for a project they initiated.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 5. What assessment was made into the quality of the product and what was the outcome and or benefit to the Northern Territory for this significant donation of taxpayers funds.

SPEECH.PARA: The only assessment provided said the product was very poor. As far as benefit to the Territory for this investment of taxpayers funds, there seems to be very little to show for it.
In any circumstances where special deals are done that don't go to tender, governments need to explain very carefully, and publicly.
I don't know who could argue with that.
When grants are given that are not through the normal process, this must be explained even more carefully and publicly, and still may attract some criticism.

But when significant grants are made in secret by Cabinet Ministers to the wife of the Speaker, where no announcements of the decision are made public and the funds come, illegally, out of a Trust Account so as to be beyond normal Parliamentary scrutiny, this can only be described as corrupt.

And it is signed by the opposition members of the committee. I point out, and it is an important thing to point out, that at the time these events occurred—and they all involved the education department of the Northern Territory—the then minister for education responsible for all this was, in fact, the now Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Shane Stone.

That is when this process became interesting, in a quite unprecedented way—which I think will probably attract the interest of some of the academic parliament‐watchers and, no doubt, a paper will be written on it. What then happened was the dissenting report that I have just quoted from was, in the normal way, prepared by the table office of the Northern Territory parliament with the majority report.

I have no hesitation in saying this, and I do not apologise for saying it: one of the reasons that the Northern Territory parliament, in terms of its processes and procedures, is as impeccable a parliament as any parliament in Australia, is that the Territory parliament has had the good sense to draw its clerks and clerk assistants from the Senate, as the clerks assistant at this table know. In fact, the current clerk of the Northern Territory parlia ment, doing a very commendable job, was an officer of this Senate, as was his predecessor. I know the clerks will correct me if I am wrong but I think I am correct in saying that his predecessor was at one time Black Rod of the Senate.

The table office prepared the reports. They were printed. They were in the normal fashion—majority report, dissenting report, ready for tabling. What then happened was the chair of the committee, Mrs Braham, went to the clerk and asked the clerk, `How do you separate the reports?' What she meant was physically separate them—actually pull them to pieces. The clerk said, `Well, normally you don't'. And I can tell you there certainly had been no precedent for this ever in the Northern Territory parliament, and I suspect none here.

The clerk said, `Well, you don't normally do that'. The chairman then pressed the matter—and this, I might add, is a matter of public information. The clerk said, I am sure quite correctly, `Madam Chair, if you wish me to do that, would you please give me those instructions in writing.' She subsequently did and a letter was written by the chairman to the clerk instructing him to physically separate the reports. So staff were engaged and a great deal of staple removing was entered into. The staples were physically pulled out of the report and the reports were physically separated, and then rebound as two separate reports.

The chairman of this committee—and this was astonishing; you talk about tricks—with absolutely no notice to the committee—which had in fact finished its job, produced its report in the way that we do in Senate committees constantly, and the report had been printed for the committee—with no further reference back to the committee and none to the opposition members of the committee, then tabled the majority report only, in the Northern Territory parliament. It was an absolute ambush. No‐one knew that this was going to happen. Of course, pandemonium ensued—and it has all been reported on the front page of the Northern Territory News. In fact, I will send you all the issues that cover this, Senator Boswell.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am finding this absolutely fascinating.
—Good. Let me tell you, Senator Boswell, any senator would, because this was truly astonishing. I ain't finished yet; you ain't heard nothing yet.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Senator interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well I have got five minutes; I will do it in time. There was also a fairly astonishing motion moved to expunge the parliamentary record—which I have never seen before, either. When this got sprung on the unsuspecting members of the committee, pandemonium ensued. The opposition then moved a censure motion—and this is from the parliamentary Hansard of the Northern Territory—in the following terms:

BREAK.PARA: I move that so much of standing orders be suspended as would allow me to move forthwith the following motion:
I move that the following words be added at the end of the motion:
"And that this Assembly
(a) censures in the strongest possible terms the Chief Minister for
(i) breach of statutory obligations placed upon him as minister for education during the 1991/92 financial year by the financial administration and audit act; and
(ii) breach of trust;
(b) further condemns him for his failure to adequately disclose these activities under the control of his administration; and
(c) expresses concern that the facts and circumstances of these breaches are prima facie evidence of official corruption."
The Chief Minister was seen to be running about with a great deal of agitation, and the government then moved the following motion:
Mr Speaker I move
That wherever the words "official corruption" appear be withdrawn and expunged in so far as they refer to any member of this assembly.

That is the most all‐embracing expungement of words. In other words, whenever any member of the Northern Territory parliament got up and said `official corruption', you could see their lips move but no sound would come out by order of the `chief dictator' of the Northern Territory.

It sorrows me to lay these facts before the Senate, which is still a democratic house. I point out to honourable senators that the Northern Territory parliament is a unicameral parliament. It is a single chamber; there is no upper house. It also has a very undeveloped committee system. That is not a criticism. It is a small parliament, which I was proud to be a member of for 10 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was your role?
—I was the Leader of the Opposition—over the last 20 years, if you remember, Senator Macdonald, a permanent role in the Labor Party.
—Senator Collins, you might like to withdraw the word `dictator' that you used earlier.
—Does the word `might' give me an option, Madam Acting Deputy President?
— No, I do not think so.
—I thought it might not. I withdraw. I could have really insulted him and called him the little dictator, because he is actually quite short.
— Please withdraw.

—I will withdraw that as well. I was actually asked by an interviewer the other day, because of my time as Leader of the Opposition, what I thought were the major differences between a chief minister I had high regard for, one Paul Everingham—I know it is a dirty word in Queensland, Senator Boswell—the former president of the Liberal Party. I said that the chief difference between Paul Everingham and Shane Stone was that Shane Stone was shorter.

BREAK.PARA: However, it was a dark day for democracy in the Northern Territory in real terms. These events that I have referred to are unprecedented. I cannot find any precedent in any parliament in Australia for them. I certainly cannot find any precedent for a dissenting report, authorised by a committee, being refused to be tabled in the House. The thought of table office officers labouring away pulling staples out of a printed report and then not seeing that report tabled is quite astonishing.

It was a bad day for democracy in a single chamber parliament in the Northern Territory. I do not think it reflects any great credit on the chief minister that did it. I think it was a short‐sighted and very immature and unwise precedent to establish on the books of the Northern Territory when you have members and senators down here—and I still will—standing up here and defending the integrity of that parliament, or at least trying to. (Time expired)
