Of course, history shows that there was only one. What Senator Schacht did not tell you was that there was also a member of the jury who was a member of the Labor Party and another member of the jury who was a union official. But did Senator Schacht tell us those things? Of course he did not. That is the standard of disclosure that we get from the people on the other side of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should be in gaol; you keep defending the old crook.
—The real reason for this debate was the deep shame that those on the other side—
— Order! Senator Conroy, I think you should withdraw that comment.
—I am not impugning anyone in the house. I withdraw.

—The motivation for this debate today is the deep sense of shame that the Labor Party felt up in the dining room the other night when Senator Ray was displayed on the 7.30 Report in all his glory, dripping bile and vitriol and hatred about Senator Colston. Even the Labor Party realised that that parliamentary performance was one of the most embarrassing performances ever to occur in this chamber. It was all about bile, vitriol and hatred.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party was so embarrassed by the whole thing—I am sure Senator Ray got a phone call from Mr Beazley saying, `What the hell do you think you're doing up that end of the building?'—that they had to resort to the good old Labor Party tactic of `when you are found wallowing in the mud, the first thing you do is reach out, grab somebody else by the legs and pull them in with you, have a mud bath'. This is the standard of Labor Party political propriety. It is the propriety of the mud bath.

This sort of politics is not something that is unknown in the history of man. I think John Milton described it very nicely in the 17th century. Senator Ray gave me cause to open up my copy of Paradise Lost. Senator Ray's performance reminded me of the performance of Satan when he rocks up in heaven and, as Milton says, `there with the companions at his fore, overwhelmed with floods and whirlwinds of tempestuous fire', he decides he is going to give a rallying speech to the troops. I will tell you what Satan said—and you could almost put it into the mouths of some of the people on the other side to encapsulate the deep level of political thought and propriety in the Labor Party. Listen to these words and you will hear the words of the Labor Party in this debate today.
What though the field be lost? All is not lost; the unconquerable will, and study of revenge, immortal hate, and courage never to submit or yield; and what is else not to be overcome?

Forget about parliamentary propriety; forget about decency. We can have immortal hate. We can have study of revenge, unconquerable will. These are the rallying cries of the Labor Party. It is all so well encapsulated by Milton when he concludes:
In arms not worse, in foresight much advanced, we may with more successful hope resolve to wage by force or guile eternal war irreconcilable to our grand Foe.

That is what the Labor Party is all about. It is about the politics of hate. The grandmaster has just walked in the door. The Labor Party is about the politics of hate. Every day opposition senators get up with yet another spurious allegation or personal slur. Those of us on this side of the chamber are quite used to it. Those of us in the National Party are quite used to the same old furphies being rocked out time and time again.

I think it would be appropriate, given that Senator Carr has claimed in this place that the performance of the Labor Party is all about integrity, that we actually examine the integrity of the party that sits opposite us. I think the track record of Labor would be very intriguing indeed. These are the people who try to clothe themselves in the cloak of integrity and respectability.

What respectability was given to the integrity of the Income Tax Assessment Act by the former Treasurer of this country who did not bother putting in his tax return for two years? Absolutely none! But it did not matter because he was so good at these things that they promoted him to be Prime Minister.

Remember—Senator Calvert, you will recall—the grand architect of the Labor Party's strategy in the years of both Prime Minister Hawke and Prime Minister Keating was former Senator Richardson. What was the hallmark of Senator Richardson's time as a cabinet minister? You have to remember that this is a man who swore on oath to uphold the high office of a cabinet minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Whatever it takes.'

—`Whatever it takes.' Thank you, Senator Calvert. That was his political maxim—whatever it takes. Former Senator Richardson had a particular regard for the truth because he saved it for particular occasions. In his autobiography he actually admits it—he admits that he was a liar, that he frequently lied in parliament during the time of his office. But the grand redeeming feature for the Labor Party is that he was very good at it. It does not matter what you do in the Labor Party provided you are good at it. Former Senator Richardson admitted that he was one of the best liars they had. That is the standard of the people who sit opposite who want to come and make allegations against us.

SPEECH.PARA: We could go into some of the other things they have done. Those people want to talk about shady deals. Unfortunately, we have a time limit on this debate. We could go on forever about shady deals. Let us talk about a shady deal that former Prime Minister Keating did with one Warren Anderson. Warren Anderson was given FIRB approval—

TALK.START.PARA: —They're quiet now.

—They are very quiet now, Senator Newman. Warren Anderson was given FIRB approval to sell the Tipperary Station to Indonesians. That was at the same time that Mr Anderson was busy selling French clocks to Mr Keating at a discount—a bit like the Demtel man: `But wait, there's more.' It is well known that these people would do any deal they possibly could.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us talk about some of the other ones. We had the wonderful spectacle—and Senator Boswell will well recall this—of the former Prime Minister being caught out on some of the claims he made about his purported piggery deal. Senator Calvert, who has a big interest in primary industries, especially looking after pig producers, would be well aware that there was a plan that was hatched between Mr Keating and various Danish interests to circumvent the quarantine laws of this country by bringing in imported Danish pig semen and genetic material.

Senator Boswell will recall that we uncovered in an estimates hearing through an FOI process a minute of a meeting in which all of this was recalled—a meeting between Mr Crean and the Danish agriculture minister to make it all possible. But the words were deleted. Senator Boswell, you will recall you and me fronting up to the estimates hearing with two copies of the same minute—one with the words deleted and one with the words not deleted. When I put it to Senator Cook that the words that had been deleted under the FOI process were `genetic material and live embryos', he said, `That is an outrageous and scurrilous suggestion. You have absolutely no evidence for that. You are a despicable person. There is no evidence for your saying that.' I said, `There is indeed.' He said, `Table it.' I said, `Okay, I seek leave to table this, which is the same document without the words deleted.' Then he refused me leave.

That is the standard of propriety on that side of the chamber. They were caught out, clean bowled. There they were saying, `We want you to give us the evidence, but we are not going to give you leave to table it in parliament.' That is the standard of the people opposite. That is the standard of their respect for the high office they held for 13 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Prime Minister who was in one place and claiming TA for another?

—We had a Prime Minister who was in one place and claiming travel allowance in another. But that was all right because he was living here at the time—and these people want to talk about rorting travel allowance! What an appalling hypocrisy from these people. They were led by the man who lived here and claimed travel allowance on the basis that his house was in Sydney; he was here claiming TA. And these people come into the chamber and try to allege that Senator Colston is somehow some massive rorter of the system! We know who the massive rorters of the system were. The Labor Party did, too. That is why they promoted him to be their leader.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, all of this squealing and carrying on from the other side of the chamber is not about improving parliamentary propriety and is not about the constitution. What this is about is that the people on the other side have realised that their political tactics of the last couple of days have gone well awry. They realise that the people of Australia are pretty much disgusted by the sort of performance that we have seen from those opposite.

A charitable person would say that their performance this afternoon in this debate would be a little bit like the passengers on the Titanic trying to rearrange the deckchairs. I would disagree. The performance we have seen from the Labor Party is more like the passengers on the Titanic having an argument as to who is going to get the deckchair beside the pool. The ship is sinking and these people on the other side are not aware of it. There is the iceberg, it is going by and they are saying, `Gee, that's a magnificent view.'

They actually think that the tactics they have indulged in over the last week are in fact good parliamentary tactics. They think that it somehow increases the standing of the parliament in the community. What they have done is irreparable harm to this parliament and irreparable harm to the institution of the parliament; yet they come in here, clothe themselves in self‐righteousness and say that they are somehow standing up for tradition and standing up for the constitution.

Senator Calvert and Senator Newman, who are both from Tasmania, will recall the respect the ALP had for the constitution in the Franklin Dam case! They misused the constitution. They misused the external affairs power to override the government of Tasmania because it suited them.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about John Devereux?

—It is obvious that it does not suit Senator Mackay. She has decided to interject; the thought has obviously just crossed her mind. It is well known that when a thought crosses Senator Mackay's mind it is the shortest trip in Canberra. The standard of the interjection we have just heard proves that.

SPEECH.PARA: What I was rather hoping we would have this afternoon was some sort of edifying debate brought on by the opposition in general business. Honourable senators may not be aware that the parliament gives Thursday afternoons for general business to the opposition in the Senate, which is their opportunity to bring forward for debate matters of great importance. It is their opportunity to bring forward for debate their own private member's bills so that they can lay out before the Australian people what their vision of Australia is.

What do we get? We get this morally and intellectually bankrupt motion from Senator Ray which he did not even have the courage to come and speak on himself. Instead, he gave it to the C team. He got Senator Schacht to speak on this motion on his behalf. Then we had the likeable and garrulous Senator Bob Collins, who added absolutely nothing to the discussion of the motion before the chamber but at least was entertaining. That is more than we can say for most of what we have had from the Labor Party for the last week.

This is a very interesting diversion, but this parliament could be debating matters of great significance. If the Labor Party thinks the greatest matter of significance that they can come up with is grabbing somebody else by the ankle and pulling them into the mud bath with them, it is a reflection on the Labor Party; but it is not a reflection on those of us opposite. We were forced to come and debate this motion. We said that we would come in and debate this motion. If the Labor Party are embarrassed about some of their goings on, they ought to be. They ought to be embarrassed about a lot of their goings on. They ought to be embarrassed, for example, about the Ravenshoe timber mill saga.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, don't bring that up!

—Unfortunately, Senator Boswell, I will have to bring it up. The reason why nobody has been charged and nobody ever will be charged is that the Labor Party sent the brief off to the Director of Public Prosecutions and it sat there for six years until the Labor Party were turfed out, by which time the statute of limitations had expired and nobody could be brought to court.
—What are you talking about?

—What I am talking about, Senator Conroy, was a massive rort of several million dollars of taxpayers' money syphoned out of one timber mill in North Queensland and sent down to a timber mill in New South Wales, I believe with the implicit support of the then Minister for the Environment, which is why the Labor Party claimed that they had no evidence of where the money went and had absolutely no proof that it had even been rorted. Of course, everybody knew that millions of dollars had disappeared.
—Even the Democrats wouldn't cop that one.

—Not even the Democrats would cop that one. The standard of oversight by the Labor Party government was so good in those days that they did not even notice that an $800,000 veneer mill had disappeared from the Ravenshoe timber mill! It is not exactly as though a veneer mill is something you put under your arm when you walk out of the factory in the afternoon. Senator Heffernan would know that a veneer mill is a very large piece of machinery. It was worth $800,000. It just disappeared out the back door. But that is nothing new.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators who were here during the construction of Parliament House will recall the deals that were done between the Labor Party and the unions. This site had a fence around it to stop things being stolen from the site, but it was one of the conditions of employment that the back gate of the fence always had to be unlocked at any given point in time. Senator Heffernan might be interested to know that there was one particular occasion down in the basement when one of those very large industrial refrigerators was delivered—one of those huge stainless steel refrigerators. It was brought in on a truck and bolted into the floor. Several hours later people went back to find that it had been unbolted, put on another truck and driven out the back gate. This was in the time when the Labor Party, then in government, was doing deals with the union movement over the running of the construction of Parliament House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, cut it out.

—Senator Carr says, `Cut it out.' Oh, Senator Carr, but that the Labor Party had cut it out when they had the opportunity; but they were too busy looking after their union mates—and these people come in here and try to lecture us on parliamentary propriety!

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose this has been a very interesting and entertaining debate, but I will close by giving honourable senators a vision of what entertainment was for the parliamentary Labor Party in Queensland when they were in opposition. The parliamentary Labor Party in Queensland used to have regular little faction meetings in the Red Garter strip joint. But they were not too clever about it, because some of the people who turned up would pay for their entertainment at the Red Garter with their union credit cards.

How did this come into the open? It came into the open because the Cook inquiry started investigating rorting in the union movement in Queensland just prior to the 1989 election. The very first thing that the Labor Party did when it got into office in Queensland was close down the Cook inquiry. It closed it down because it was worried about who else might have had a credit card and gone to the Red Garter strip joint.

We are getting a lecture from people on the other side who used to have their parliamentary faction meetings in the Red Garter strip club and they have the audacity to come in here and lecture about parliamentary propriety. They ought to hang their heads in shame.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been informed that, under the new resolutions that were passed in the Senate the other day, the time for the debate has expired. In fact, we have exceeded the time that was allocated under the new rules.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 February, on motion by Senator Woodley:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take note tonight of the annual report of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, AWRAP. The role of AWRAP is to improve the performance of the wool industry by bringing together the promotion of wool and wool products and research and development activities. It is more practical for AWRAP to pursue these ongoing promotional research and development activities distinct from the immediate and short-term need to sell the stockpile, which is now down to 1.8 million bales from the 1993 level of 4.2 million bales, and to clear the debt, which is presently around $900 million down from $2.8 billion in 1993.

BREAK.PARA: Wool promotion clearly must operate within the world's trade access environment. It is in this trade access area that the Minister for Trade, Mr Tim Fischer, has made substantial gains, with more to be done in 1997 and in subsequent years. It is certainly a priority of this government to obtain sustainable reductions in wool trade barriers.

The Deputy Prime Minister has already demonstrated a strong commitment to trade liberalisation and the government is aware, as is the whole industry, of the enormous benefit to wool growers of tariff and quota reductions. The first of these was the 1996 reduction of tariff barriers to Mexico, which was good news because it had the potential to provide enormous access to the high value United States market, which is presently highly protected with significant quota levels and import duties applying to wool apparel and to greasy wool. China also has high levels of tariff protection, which range from 15 per cent for greasy wool to 45 per cent for apparel.

India, another major and emerging market for Australian wool, imposes a massive 52 per cent tariff for almost all wool categories. Just two weeks ago, the Indian minister for textiles was in Australia and discussions took place between him and the government. The Indian minister indicated then that he would make representations in their budget deliberations, which are presently going on and, I understand, are presently before the parliament. I expect some good news to be forthcoming from India that their level of tariff protection will be reduced, which is very important and would be very good news because it is an emerging market of great importance to us.

These three countries—India, China and the United States—will be the focus of the government's efforts over the next 12 months. These three markets currently consume about a third of Australia's wool production and, therefore, even modest improvements in trade access would be greatly welcomed by the industry.

I am sure senators would realise that the textile trade is always a two-way operation. Therefore, it must be remembered that successful outcomes in trade negotiations depend partly on Australia's willingness to liberalise domestic trade restrictions in textile and clothing industries. Obviously, we are an importer of textiles and clothes. Therefore, the sort of perspective placed on Australian trade access to other markets must be seen in light of access to our own market.

At the wool round table meetings last year, a number of recommendations were made to the government, including the changes of future stockpile management, on which the government has acted. It was agreed that in addition the Wool Council and AWRAP would develop a framework, including potential additional funding plans for the wool industry, to address issues of how to increase demand for wool through promotion.

Presently, the International Wool Secretariat spends around $75 million on promotion, being by compulsory 3½ per cent levy on growers. The continuation of this levy is something that the industry will be debating. The framework of how the levy is imposed will also be debated in the next few months because the original enabling legislation setting up AWRAP in 1993 said that, whilst the present arrangements would continue on after June 1997, they would have to be subject to industry review.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 February, on motion by Senator Ian Macdonald:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Antarctic Foundation Annual Report—1995-96 contains some aspects under the heading of `Support for educational projects' which are of particular interest to those of us who are Tasmanian. Amongst those items two projects are named in connection with the Royal Tasmanian Botanical Gardens: Royal Tasmanian Botanical Gardens—Display Antarctic Plants; and Royal Tasmanian Botanical Gardens—Construct Prototype Sub‐Antarctic Plant House.

SPEECH.PARA: This report is highly commendable in relation to the work of the Australian Antarctic Foundation generally but, obviously, in relation to those two projects specifically. I am pleased to note that the foundation does use its funds in these sorts of ways to support what are significant and imaginative projects.
In particular, I will speak about the Royal Botanical Gardens project. I noted with interest, under the chairman's overview, the paragraph that deals with this issue which says:

The Royal Tasmanian Botanical Gardens developed a particularly impressive project for consideration by the Board. This project creates a Sub-Antarctic environment within the grounds of the Royal Tasmanian Botanical Gardens for the study, display and propagation of plants from Macquarie Island. The Gardens already have a significant collection of vegetative material from past trips to the island. The Sub-Antarctic House will feature Macquarie Island murals and recreate some of the island's attributes as well as providing significant information concerning the Sub‐Antarctic environment. The display will be viewed by over 300,000 people a year, enhancing their knowledge of this most significant location.
That is very good news for the Royal Botanical Gardens and, as a result, very good news for the people of Tasmania.

For those of us who live in or who have visited Tasmania and the Royal Botanical Gardens know that those gardens are the second oldest botanical gardens after those in New South Wales. The botanical gardens in Tasmania have the oldest living trees, which date back to 1828. There are many reasons for the planting of those trees, but certainly the colonists in Tasmania were keen to have reminders of where they came from—particularly those coming from the United Kingdom—in terms of the sorts of trees that were planted.

The conifer collection is the largest public collection of conifers in the Southern Hemisphere. It includes 40 species which are literally on the verge of extinction in their country of origin. Clearly, this is a very important area in terms of ensuring the continuation of these species. The gardens are clearly capsules of biodiversity and they have links with botanical institutions worldwide. This, of course, ensures a flow of knowledge on plant protection and conservation.

BREAK.PARA: As was indicated in the report, last year 310,000 people visited the botanical gardens. These gardens are very important for our tourism industry and as recreational facilities for the people who live in Hobart.

Unfortunately, a crisis is facing the botanical gardens. It is with great sadness that I say that a deadly virus has arrived in the gardens which is killing a number of the trees to which I earlier referred. It is very sad, but 13 large trees have already died, and numerous small ones are dying. Tasmanian people have rallied to combat this crisis by trying to raise funds to save the gardens. This is a very worthwhile project and, hopefully, we will be successful and the gardens will be saved. If that is the case, the work funded by the Australian Antarctic Foundation will not have been in vain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank the Senate for its indulgence. I thought this was a report worth bringing to the attention of the Senate, as a number of these reports just slip by. This report covers an area predominantly in Queensland, an area very close to my heart. It looks at a large number of issues which affect the wet tropics. These areas are so fragile and currently are in such pristine condition that one must be careful of disturbing their equilibrium, otherwise we will lose them for all time.

SPEECH.PARA: Just briefly going through the issues associated with the state of the wet tropics at page 20 of the report, we see that the issue of land clearing again is highlighted. Undoubtedly, land clearing has an adverse effect on the environment and on the regrowth of any new vegetation in that area.

The report goes into other issues too—and I must say that I was not aware of all of these until I myself started to read the report—such as diseases threatening frogs and cassowary populations. This is certainly of interest to Queenslanders. As my colleague Senator Reynolds knows, the cassowary is a rare species of bird living in the North Queensland wet tropics which is very much under threat. However, unless this sort of report is out there and being circulated, people do not realise the difficulties that are being faced.
The other one that I want to draw to the attention of the Senate is the papaya fruit fly.
Senator Mackay interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Please, Senator Mackay.
—Please, Senator Mackay. I can assure you it is no laughing matter in Queensland.

—No, it is not. We had major difficulties with an outbreak of the fruit fly in North Queensland only at the beginning of last year. This is a threat not only in Queensland but also to the rest of Australia. So it is something that has to be taken very seriously. This report draws the attention of this Senate to that problem.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other things. The cane toad and its spread are damaging the environment, damaging other species and withdrawing the rights of other species to survive, particularly other species of frogs. My colleague from North Queensland Senator Reynolds would know this is a major problem that is not only experienced in Queensland. Now there are reports of the spread of the cane toad to other parts of Australia. It is a threat that is taken seriously by departments of industry and agriculture in other states because it threatens the livelihood of farmers in those states.

Last but not least, I just wanted to draw the attention of the Senate to the survey on page 28 of the report which refers to the pleasingly high level of acceptance that the wet tropics world heritage area has now got among the public and the ongoing support that I hope we will get from the government in maintaining these wet tropics areas for our future generations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity to speak on the annual report of the Wet Tropics Management Authority, particularly because I would like to pay tribute to the work of its first director, Mr Peter Hitchcock, who has recently retired. He played a very significant pioneering role in establishing the Wet Tropics Management Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not an easy job to head up an authority which has at the political level a number of political masters and, indeed, mistresses. At one stage a woman minister, Ros Kelly, was responsible for the Wet Tropics Management Authority. It is not always easy, when you are pioneering an area like wet tropics, to have to answer to a number of political representatives. State, federal and local representatives, the business community and the tourism community all were concerned about how the Wet Tropics Management Authority was going to balance the demands of the world heritage values, indigenous rights, tourist interests and farmers' interests. It was quite a challenge for Mr Peter Hitchcock.

I would like to put on the public record not just the thanks of the people of North Queensland but the thanks of the people of Australia for the very good work he did. He demonstrated considerable patience and tolerance in dealing with such a wide range of competing interests. He tackled that role with considerable dedication, tact and diplomacy. I can assure you, Mr Deputy President, that when you are trying to balance competing interests it does take considerable effort and I think we should record our appreciation of his work.

My colleague Senator Hogg, in speaking to the report, did identify some very serious problems that are mentioned in the report. I note that some of my southern colleagues were quite taken aback by the problems that we have in the wet tropics. The disappearance of frogs and cassowaries is a very serious issue because it indicates to us that something is not right in terms of the environmental standards within the wet tropics. There is too much land clearing. There are quite serious threats to these species. The papaya fruit fly is extremely damaging and of concern for primary industries. We have had to take very specific action over the last 12 months or so.

BREAK.PARA: In terms of the standards that must apply in managing a world heritage area, I would have to say that I believe that Senator Hill's intentions are honourable. I think that, as an environment minister, he does have a commitment to his portfolio and to his responsibilities. But, as an environment minister, like Mr Peter Hitchcock, he has all kinds of pressures placed upon him. I know that many people in the north are concerned about the level of commitment of the coalition government to maintaining high standards on protection of world heritage.

We have in North Queensland a very unique area where the wet tropics meets the Great Barrier Reef marine park, so we do have a very unique area for protection. Some of the decision making processes and initiatives that have been taken in the last 12 months do put at risk those standards. I would urge other ministers to give support to Senator Hill when it comes to protecting those unique areas of world heritage. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to enter into this debate on the report of the Wet Tropics Management Authority and thank my Queensland colleagues Senator Hogg and Senator Reynolds for their genuine concern about the cassowaries, the papaya fruit fly and the frogs. Like Senator Reynolds, I was a little concerned about the giggling of some other members of the Labor Party, but I guess they do not understand the things that are particularly important to this very fragile area of North Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hogg mentioned cassowaries. I want to say to him that his concern is certainly mirrored by our concern. I am concerned; Senator Hill is concerned; and the government generally is concerned. We are particularly concerned that this very rare bird could be in danger of extinction unless management plans are introduced.

I spent the period over New Year driving along the Black Mountain Road speaking to people about a cassowary colony up in the Black Mountain area behind Cairns. We will be trying to do something about that in conjunction with the ARK group in Kuranda, the Association for Regional Kuranda, which has an interest in that cassowary colony. I know that Senator Hill is aware of that, and he will be working a way through that particular problem.There is a management plan in the cassowary colony at Mission Beach, and we will be drawing on their experiences in looking at other ways to assist the cassowary population in North Queensland.

I do not need to say anything more about the papaya fruit fly than what Senator Reynolds and Senator Hogg have already said, except to agree with them on their concern. There was also a concern about the frogs, which are facing extinction. The cane toad is a real menace, and it is something we really have to—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a predator.

—It is a predator. That is correct. We have to try to do something about that. We are a little fortunate in the government in that, for the first time ever, we have available $1.29 billion to plough into the environment. I am a bit sorry that Senator Reynolds and Senator Hogg did not support us in getting that money for the environment. I do hope they will support us on the Natural Heritage Trust Fund Bill, which is currently before the chamber, because we really do want to get some money to be able to address these problems that have, quite rightly, been identified by both Senator Reynolds and Senator Hogg.

SPEECH.PARA: I might invite both Senator Reynolds and Senator Hogg—as they obviously have a very genuine interest in this—to work together with us on these things, particularly those things that we all do agree upon. There are some items in connection with the environment that I suspect we will never agree upon. But, for those that we do agree upon, we really should work together in a cooperative way to try to get solutions.

Having said that, I do not want to cause division. I simply say in passing that it was the view of our predecessors that the environment was a political tool to be used to gather votes as they saw fit. I regret to say that all the Labor Party did was cause divisions with their environmental policy. The wet tropics management area is a classic case in point. They thought they gained a lot of votes—and I think perhaps they did—by declaring the wet tropics management area in the boundaries. Unfortunately, they never provided any money to manage those areas.

The allocation and the proclamation of the wet tropics management area was a good idea, and is one that I have always supported—although I had some hesitation about the boundaries—but it was an argument that divided the community. We want to bring the community together. We want everyone to work. We want to put some money in so that which do not have to talk about cane toads.

TALK.START.PARA: —From your slush fund?

—I am sorry you call the Natural Heritage Trust Fund a slush fund. Senator Hogg and Senator Reynolds obviously want to join with us and do something about it. We want to consult everybody. I am pleased that we now, as a parliament and as a government, have the wherewithal that we can start doing something about the cane toad, start doing something about protecting cassowaries and start doing something about protecting those frogs.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I want to welcome Professor Tor Hundloe—I think I may have done this when I spoke before—who is the new chairman of the Wet Tropics Management Authority. He is a tremendous bloke, and I know he will have the support of all senators.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to direct my remarks to the Finance and Public Administration References Committee proceedings of the round table discussion that we held arising out of the discussion paper from the government: Towards a best practice Australian Public Service . I will quote a couple of lines from that round table discussion, particularly those attributed to the Public Service Commissioner, whom, for a while, I thought must have written the government's discussion paper because of some of the views that he actually expressed.

SPEECH.PARA: I found it interesting that in his submission the commissioner supported the discussion paper and its supposed very comprehensive content. It was certainly a different view to the one I had about it. I found it rather confusing and not the slightest bit comprehensive about what we might do so far as improving the Australian Public Service is concerned. Nevertheless, the commissioner quoted the secretary of the Canadian Treasury Board, who says:
I would say how strongly I was struck by the articulation of many of the issues in the paper.

I do not know whether he got the same paper that I got, which was one issued by the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service, Peter Reith. In the first instance, it contains some quotes from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and does some comparisons with regard to the public sector—the cost of doing things in the private sector versus the cost of doing things in the public sector.

I am quite amazed that the minister would endeavour to draw some conclusions along the lines he has done because it simply is not possible. For a start, the private sector is not required to deliver anything like the level of accountability and reporting that the public sector is required to deliver. During the course of our round table discussion that became quite evident. A number of the people who gave submissions raised those very issues.

By way of example, in Florida they contracted out the payment and distribution of the Department of Social Security benefits for the dole and other beneficiaries. Two years running overpayments amounted to something like $126 million per year. That went unno ticed for two years. When the government found out, it endeavoured to take the company that was contracted to do that work to court.

Ultimately, the court found that the government had changed its policy and had changed its level of payment, but in the contract the company had an obligation to a certain format of computer program. The company had not been advised and the company was not obligated to change. Not only did the government lose the money in additional payments; it was subsequently ordered by the court to pay another $63 million in damages. Contracting out services is not a straightforward exercise.

I wish to look at another matter in terms of the discussion paper itself that was also quite evident in the views of the people we had at the round table discussion—and there were varying views. A quote was attributed to the Prime Minister, who said:

The Australian public is very fortunate that over the years it's had a federal public service that has been distinguished by two characteristics. The first of those characteristics is an extremely high degree of integrity and honesty . . . The other characteristic, of course, is a very high degree of professionalism, and a willingness over the years . . . to give comprehensive and, on most occasions, pretty zealous technical advice.

The Prime Minister endorsed a statement and then it goes to a number of points, one of those points being a strong commitment to the community and a responsiveness to government. That is what the Public Service is designed to do. It is designed to be responsive, with a strong commitment to the community.

That is one of the fundamental issues which is then overlooked on the very next page. It is very clear on page 9 of this document where the government is headed with regard to how it is going to deal with the future of the Australian Public Service. It says in the third paragraph:

A responsiveness to governments and public accountability are equally important. The APS will continue to be responsible for ensuring that the delivery of programs and services accords with the public purpose set by government. To this end the APS will retain the role of oversighting service delivery whether it is undertaken by specialised APS agencies (such as the proposed Department of Social Security/Department of Employment, Education and Youth Affairs Shopfront), new authorities outside the Public Service Act (such as the Public Employment Placement Enterprise) or—under contract—by private or non-profit organisations. This continuing role is central to the maintenance of accountability to the Government, Parliament and the Australian public.

We know what the government is proposing to do with regard to work for the dole. As we understand it, it has proposed to hand that responsibility over to non-profit organisations. But it all comes back to the questions that were raised in the round table discussion about accountability and about the cost of delivery in terms of the reporting obligations.

The very point I want to make and will continue to make to the government is that you cannot compare the cost of operation in the public sector with that in the private sector. It is a very simplistic view when we in this place require so much accountability and reporting back from the public sector. Those obligations are not placed on the private sector. Therefore, a cost comparison is basically misleading and is something we should not be doing if we are committed to properly delivering services to the public.

If, as the Prime Minister says, that is something we should do, then we cannot take this flippant approach and say, `It is three times cheaper to do it through the private sector.' That is simply not the case. I would say that there are numerous examples of where much of the public service in other countries has been privatised. In the case of the UK, there is now significant regret, even within the conservative government, about the steps they have taken with regard to privatising much of their public service.

I read some very interesting articles in the British press with regard to bus services. They have bus services now that are totally privatised. You have all the buses running at peak hours—five buses bumper to bumper—and then no buses for three or four hours. What sort of a service is that to the public? If we are to spend taxpayers' money, then surely we have an obligation and a responsibility to ensure that the service is available in an equitable way and to all of the people.

The other aspect of what has happened in the UK is accountability. There is no mechanism for somebody who has a complaint against the service being provided other than to complain to the person that is actually providing it—the private sector provider. There is no mechanism to go to the government or to the opposition parties and raise concerns. The response from the government will be, `You have to see the person delivering the service.' There is no role of government, no real accountability and certainly no responsibility on the part of the government. Look at some of the comments made recently by Max Moore‐Wilton at a recent conference here in the ACT. We certainly know his view of the Public Service. He would not have one.

As was indicated in the letter to the minister which accompanied the Hansard of the round table discussion, we look forward to the government developing a white paper. I am very surprised and saddened to see statements by the government and the minister that they are intending to avoid what is currently award coverage and, indeed, proper negotiations with regard to workplace agreements or enterprise bargaining. They are going to head down the road of stepping around the current Public Service Act and endeavour to put people on individual contracts. I hope that at the end of the day they will take account of the circumstances they find themselves in and ensure, as the Prime Minister said, that one of the key principles of the Public Service is the ability to deliver to the public a service that is good and reliable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this same report because I share some fairly strong concerns, having read the precursor of this—the discussion paper entitled Towards a best practice Australian Public Service . I do not think the round table report that has been tabled here this evening in any way resolves many of the issues. It is my view that the original document was predicated on the view that there is something wrong with the Australian Public Service.

BREAK.PARA: My colleague has quite clearly drawn out the fact that there is a real difference between the Public Service and the private sector. The Public Service is there to serve the public. Whilst efficiency and effectiveness are important, the needs of the public are supreme. This may mean in some way sacrificing certain so-called economic rationalist efficiencies which might be perceived by the economic rationalists out there in our society.

Some of the best practice that can be applied in the corporate sector might not necessarily be able to be applied, and undoubtedly cannot be applied, in a public service that is serving the public. After all, that is what it is there for. The corporate sector is driven by profit, whereas the public sector is not and should not be driven solely by the economic rationalist theory of profit.

In my view, the approach of the document shows no compassion for the employees or clients of the service. If the clients do not fit the needs of the business, the private sector can ignore them; however, no such option is available to the Public Service. The Public Service is there to serve the public, regardless of what they might think of their client base or how they might want to treat their client base.

Best practice cannot be applied cold heartedly and dispassionately as in the private sector. I think that is a telling difference between the private and public sectors—that the best practice which is applied in the private sector, whilst it meets the profit motives of the people who run the private sector, cannot be dispassionately and heartlessly applied in the public sector. The service provided by the Australian Public Service is of the highest quality. That has been the subject of ongoing review over a long period of time.

The original discussion paper talked at page 22 of revitalising the Australian Public Service. I think that was, in some ways, a slur on our public servants and was completely unwarranted. Part of the vision of the government, undoubtedly, is to make the government more efficient and cost conscious by outsourcing. Whilst outsourcing might be good in economic rational theory, in practice it does not necessarily all go well in government. The government have already flagged things such as IT and many other functions of government being outsourced. This will lead to massive job losses within the public sector.

I have grave concerns about the path of Towards a Best Practice Australian Public Service when the path that the government contemplates advocates best practice not based on best service to the public but on least cost to the government. I think that is the telling factor in this whole thing. It will end up being an exercise in being cent wise but dollar foolish.

I believe that the government should tread very warily. An example is the sort of thing that was tabled in both the Senate and the House of Representatives yesterday: the joint plan by the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives—a headline today in response to that read `Jobs at risk in parliament plan'—to fold the joint parliamentary divisions into the Department of the House of Representatives and the Department of the Senate.

This highlights the fears that come out of Towards a best practice Australian Public Service: that, in the end, this is an attack on jobs, on lifestyle and on people's ability to earn a legitimate income. It was flagged in the proposal that was put before the Senate and the House of Representatives yesterday that, over time, it would see people not necessarily made redundant but just drifting out of the system. In my view, this is not an acceptable way for the government to act.

The government has a responsibility to people to be in the job of employing people and to see that people are utilised well in the best interests of the Senate and the House of Representatives. But, at the same time, the government must not be preoccupied with, or focused on, a purely economic rationalist approach which sees people reduced to nothing more than mere statistics in the unemployment lines.
I commend this report to all members of the Senate. They should read it closely, and the government in particular should take no solace from the things that I have just spoken about.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 February, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —When I last spoke on this report into the abolition of the development import finance facility, I spoke about the cavalry coming over the hill—that was how the inquiry was seen by one of the people in attendance at the lengthy inquiry we had. This evening, in the few minutes that remain to me, I wish to focus on the fact that one of the important recommendations that came out of this inquiry was that the government should look at establishing a replacement program for the DIFF scheme because there was no doubt in the evidence that was heard before the DIFF inquiry that there was a real place and real role for a scheme to operate similarly to DIFF, if not the same as DIFF.

SPEECH.PARA: While DIFF was an aid based scheme, the scheme that was required was one that gave concessional finance to exporters to make their mark in markets overseas. With the withdrawal of the DIFF scheme, this facility was withdrawn from those particular exporters, primarily small business people in Australia. So the community that was hurt by this decision of the government was in effect its own electorate and its own constituency: the small business community.

One of the recommendations in the majority report was that the government establish a mixed credit scheme based on these criteria: that it be primarily a development scheme; that emphasis be given to projects of a humanitarian, poverty‐alleviation or environmental nature; that all projects be nominated by recipient governments; that it be integrated into AusAID's bilateral program for individual countries; and that all projects be open to competition amongst Australian companies.

The need for such a scheme is purely and simply based on the evidence that came before us, that the part of the marketplace vacated by us has been taken up by other nations, be they Norway, America or Japan. They are making use of mixed credit schemes to see that their small business communities have a launching pad to get into some of the burgeoning markets, particularly in South‐East Asia. Of course, that is where the main thrust of our DIFF program was.

The government's response to the report was: `Thank you, but no thank you. We don't want to have anything to do with it. We don't want to have a part in this. We have shunted that off to another inquiry, and we might see you in a couple of years, thank you very much.' That is no consolation for the small business operators in Australia who were getting a kick‐along as a result of the DIFF scheme.

But the majority report went one step further and recommended that the percentage of projects under the green DIFF component, in any new mixed credit scheme, be raised to 40 per cent. So there was a balanced approach in the majority report. But what did the government say to that? Again, it said, `Thank you, but no thank you.' In its response, the government has not addressed the issues involving many small business companies that were at the leading edge of technology and innovation in exporting to South‐East Asian countries. All we see now is that that has been put into the too‐hard basket. It has been put on hold. Golden opportunities are being missed or wasted by the lack of initiative of this government to take something that was a success and run with it. The government's response is a failure in itself and, indeed, should be recognised as such.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment on the government's response to the report of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee on the abolition of the DIFF scheme. I concur wholeheartedly with the remarks of my colleague Senator Hogg, who was a member of the committee that I had the privilege to chair.

SPEECH.PARA: The DIFF scheme was an excellent scheme. That was clearly acknowledged in all of the evidence put before the committee by industry and by people who in many cases came from the constituency that strongly supported the Liberal and National parties in recent elec tions. It was quite clear that they were very disturbed about the attitude adopted by this government in unilaterally abolishing the DIFF scheme.

As I have said, the DIFF scheme was an excellent one because, on the one hand, it provided very well targeted aid to countries in our region and, on the other hand, through the use of mixed credits it enabled Australian companies to be involved in those projects and to gain some benefit from that involvement.

The majority report sets out in some detail the way in which the scheme operated. It also sets out that Australia, in having such a scheme, was able to be a participant in the development of aid projects for countries in our region alongside and in competition with other countries. Many other countries, particularly European countries and some of the more wealthy Asian countries, such as Japan, have long used similar schemes as part of their aid program—in many cases in far more restrictive ways than the DIFF scheme operated.

The government's unilateral decision to abolish the scheme saw Australia opting out of this type of provision of aid and putting forward no replacement. Therefore, many Australian companies are suffering. They are suffering because they have invested a lot of time and money in the program to be cut off at the 11th hour by this decision. Also countries in our region made known very clearly to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) their attitude in opposition to this decision of the government.

The minister was then forced to review his decision to provide a limited opportunity for further projects to be approved. The minister was forced to back down in the face of significant complaints from our neighbours in the region and from industry. Notwithstanding that limited backdown, many companies—after having spent a lot of time and money developing projects, getting through almost all of the stages of the process—found that they were not able to complete the process and proceed to have their projects approved.

One of the majority recommendations was that companies holding letters of advice be given approval. The government responded to that saying that, if they changed their mind now, it would be a breach of their election commitment, as they had made an election commitment to abolish the DIFF scheme. One of the election promises that this government should have broken was this one, because it was a dumb promise to abolish a scheme that was working very successfully. It was providing aid, and it was providing Australian industry with opportunities to develop their export business throughout Asia and the region.

The government runs back and hides, saying, `No, we made a promise. We cannot change our mind,' when in every other area they have broken promises—in health, education, funding to the ABC and so on. After having broken those promises in those areas, what did the government do? They set up a review. We saw it in education. They slashed education funding and then established a review to see how things were going to operate. It is the same with the ABC. They took $55 million out of their budget and then set up the Mansfield review. That, in many cases, demonstrated that this government's attempts to virtually destroy the ABC and its independence were quite wide of the mark.

Similarly, in the area of foreign aid and the operation of mixed credit schemes, the government set up a review. They set up the Simons review after they made the decision to abolish the DIFF scheme. As is noted in the government's response, they have rejected a number of the majority committee recommendations. They said, `We have the Simons review which is looking into the possibility of a replacement scheme and will see what future arrangements should apply in this regard.' They say that they want to await the outcome of the Simons review.

It has been stated on a number of occasions that the Simons review was going to be an exercise which would result in a report early this year. Certainly, the clear indication in the government's response No. 2 is that any new arrangements could not be introduced before 1997‐98, which is the financial year coming up. When we suggested the Simons review terms of reference might be expanded, they said, `Oh no, we can't do that, because we have to get this review completed so we can get a decision—a report—on how these things should be constructed in the future.'

Madam Acting Deputy President, as you will recall from the estimates committee hearing the other night, when officers of AusAID were questioned about how the Simons review was proceeding, and when we were going to get the report, we were told, `Oh, in the near future; in a month or two.' It is early March. In about two months time, we are going to have the budget delivered in this parliament. The budget negotiations are already under way, but there is no sign of the Simons review on this very important area of overseas aid and the way in which aid may be delivered through mixed credit schemes such as DIFF was.

As was clearly acknowledged at the estimates committee the other night, we are not likely to see the report and certainly not likely to hear any response from the government on such a report before the budget. So what is going to happen is that because that review has still not been completed, there will be no proposals forthcoming from this government which would in any way be able to operate for the forthcoming year 1997‐98. So the government, once again, have failed miserably to deal with this problem that they themselves created. That is, they abolished an excellent scheme that was operating very well. There is certainly nothing forthcoming at the moment and there will be nothing forthcoming that could in any way operate in the coming financial year. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Community Standards Committee Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 February, on motion by Senator Tierney:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —This report, The betrayal of violence in the electronic media , is one report that should not escape the attention of anyone. I noted in perusing the report that it talked about community concern. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The strong support expressed in submissions for a reduction in the amount of violence shown must be seen in the broader context of community attitudes generally and of the shocked reaction in the wake of the Port Arthur massacre.
The report went on to state:

Public opinion polls conducted after the mass murders showed that up to 68 per cent of those surveyed favoured more restrictions on violent movies, videos and video games and 75 per cent of voters believed violence on television was excessive.

Whether or not one agrees with those survey results, there is not doubt, out there in the broader community, that there is a real concern about the violence that is being faced by people today and, of course, the effect that violence in the electronic media has on others in inciting them to violence themselves. It is worth while then turning to the conclusions of this report where the committee, among other things, says:

The Committee recognises that the community needs "true stories" and "dark stories" as well as happy tales. Violence is often part of the former and must be portrayed. The evidence before the Committee suggests, however that the community questions the graphic way in which the violence is conveyed and the frequency with which the electronic media offers violent portrayals for consumption. It expects government action on this issue but it also expects professionals in the electronic media industry to assume responsibility for reducing the volume of anti‐social messages conveyed in programs and film.

I think that is spot on. I think that reflects totally the community attitude out there. There is a real concern. Whilst the community identifies that government has a role to play, the community also recognised that the media has a role to play in this as well. This is the frightening part of this report, because it then goes on to say:

As technological advances make more electronic images and information easily available, the problem of reducing exposure to violent portrayal becomes so complex that it can only be dealt with by a concerted effort at international, federal and state government levels.

So it is something that should not be wiped away by the presentation of this report to this Senate. It is something that needs continual addressing, because it is going to be an ongoing concern out there in the real world. The committee report concludes inter alia:
. . . a reduction in the volume and levels of violent images that can be received in homes and schools around the country.
That is one of the important things that needs to be addressed. It continues:
The result may be a safer and more peaceful environment for all.
One would hope that at the end of the day that is what we will be able to achieve. The last recommendation in the report is on page vi. It says:
The Committee recommends that the Australian Broadcasting Authority review the number of viewer complaints about the amount of levels of violence shown by television networks in order to:
(a) highlight those television networks showing the most violence
(b) encourage a reduction in violent programming by linking it to the commercial television licence reviewing process.

I would hope that at some stage when such a review takes place, we can monitor in an ongoing way this crucial issue to the people out there in the wider community. I commend the report to all senators. I believe that it is something that should be given a bit more attention than just being tabled in the Senate and then lost forever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak, but I really think I should compliment my friend on the other side of the chamber for his remarks. I think Senator Parer would share the same view that I do that Senator Hogg is quite correct in saying that we do have to counter the level of violence and indecency which is appearing in the electronic media. I take this opportunity to raise my concerns about it. I think Senator Hogg would probably appreciate these points.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies refers to pay television, but what is of concern to me is the convergence of electronic media. We will soon have a situation where the distinction between the Internet in terms of service providers and pay televi sion will become very blurred. We will soon get to a situation where it is possible to order video on demand over the Internet. The technology for compressing digital signals is now so good that in Singapore I even saw CD video, which is a little CD player, just like an ordinary CD player that you would use for music—you can use it for music—with a standard size CD that contains a whole feature length movie. We are not talking about a big bulky laser disc. We are talking about a standard size CD containing a video compressed version of a movie.

It will soon be possible to download feature length movies on demand over the Internet. Whilst it is likely that there will be a charge for that and, therefore, people will have to use a credit card or have some other means of paying, it worries me that you may well have a situation where these service providers are offering free samples of violent or pornographic movies, which could be downloaded at no cost. I really do believe that we have a major challenge in terms of maintaining standards of decency. It is not, Senator Hogg, like the movies when you were a boy or when I was a boy or when Senator Parer was a boy.

TALK.START.PARA: —There's a bit of difference in our age; have a bit of respect for your elders!
—I offer you an enormous degree of respect, Senator Hogg.
—He's old enough to be your dad.
—Senator Gibbs, I do not know whether he would like that interjection.
—No, I don't.

—He does not like the interjection, Senator Gibbs. I shall not ask you to withdraw it, suffice it to say that Senator Hogg does not look old enough to be my dad. The point is that it is the graphic nature of the description of violence which is of significance. Senator Parer, you remember the old‐time Western movies. The cowboys would shoot the Indians and they would fall off the horse and that was it. These days we are treated to a person riding around in agony. We are treated to the blood and intestines hanging out of the wound and the whole gamut of it. I am not a wowser. I really do enjoy the old Arnold Schwarzenegger movies; I think they are funny.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some people who are particularly impressionable, and we have to consider how they are affected by the proliferation of this material. I suppose it is not any one particular movie but it is the enormous extent to which the material recurs that creates the problems. When I was a kid, you used to see a scary movie, you would have a nightmare and you would forget about it because you might only see one a month or one every couple of months. If you are seeing the same sort of material over and over again—

TALK.START.PARA: —It desensitises.

—As Senator Parer says, it desensitises the individual. I believe that it is important that there be a concerted effort. I believe that that concerted effort must also be aimed at Internet service providers and it must be aimed at the availability of video Cds, video tapes and a whole range of material which is currently available or will be available if we are to maintain the standards of decency which the vast majority of the people of Australia—well over 60 per cent or 70 per cent—would like to see prevail in this country. As everybody in this chamber knows, 51 per cent can be a political landslide. Sixty per cent or 70 per cent is more than that; it is an earthquake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies, a report of which has just been the subject of comment, I would like to make a very brief intervention. I congratulate Senator Hogg and Senator O'Chee for their remarks and for highlighting the report that is before us.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee has done a lot of work, as you would appreciate, on this matter. Through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to Senator Hogg, I would say that we are dealing with this matter on a cross‐party basis. I think that there has been unanimity on everything that we have done in this area. The government should understand that when they respond to the committee's findings. Frankly, I am looking forward to hearing that response from Senator Alston very shortly. I would hope that he would understand that the committee's report was unanimous and that there are a variety of views on the committee.

The committee has a very hardworking secretariat—Roxane Le Guen, the secretary, and Kate Tremble, the executive researcher. Senator Tierney is the chair of the committee, and Senator Reynolds is the deputy chair. Members of the committee are: Senator Denman, Senator Knowles, Senator McGauran, Senator Troeth and Senator Stott Despoja and me.

The committee agrees with Senator O'Chee that the interaction of various media and what might or might not occur with on-line services, the Internet and so on, are very important issues. I would like to confirm what Senator O'Chee has mentioned and urge honourable senators to let people know about the current inquiry into on-line services which we have been charged by the Senate to investigate.

The committee will undertake the inquiry into computer on-line services in Australia. In particular, the committee will examine: recent technological developments in computer on-line services, including blocking devices suitable for use by parents and teachers to prevent minors from accessing undesirable material; the implications of these changes for regulatory systems currently in place; progress on the development of codes of practice by providers of on-line services, including ways in which those providers can take community standards into account in a deregulated environment after June 1997; the efficacy of recent measures taken by the federal, state and territory governments to prevent the exploitation of minors through the Internet; and a review of recent international developments in on-line services and their regulations.

The committee has detailed information and most of us are familiar, in all events, with some of the matters that Senator O'Chee mentioned. I congratulate Senator O'Chee and Senator Hogg for raising this issue in the chamber.

BREAK.PARA: In conclusion, we have been asked by the Senate to table a report on this reference on or before 26 June 1997. The purpose of my getting up now is to urge all honourable senators to have a look at the terms of reference and to spread them around widely, because we would be very grateful for information and submissions on this particular matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 February, on motion by Senator Margetts:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade has, for a period, reviewed our relationships, particularly our trade relationships, with many of our regional neighbours. This report is an excellent contribution to that process.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things the committee did at the beginning was to have a discussion about which country or countries could be looked at in order to highlight the problems that Australia and Australian service providers might have in breaking into markets in Asia. This report is significant because it draws our attention to a whole range of weaknesses in our arrangements, and those who came before the committee showed us their successes in trade in services.

This report is also very significant because of the important employment aspects that it has for Australians throughout the country. I think it also allows us to see various regional advantages that some areas of Australia have and how, from evidence we had, some people with enterprise had opened up markets.

In particular, we were looking at Indonesia and Hong Kong. We selected those two places because they were different markets. They were markets where I think we in the service industry in Australia, the largest sector of our economy, could learn lessons that would assist us in looking outward to our region and developing trade.

BREAK.PARA: Australia's trade in services has grown strongly during the 1980s and 1990s. Trade in services accounted for 20.5 per cent of total trade in 1984-85. By 1995-96, this had increased to 22.7 per cent. Exports of services have grown at almost double the rate of service imports. In 1994-95, service exports were valued at $20.4 billion and, in real terms, contributed 21.3 per cent to total exports for goods and services.

The percentage increases to some 40 per cent when embedded services—those bundled in with goods—are taken together. Although it is difficult to define in some cases a service and the goods that are attached to a service, nevertheless it shows in those figures how important it is to our economy. The service sector makes a critical contribution to the domestic economy and economic development. Services directly comprise some 70 per cent of gross domestic product and more than 70 per cent of the work force. So, as I say, it is absolutely critical to our job creation programs and the needs to overcome unemployment as it is in Australia.

While the committee and many others applaud these international trade achievements by the service sector, there is little room for complacency in the evidence that came before the committee. The intelligent exports: ". . . and the silent revolution in services report, launched in September 1994 by the then Labor Prime Minister and jointly commissioned by the government and the private sector, revealed that only a small percentage—1.2 per cent—of Australian service companies export. When you consider the fact that 1.2 per cent of companies are doing it, then you realise how serious that is as far as Australia is concerned. Unfortunately, we have the need to get a cultural change as far as service companies are concerned, because that 1.2 per cent represents only about five per cent of Australia's total service capacity.

The proportion of service exported does not compare well with some of our key competitors. When we look to others we find that Singapore has 69 per cent of its services in exports; Hong Kong, 19 per cent; the Netherlands, 17 per cent; France and the United Kingdom, 10 per cent; and New Zealand and Germany, nine per cent. So our Kiwi cousins are doing far better than us in the service sector area. Australia's service export proportion rate equals Canada's five per cent, is slightly ahead of the United States—four per cent—and more than double that of Japan.

In seeking the reference the committee chose Indonesia and Hong Kong markets for investigation for a number of reasons, as I have said. Both markets have strong growth rates in the service sector and are attractive markets for Australian exporters. These two markets provide a contrasting challenge for Australian business in service exports.

The committee also felt that there were lessons to be learnt from the Hong Kong experience which would assist Australia's exporters to Indonesia. So, in choosing both Hong Kong and Indonesia, we felt that we would be able to benefit from the differentiation between the two markets. Hong Kong is a mature service market, with services being the fastest growing sector of the economy, accounting for 83 per cent of the gross domestic product in 1995. In looking at Hong Kong, to a large extent one is also looking at China, since a substantial part of Hong Kong trade is eventually linked to China. Indonesia is a net service importing country. The potential for service exports to Indonesia from Australia is significant. More generally, Indonesia is recognised as one of Australia's most important trade partners.

I do not intend to go through all the recommendations, but I would like to mention just a few of them. The committee, in drawing attention to the areas where Australia needs to lift its game, in many cases had to refer to the need, for example, for the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs to commence its promotion of the Australian qualifications framework as a matter of urgency. Another recommendation was that Australian companies adopt the policy of recruiting and supporting students with both language and professional skills to provide an important resource for Australian businesses operating in the Asian-Pacific region in the future. So those recommendations and many other recommendations are in the report, but I will leave it at that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of staff of senators and members have been distressed today by an editorial in the Australian newspaper which refers to the payment of their travelling allowances. Those staff have drafted a letter to the editor, a copy of which I have, which has been signed by staff representing the Liberal Party, the National Party, the Greens (WA), the office of Senator Harradine and the Australian Democrats. I also understand that staff of Labor Party senators and members have drafted their own letter.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, these staff have been very distressed because they do not have a public right of reply to such allegations. They have drafted this letter to the editor which obviously they hope will be published. It is obviously an issue which affects the staff of all senators and members. On their behalf, I seek leave to incorporate a copy of this letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—
The Editor
The Australian
Dear Sir,

Today's Editorial (6.3.97) is an unfair swipe at the use of travel allowance by Parliamentary staff and fails to distinguish between allocation of travel allowance for staff and Members of Parliament. Travel for staff is not discretionary but is at the direction and under the authorisation of the Member of Parliament.

The Department of Industrial Relations determines the amount of allowance paid to all Commonwealth employees using a formula which accounts for the average cost of accommodation, meals and transport. Travel allowance payments are also closely monitored by the Department of Administrative Services. The formula applied is similar to that applied throughout the public sector and is paid at a lower rate than that for Parliamentarians. A travel allowance system is also used significantly in the private sector.

We are required to be in Canberra for parliamentary sitting weeks—for some staff this can be up to 25 weeks a year. Aside from the disruption to family life, in Canberra we are unlikely to have access to a car or any other usual form of transport. In many instances we do not have access to cooking facilities and the long working hours don't allow time for grocery shopping let alone cooking. Cafeteria meals are not subsidised.

The accommodation allowance certainly doesn't allow for accommodation in a five star hotel and very few stay rent free! In addition, many staff are not paid travel time and frequently are required to travel to Canberra on a Sunday for which overtime is not payable.

It is widely acknowledged that political staff are not well paid and many sacrifice the benefits of a higher salary to contribute their services. There is no structured long term job security for political staff as their employment is determined on the electoral fortunes of their Member or Senator. The average salary is around $35,000. To assert that they have little compunction in rorting the travel allowance system is both unjust and churlish.
Yours faithfully,
Andrea Bell—Liberal Party of Australia
Geoff Greene—Liberal Party of Australia
Suzanne Ferguson—National Party of Australia
Alan Carter—The Greens WA
Margot Scales—Office of Senator Harradine
Matthew Townsend—Australian Democrats
