DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: David Helfgott Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the past week or so, particular sections of the Australian media have been giving a great deal of air time to criticisms of David Helfgott's ability as a pianist. Central to those reports have been the interviews with the music critic of the Boston Globe newspaper, Richard Dyer. I have now heard interviews with this gentleman on four occasions. He has been given, I have no doubt, far more national air time in Australia that he has in the United States.

SPEECH.PARA: I have now heard him in two separate interviews criticise: one, that the Schumann piece on track six of the Shine CD was being played not by David Helfgott but by Wilhelm Kempff; and, two, that the movie Shine delivers the message that mentally ill people should marry their astrologists. I now have no doubt, after hearing that interview to my great anger on national radio this morning, that Mr Dyer belongs to that large group of anally retentive professional critics who are far more preoccupied with the cleverness and the acerbity of their own criticisms than they are about a serious attempt to fairly analyse a performance.

In respect of the first criticism about the Schumann piece on track six, Mr Dyer attempted to falsely create the impression that he had discovered this as some piece of deception on the part of David Helfgott or the people who put the CD out. It is, in fact, nothing of the sort. Mr Dyer found out about this in the same way I did, by reading the liner notes on the CD. They clearly explain which musician performed every track on the album, including the fact that the Schumann piece was played—beautifully, I might add—by Wilhelm Kempff.

Would I suggest for a minute that a number of the tracks that are played by David Helfgott on the Shine CD, which I enjoy enormously as much as I enjoyed the film the four times I have seen it so far, are the best performances that I have of these compositions, most of which I love? No, of course, I would not, because a number of these tracks are played by David Helfgott on out of tune, tinny pianos with lots of atmospherics. But do I enjoy them any less for that? No; in fact, I enjoy them a lot more.
I would like to quote what Scott Hicks, the director of the movie, had to say about music and cinema with which I absolutely agree—and I love both music and cinema. Scott Hicks said:
Cinema, like music, is not primarily a medium of the intellect, it is about the emotions and agitation of the mind.

Indeed it is. That is why I love this album so much and that is why I love so much Helfgott's rendition of Rach 3. I love that composition and always have. It is over-the-top, heart on the sleeve romantic and I love that sort of music.

The intellectual music, which I listen to sometimes on the ABC at 3 o'clock in the morning, is usually punctuated by extremely long pauses and then a lot of discordant notes. I appreciate that musicians love that sort of music and that is intellectual music. The only trouble with it is that it sounds dreadful, so I do not hesitate to say that I like romantic music, I like the way Helfgott plays it and I agree with Scott Hicks. But back to Mr Dyer.

Mr Dyer's other criticism—and it was disgraceful—was that the movie attempts to, as he said in the interview this morning, deliver the message that mentally ill people should marry their astrologist. I do not know if in real life Mrs Helfgott ever was David Helfgott's astrologer, but having seen the movie and the trampoline scene, which is their introduction in the movie, the movie suggests nothing of the sort. The movie does not suggest that Mrs Helfgott ever was David Helfgott's astrologer. He met her because she was a friend of a friend.

Of course there is that wonderful line in the movie where, having met her for the first time his life, he immediately proposes marriage to her. When she expresses some polite rejection of this approach and some concern about it, he says to her in the movie, `Consult the stars.' It is a great line in the movie. It was probably never uttered in real life, but so what?

Who can possibly suggest that a movie in one and a half or two hours can be an absolutely accurate portrayal of someone's life? But it is a great depiction of Helfgott's life. It is a great depiction of his love of music, which is shared by so many millions of other people. It is a great depiction of the success, the triumph of the human spirit, as we say in real terms, of that man dragging himself back with the help of a lot of friends from the abyss of crippling mental disease to the point where his life has at least been substantially restored. He loves playing the music and the audiences love listening to it.

I have to say that, in respect of this outrageous and inaccurate slur on the movie, if Mr Dyer is as accurate a music critic as he is a film critic, then the Boston Globe should kick his backside through the top of his head and sack him because what he said about this movie is wrong. He also told a few other little fibs in this venom—and that is what it is—that he is continuing to deliver on Helfgott.
He was asked by John Highfield how the audience reacted to it, because he absolutely panned the premiere performance of Helfgott in Boston—a great music loving town, as I know. Richard Dyer said:
Courteously, as American audiences do, and with some warmth because they were responding to the myth.

Is that true? No, it is not. In fact, Helfgott got four standing ovations at that performance. The audience reaction was so spontaneous and wonderful that, having given him four standing ovations, they then flowed onto the stage of the amphitheatre to meet him.

To refer to the rest of this interview—and I said it was pure venom—I rest my case. I will not read it all out. I know a number of people heard this interview this morning on Radio National. I refer to the comments Dyer then made about people—unidentified, of course, by him—apparently physicians who came up to him and rang him the following morning after the performance and said, `Wasn't it dreadful. I have got to get out of here.' Mr Dyer said, `I felt it indecent being present.' I can suggest a very easy way out for him if he is so offended by being present—don't be present.

I was absolutely delighted to see on AAP tonight, because I decided this morning that I would deliver this speech, an article headed `"Elitist" criticism prompts rush for Helfgott tickets'. This really cheered me up. It said:
The North American public has shown its disdain for critics of acclaimed Australian pianist David Helfgott by rushing to buy the few tickets remaining for his current tour, according to promoters.
Mr Helfgott—whose life is the subject of Oscar-nominated film Shine—has 17 concerts remaining on the American leg of his world tour, of which 14 are sold out.
This story goes on to say that he had four standing ovations, and the audience got out of their seats and walked down to the stage just to meet him.

I wish David Helfgott well for the rest of his tour. I publicly thank him for all the pleasure he has given me since his emergence as a pianist. I wish him the best for the rest of the tour and would like to say to him, in much milder language than I would like: stuff the critics, what do they know?

In conclusion, while the critics in America are obviously singing a different tune from music lovers—I am pleased to say—in their appreciation of David Helfgott, as demonstrated by today's AAP report, I will use my remaining time to briefly touch on a minister in this parliament who is today singing a different tune from the one he was singing last night. In Senate question time today, Senator Herron tried to make light of a number of remarks he made at Senate estimates last night regarding the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

Senator Herron attempted today to dismiss his statements of last night that the Prime Minister was as ignorant as I was and needed to be educated after describing Third World conditions in Aboriginal communities, indeed, as being something that should not be said. I would invite anyone who believes that view to either listen to the Hansard recording or read the Hansard of last night's estimates which reveal what nonsense that is—and I will read out the final bit of those estimates:
Yes, I have got them. I just wanted to point it out to you, Minister. But the reason I asserted this is no less an authority than your leader, the Prime Minister of Australia, said—
Interjection from Senator Herron:
Yes, he used the phrase too. I will have to educate him.
Senator BOB COLLINS—He said in 1995 in a major headland statement Standing on the Headland—
Senator Herron interjects again:
It is a common misconception.
This is in respect of the Prime Minister. I finally got the quote in and quoted it. I then went on to say to Senator Herron:
Could I just point out this total discrepancy between your position on this and his?
Senator Herron replied:
Yes, I will have to educate him, Senator Collins. He is as ignorant as you are.
I was astonished by that statement, and replied:
Good luck, Doctor Herron—
which was not a slip of the tongue; of course, I was ironically saying, `Well, you probably won't be a minister tomorrow. I said:
Good luck, Dr Herron—sorry, Minister.
Any fair reading of the Hansard clearly demonstrates this was no laughing matter at all.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Baseball Proposed Nuclear Waste Reprocessing Plant: Sutherland Shire

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to make a few comments about the Sutherland Shire, an area in southern Sydney that I am and have been all my life proud to live in. Firstly, I would make some comments about a pleasing feature of the Sutherland Shire, and that is the continuation of a great sporting tradition in that shire.

SPEECH.PARA: We have already seen earlier this week the Super League Sharks beat Canberra at the start of the Super League. I have to put on the record that I am not a fan of Super League and I do not like the way in which it was established. But I can certainly say that it is good to see the local team going well in that competition. I look forward to the day when we get back to a single competition in rugby league in this country. It is unfortunate that the game has been rent with the difficulties and traumas it has suffered over the past year or two.

BREAK.PARA: Tonight I will talk about the sport of baseball, particularly junior baseball. I had the privilege and pleasure on 15 and 16 February this year to attend the state cup finals of New South Wales Junior Baseball. They were held over at Curl Curl on the north side, probably as far as away from the Sutherland Shire as you can get without getting out of the Sydney metropolitan region. In that competition the Cronulla Sutherland under‐12 team, also known as the Sharks, was represented. It was a particular pleasure, I must confess, because my own son was in the team.

The team played along with teams from Manly, the Hills District in Sydney, the Illawarra, Newcastle, and Ryde‐Hornsby. Those regions made up the teams in the finals, and the finals were played over two days. Firstly, I have to congratulate the team from the Hills that won the event. They narrowly won the event from the team from the Sutherland Shire, the Sharks, who were runners-up. I pay tribute to those teams in particular, and also all other junior teams that participated in that competition.

Baseball is a sport which is growing in leaps and bounds. It is growing because it is played with such a great attitude—an attitude demonstrated by both juniors and seniors who play this sport. One of the great things about the game is that it is a game that particularly at junior levels all children can participate in, children of both sexes can play in the same teams, and all the kids get a go. You do not have to be a star to enjoy your baseball. I particularly pay tribute to the organisers of the competition and all the players and officials because of the way in which it was conducted.

To see kids who played it hard for two days in each of their games and then, when it was all over, get out and enjoy each other's company on the field was a great pleasure. As I said at the outset, I just hope that we can get back to some of that attitude of enjoyment and love of the game of rugby league.

I also mention this because one of the coaches came up to me after the game and said, `Listen, Senator, these kids have put their heart and soul into this all year. How about getting them a mention in the Senate?' I could not say no. So I am going to mention them. These are the players and officials from that team from the Sutherland shire: the team, Peter Baker, Mark Bardsley‐Smith, Ben Black, Peter Blanch, Wayne Bochkareff, Bradley Callaghan, Matthew Callaghan, Tim Haig, Matthew Kinnear, Tod McKay, Adam Minter, Dylan Reddy, Rhys Wilson and Martin Forshaw; the coaches, Ken Saville, Bob Callaghan and Dennis Mannix; the manager, Ian McKay; and the scorer, Kathy Blanch. I think you have all done a great job and I am pleased to record it in the Senate. I know you will be as proud of it as I am.

Having said that, in the remaining five minutes I have to turn to an unfortunate aspect which could possibly take away a lot of that gloss and pleasure that we in the Sutherland shire are used to and enjoy. What we have seen in the last couple of days, again, is this coalition government wanting to inflict more distress and anguish on the people living in the Sutherland shire.

Not only are they looking at locating a 24‐hour international airport within the Sutherland shire in the Holsworthy region, but we now hear that they are considering building a nuclear reprocessing facility at Lucas Heights. What else do you people in the government want to do to the good citizens of the Sutherland shire in the electorate of Hughes? We already have the nuclear reactor. The people have within their area Australia's largest oil refinery; they have the largest metropolitan waste disposal centre in New South Wales; and this government is now seriously considering locating a nuclear waste reprocessing centre at Lucas Heights.

This is just a crazy proposition because, if the community is outraged, as it is, about your plans for an airport at Holsworthy, you just wait till you hear their outrage when it comes to this proposal. Indeed, in the other place, when this matter was debated yesterday in an MPI and was again brought up today, your own local member, Danna Vale, virtually had to be restrained from getting up and getting stuck into the lot of you. Unfortunately, your own Liberal member for this electorate is unable to do anything about this. But the community is going to do something about this. They are going to send you the message loud and clear that they are not going to put up with this proposition for a high‐level reprocessing plant which is just going to create further health hazards, further potential damage to the sensitive environment of that region and cause great distress and anguish as well as potential economic loss for the citizens of that shire.

This proposal is clearly contrary to the recommendations of the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste brought down last year entitled No time to waste. The recommendations of that committee, of which I was a member, were that Australia look at building a waste disposal repository away from suburban areas. But what is this government doing? It is actually looking at putting, in an area where there already is a nuclear reactor, another and potentially more dangerous facility to process and store on a long‐term basis nuclear waste from both within this country and overseas.

This proposal is also quite contrary to the ANSTO Act when it was amended back in 1992 because there was clearly an intention in that legislation then that Lucas Heights would not be the site for any facility which would be used for the storage of nuclear waste on a long‐term basis.

There are two issues to be addressed at Lucas Heights. Firstly, there is the issue of the future of the reactor. Whilst the people of the shire have accepted that it is there, they are not going to accept putting a new nuclear reactor there. Secondly, they are not going to accept this disgraceful proposal to dump this reprocessing facility in their backyards. The sooner the government gets that message loud and clear, the better. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to raise those two important issues tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say up front tonight that I have a passionate regard for the responsibilities associated with the use of parliamentary privilege. It has saddened me greatly on past occasions to see this being misused, particularly by some people pursuing personal vendettas.

SPEECH.PARA: I have never in my parliamentary career said anything inside this place which I would not have said outside this place without the protection of parliamentary privilege. I am not about to change that tonight. I will simply say that I would never comment publicly on my private life and I would certainly never comment on anybody else's private life.

Politics is, above all, frustrating. We all come into this place excited by the opportunities to change, if not the world, at least our society in some way. Most of us do not achieve all that we have hoped for. I felt that in 1993 when I lost the seat of Lowe and I feel that again today.

So many activities in the health area are about to burst into flower: changes to the Australia New Zealand Food Authority, the Australian Hearing Services, the Australian Government Health Service and the Therapeutic Goods Administration, just to mention a few. Some have clearly had an impact already; some are yet to do so. I am delighted that those areas are now in the very capable hands of Chris Ellison, who is not only a good friend but a very fine and able parliamentarian.

I would like to pay a compliment here to Michael Wooldridge, the Minister for Health and Family Services, who is my dearest friend in parliament and godfather to my youngest son. I would like to praise him for his humanity but also for having the courage to grasp the various nettles in the health arena and not being afraid to take some of those necessary tough decisions.

I also would like to add my enormous regard for two senior public servants in my field: Ian Lindenmayer and Mary Murnane. Both have been excellent examples of the perfect public servant—with wise, impartial views and sensible perspicacious advice. It was a pleasure to work with both of them, together with so many other public servants. The body of the Public Service is very much maligned, but it really is overflowing with very competent individuals.

BREAK.PARA: I would like in this last speech just to touch briefly upon some of the current directions of politics which really concern me. Others in this place and outside it have already mentioned the role of the High Court. I genuinely believe that, with decisions like the Wik case, our democracy is at real risk of being subverted.

Putting aside the question of the actual Wik decision, the High Court has clearly, partially at least, taken over the role of our democratically elected representatives. They now see themselves as law makers rather than law interpreters. Given their non-accountability to the people of Australia, this is a development which gives rise to enormous concern to me and I know to many others.

I also have concerns about the increasing power of the ACCC. Whilst most of us here—I think on both sides of this chamber—strongly believe in the virtues of competition, this commission really has become such a nitpicking organisation which has lost sight of the overall plan and which has the potential to hamstring some of our Australian industries. I hope they are able to raise their eyes from the small print on the desk to the broader horizons of our national future.

I had initially planned that I would leave this place last week. Although the ALP—which behaved very fairly in all of this—offered to pair me for party divisions, my concern was to ensure that the vote on the Kevin Andrews euthanasia bill was not affected by my resignation. I am delighted that Winston Crane—who was not able to be here tonight, who would have taken a different position from me on that bill—has very graciously offered to abstain from the division, although I am sure he will make his views very clear during the debate.

The issue is one which I have been very close to during my years as an oncologist, as a cancer specialist. I have no doubt—and I think many others here would share my view—that often the dose of morphine needed to relieve pain may shorten patients lives by minutes, hours or sometimes even more. I have no problem with that at all. What I have enormous problems with is the concept of legislating for euthanasia. I believe the law is too blunt an instrument for this. I have no doubts that it can potentially be open to misuse or abuse, both by the well meaning and also by the unscrupulous.
I think it is fair to say that these issues which I have touched upon very briefly—democracy, and building a competitive but very fair and humane society—are central to all of us here.

I remain very confident that the government, now just beginning its second year, will continue with the great start it has had. I sense that we are now better in touch with the reins of power. I think it took a while, after 13 long years in opposition, but I am sure that under John Howard's leadership the country really now has the ability to fulfil its potential in every sense—social as well as economic. I look forward to watching it, albeit from the sidelines now.

I would like to thank my friends and my colleagues—particularly, but not only, on this side of the chamber. I have made some very good and very close friendships. It has been very important to me. I look forward to continuing those friendships.

I would also like to thank the very many members of the public and the Liberal Party in particular who have been so supportive. The strength and the warmth of that support that we have received from all quarters has been absolutely overwhelming, and we are truly grateful. Being a senator has been a great privilege. I thank those responsible for extending that privilege to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond briefly to the final words of Senator Bob Woods in this place and to wish him well in his retirement. In some ways I think it has been a frustrating political career for Bob.

SPEECH.PARA: He was the member for Lowe from 1987 until 1993, when he left lower house politics through no choice of his own. He stayed involved in the organisation of the Liberal Party and held senior office within it. He then joined us in the Senate, where he has been for some years as well. He has not really said it—although he was generous in what he said about the role of the Senate and so forth—but I think his passion was more with the lower house.

We do find—don't we, Senator Short and others?—that we inherit some who have had that lower house experience. We like to think that it is their choice—I see Senator Tambling grinning—as the role of the house of review is a different type of politics and it has a different role within our parliamentary system. I fear that most of them, if you give them the choice, would say that they would have preferred to stay where they were. I think that was probably the case with Bob.So it has been an interrupted political career, and he leaves it again.

Bob mentioned his life before coming into politics and the time he spent as a cancer specialist. I understand that is an area in which he was held with great respect. I am told in particular of his contribution in helping set up the Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research and also the Cancer Treatment Centre at Concord Hospital.

When we look at his record as a parliamentarian, we will recall his contribution through various parliamentary committees: the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee, the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, the Joint Statutory Committee of Public Accounts and others. Therefore, he made a very willing and worthwhile contribution to our parliamentary committee system.

My memory of Bob will be particularly related to that period in which he was opposition spokesman for health, from 1990 to 1993, in which I worked close quite closely with him. It is one of those periods when we were seeking to develop the perfect health policy—as every shadow spokesperson has ever done and found that it is an enormous challenge. In the work that Bob did in the development of that policy, you could sense his passion for medicine and his passion to contribute to a better health system in this country.

BREAK.PARA: In the end, he did not quite achieve the goal that I know he would have wanted to—that is, to have the opportunity to implement health policy as a minister in this place. Nevertheless, he has played a very valuable role in the help that he has given to the Minister for Health and Family Services, Michael Wooldridge, and the help that he has given to many of us as we have had these complex debates on good health policy for this country over the years.

At the time of Senator Bob Woods's final speech in this place and his retirement, I certainly wish him well in whatever is his next career. We all know there is life after politics and Bob will prove it, as others have who have gone before him. I hope he does find another satisfying career and I also hope his family finds happiness in his retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly say a few words on behalf of the opposition in this valedictory debate. As Senator Hill has said, Senator Woods had two terms as the member for Lowe in the House of Representatives, elected in 1987 and 1990. I remember those campaigns well. I remember the nature of those campaigns. I think all who were active in New South Wales politics would have to acknowledge they were very tough election campaigns when Bob Woods won and a tough election campaign when he was defeated.

SPEECH.PARA: During the period from 1990 to 1993, when Senator Woods was the then opposition spokesperson on health, I must say that I thought he had a very tough job. It was difficult being the health spokesman at that time for the Liberal Party, and I do not think it would be a task that too many in his own party would have envied. It was tough going. I think all of us could acknowledge that it was a difficult time.

You came into the Senate, I believe, on the resignation of Senator Bishop and you have been in this place for three years. Since the election you became Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services. You have had a very substantial in volvement in a very significant range of a number of Senate committees. I am sure you have enjoyed those experiences, although I think we all acknowledge how frustrating committee work can be at times.

I did want to say to Senator Woods that I want to be honest and acknowledge that you are leaving this place in difficult circumstances, in unfortunate circumstances in terms of matters that have become well known and well canvassed in the public arena. I want to say to you that we sincerely hope that time will heal those wounds for you and all those who have been involved in the circumstances that have led to your resignation. Let me say to you, on behalf of the federal opposition, that we wish you well for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, on behalf of my National Party colleagues, would like to join the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) and the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) in wishing Senator Bob Woods the best as he leaves the parliament after nearly eight years of service. He came in in 1987. I had known him in his previous shadow ministry role. I have known him even better since he came into the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: He is fortunate, in a way, that he can go out into the community now and he can actually save lives and do a job as a doctor. He will have a good and a bright future. He will be in a position to be able to help people as he has tried to help people in his service to the parliament.

It is a difficult time for you. We all feel the difficulties that you have been going through. But, as the Leader of the Opposition said, time does heal all wounds. What is today's news wraps tomorrow's fish and chips—we have all heard that one. We hope that in two or three months this will all pass and everything will settle down and your family and children will come together and you will have a rewarding medical career in front of you and everything will come together. On behalf of my National Party colleagues, I wish you all the best. We wish you a great career in medicine. Good luck and God bless you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would certainly like to associate myself with the remarks of those who have spoken. Bob Woods is, I think, a special character in this place, not least of all because we are very fortunate when we have people who come into the chamber with very high level qualifications. To have a person who is active on the policy front is often necessary but not sufficient in this game. What you also need to be is an effective politician. I think we would all acknowledge that Bob has been steeped in politics. He has loved it as a game, as a commitment, as a public service. I think he has performed the combination of those two roles very effectively.

SPEECH.PARA: He was certainly there in the hard years in opposition. He reached the heights of the shadow cabinet and he was really, I think, in a very difficult position—not only having to solve the problems of health policy but also having to hold on to a marginal seat at the same time. He was able to bring the lessons he learnt from that experience into play in recent years in coordinating the marginal seats committee in New South Wales.

I think the real test of his commitment to public service in politics was the decision he made after he lost the election in Lowe to actually continue to pursue a political career. It is very easy to walk away, to go back to the private sector, undoubtedly with a great deal of professional promise and reward ahead. But to say, `No, I'm still attracted'—fatally attracted for a number of us, I suppose—`to the sport and science of politics and I am prepared to sacrifice the profession that I could pursue outside for the profession inside parliament,' I think was a measure of his commitment.

I am sure he feels that in a number of ways he is leaving this place prematurely, but I think we all understand why he feels the need to do it at this time. I think he should look back on his years in politics and be aware that we all acknowledge that he did make a very significant contribution to the Liberal Party—both the organisation and the parliamentary wing—that he achieved quite a great deal in the time he was here and that many of us will remember the work he did and the friendship he provided to us. We all wish him a great deal of good fortune and good health in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all sad to see Senator Bob Woods go from this place—all of us in this chamber except, I suggest, for a number of people in this place whom I think I should mention. They are somewhat relieved to see you leave this place. They are the Senate Hansard editors and reporters. I have not seen anybody in this chamber who is so rapid‐fire in his contributions as you are, Senator Woods. I am sure the Hansard writers are somewhat relieved, though themselves no doubt personally saddened, to see you leave this place. I think I have the privilege, if that is the word, of being the most fondly thought of senator, so far as Hansard is concerned, because of the slowness of my delivery. But you, I think, would have the record as the fastest.

SPEECH.PARA: Bob Woods, as we all know, has a wonderfully agile and brilliant mind. The people of Australia, I believe, owe a great debt of gratitude to Bob for his service to this parliament—not only to this Senate but of course through the House of Representatives to the electors of Lowe. I express my appreciation for your dedication to the people through this parliament and also for the job you did in this place as parliamentary secretary to Michael Wooldridge. I know that you brought a new look to things in that particular arena. You were aware of a number of things that would face health in this country over the next few years and you took the long-term view. You realised the dangers of, for example, destructive human embryo experimentation and also cloning. I think it is worth while, if I may, just to read the poem of Leunig's cartoon in the Age of 17 February on cloning of the clown. It reads:
As little Mister Curly lay sleeping in the hay
A most ambitious scientist did steal his D.N.A.
And in the dark laboratory, from microscopic shreds,
A band of little men were made with curls upon their heads.
When Mister Curly woke in fright to see that he'd been cloned
He cried, "You've plagiarised my soul" and hung his head and groaned,
"You tragic fool; your cleverness shall be your fatal weakness;
You steal from God when you do steal a living thing's uniqueness."

I don't know whether he is as good with the pen as Leunig, but Bob Woods has had that vision. I feel very sorry on that level that he is leaving us here today. I would like to add my personal regrets that he is leaving here, but wish him and Mrs Woods all the best for the future. Our support will be with you in more ways than one. I am sure that you both will make and continue to make marvellous contributions in the fields in which you are so well versed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —It was with regret that I recently learned that Bob Woods had decided to resign from this place. As his successor as parliamentary secretary to the minister for health, I can tell this chamber and the wider community of just some of the achievements that have occurred under Bob's stewardship of that position in the last 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: In his time as parliamentary secretary Bob drew on his vast experience and substantial intellect to ensure that this government's approach to health and health reform was delivering the best outcomes for all Australians. Before becoming a parliamentarian, Bob was an oncologist of note. He transferred his commitment to society into politics and he worked as shadow minister for health and a member of shadow cabinet.

When he was appointed parliamentary secretary, his responsibilities included some of the most active areas of health reform, including food regulation, medicinal products, hearing services and government health services. Along with reform and good management, Bob has been instrumental in ensuring the passage of difficult but necessary budget legislation. A substantial part of the great volume of groundwork he has done in only a relatively short time. The groundwork he has completed has left these portfolio responsibilities in good shape. I want to thank Bob for his kind comments on my succession. However, I must say that I approach it with some trepidation in view of the example that he has set before me.

I note that Bob mentioned that so many things are about to burst into flower, and indeed that is the case. I would draw the attention of the Senate and of the wider community to just some of the things that Bob has done. With the Australia New Zealand Food Authority, Bob completed the formalisation of our nation's harmonisation of food standards with New Zealand. He personally drove the debate on the introduction of genetically modified foods and oversaw the greatest reform of our nation's food hygiene laws ever. This progress pursued the overarching goal of ensuring high standards of health for all Australians while removing unnecessary burdens from industry. I say that with special reference to small business food outlets. I believe that Bob achieved a balance between a viable food production and processing industry on the one hand and consumer rights and health and safety standards on the other.

He also drove reform in the area of hearing services. With the corporatisation of the Australian Hearing Service now in hand and the development of a new voucher system for people eligible for government hearing services now the subject of legislation, Bob has brought to life the best current thinking of industry and consumers in order to not only deliver what people had been calling for but to do so in a manner which is fiscally responsible and provides quality of service.

In the area of drug regulation and supply, Australia's unique system is the envy of the world, but more than a decade of mismanagement by the previous government was taking us down the path where drug approvals were unfairly slow and the growth of the pharma ceutical benefits scheme was out of control, potentially damaging our whole health system. Through facilitating consensus and incorporating the government's overarching economic and social themes, Bob began reform which has seen the time taken for approval for medicinal products shortened without any impact on proper health and safety checks. The foundations have also been laid for restraining the growth of the PBS without restricting people's access to well priced medicines. In relation to the Therapeutic Goods Administration, a response is about to be formulated in relation to a report commissioned by Bob Woods, and I hope I do that response justice.

The reforms I have mentioned will result in quality outcomes and improvements in the health system. Although they will take time to measure and appreciate, there is one measure of Bob's effectiveness which I can relate now. In my new role as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services, I have found that consumer, industry, community and other groups all speak very highly of Bob and the work he has done. Bob is held in high regard by an enormous variety of people with whom he has worked closely. These endorsements I am experiencing from a diverse range of people and groups and they speak volumes for his effectiveness.

I am saddened to see his resignation and I am sorry that he will not see the bursting into flower of some of these initiatives that he has set in train. I am lucky to have followed him and I congratulate him on the work that he has done, and I think this should be brought to the attention of the Australian people. I have enjoyed working with Bob as a trusted colleague and I wish both him and his family well for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Heffernan, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add my remarks briefly to those of the earlier speakers as the person who chaired Bob's preselection. Tonight, on behalf of the New South Wales division of the Liberal Party, Bob, I would like to thank you for your service to the people of New South Wales, first as the member for Lowe from 1987 to 1993 and then as a senator for your state from 1995 till today.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout his parliamentary career Senator Woods worked tirelessly to represent New South Wales constituents, particularly in the inner west and greater western Sydney areas. Senator Woods had his office in the centre of Sydney, Parramatta, to provide greater access to Liberalism in what had been before the last election—thankfully no longer—a Labor area. It is very much thanks to Bob Woods and his work in that area that we achieved that result. It was Bob's key role in the 1996 federal election campaign which helped to turn the tide against Labor and saw a record win for us in New South Wales. Of 12 new Liberal seats won in New South Wales, four were won by women, including the extra seat in this house by Helen Coonan. This was done without quotas or tokens, I might add.

When people make the unselfish decision to leave the often more profitable private sector and take up the great and onerous task of public service, as I said in my maiden speech, the cost of political commitment is both high and well documented. Unfortunately, Senator Woods leaves the Senate today under unparalleled media scrutiny of his private life. The ugly Fleet Street nature of the media intrusion into the private life of a public person has set a dangerous precedent. I would like to commend the opposition for their respect for the private life of their Senate colleague, and I hope that they join with me in condemnation of the tabloids' venture into dirty backyard journalism.

As one door closes, Bob, another opens. I wish you and your family all the best in these difficult times and hope that you find a fulfilling future together, and that God's light shines upon you. Thank you, Bob.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly to wish my colleague Senator Woods well as he leaves this place. When we come to this place, we come with 75 other colleagues, many of whom remain only acquaintances for the duration of their time here. Some become friends; some become very good friends. Then there are others whose company we enjoy a lot on both sides of the chamber. Bob Woods is one of those people whose company many of us on this side have always enjoyed.

SPEECH.PARA: I was looking through the list of senators tonight who have resigned. I have been in this place less than five years, and I think Bob takes it over the halfway mark of those senators who have left since I joined this place less than five years ago. That indicates a very high attrition rate, but it also indicates some of the stresses placed on people in modern public life. In less than five years, I think 38 senators have come and gone since I came into this place. That speaks a lot of the pressure many people are placed under in this place.

I join with the comments that Senator Heffernan has made. What I regret most is the nature of Senator Woods leaving this place. When newspapers and the media have to resort to telescopic lenses to make a story for their papers, it is not the sort of Australia that I want to live in. I always understood that reporters were there to report the news, not to make the news, and that people took a career in journalism not in commentating. It seems as though every reporter wants to be a news maker, not a news reporter and every journalist wants to be a commentator, not someone who reports the facts as they really stand.

In regard to the media's response over the past month to both Senator Woods's private life and the allegations made against other senators in this place, many things have been written that are incorrect and many assumptions have been made that do the media no credit. I do not think they do Australian society any credit either. I guess it is up to this chamber or the parliament as a whole to determine how the community should react to the sorts of pressures that individuals are placed under by a media which has no respect for privacy whatsoever.

Bob, you came into this place with a very successful career. You leave at an age when I am quite sure you have time to make another very successful career. I certainly wish you well. I know that lots of your colleagues who enjoyed your company on this side will miss you, will remember you well and wish you well in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not let tonight go by without thanking Senator Woods for the work that he has done in terms of the health committees of the parliament since his arrival here. I have been in this parliament for 12 years, and I have found that the arrival of Senator Woods and Dr Wooldridge put a breath of fresh air into the Liberal Party in terms of health policy.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Woods well knows, I have had a very long, deep and abiding interest in a lot of alternative health therapies. I believe the Commonwealth need not be spending the money that it is spending if there is a cheaper and more effective way—even if it is thus untried—which is a real alternative. It was extremely refreshing to find people like Senator Woods and Dr Wooldridge who were not only interested in and aware of these alternatives but also prepared to consider those alternatives with someone with a deep and long interest in them.

It was a real plus for me when I ended up sitting besides Senator Woods. Unfortunately for him, I would chew his ear off at every question time. It was something that I really cherished. I think it has been an interesting shift in terms of Liberal Party policy in the way in which we have looked at health over the last few years.

So to you, Senator, I say a huge thank you for the contribution that you have made. You have been a terrific friend. You have been a lovely guy to work with. As I have said to everyone since the controversy broke, `Hey, hold on, I sit beside Bob, and I know the type of guy he is.' He is someone I am proud to know and proud to call a friend. To you, Senator, to Jane and your three children, I say good luck and good fortune. The time that has passed has not been easy. You must remember that you have good friends and you have loyal friends. Not only that, you have people who admire you for what you are capable of and for what you have achieved. Good luck and all the best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —I too want to associate myself with these remarks tonight. Bob is probably saying, `What the hell is Calvert getting up and speaking for?' I, like my colleagues Bill, Fergy and a few others have been disgusted with the way that you have been treated by the media. This is a club. We all get pushed together into this place, and the whole lot of us are under attack at the moment in every way you can think of by the media. I suppose that brings us closer together.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps in some ways you are lucky to be getting out of this place. You can get a job where you will not be attacked and bound to the sort of scrutiny that you have been under and which a lot of us are coming under at the moment. You know in your own heart how hard you have worked for your constituents. We know how hard you have worked for your constituents. You can hold your head high and say, `I have done my job in this place.' Whilst it has not been reported, the negative sides of your life unfortunately have. As has been said, you can get away from the place and enjoy yourself.

I have appreciated your friendship in more than one way. I enjoy your passion for Chinese food, as we do in Lee's on odd occasions. It was great to be with you last night. I think that is something that you are going to miss. That is one place where we get together. You cannot get together in here or while you are busy, but at least after the bells ring and we get away from this place we can enjoy ourselves in a social manner and get to know each other better. There is no better way to do that than representing this country on an overseas trip, as you and I did in Bucharest.

After having heard all the wonderful things that you have achieved in medicine, I must say that I do have some doubts about your effectiveness as a doctor, having been with you in Bucharest and seeing what happened after a few days. You could not even stomach a bit of wild boar; you had to leave and come home, which was most disappointing—not only for me but also for you. You worked very hard on that trip with me and I appreciated your support. I think we played our part in representing Australia in that part of the world, even though the food did not agree with you.

Like my colleagues, I wish you and your family all the best. You have a lot of your life left. I am sure you are going to make the most of it and make a very significant mark on this country that you have served so well in this place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to publicly associate myself with the comments of my colleagues and adopt those comments. I wish Bob and his family all the very best for the future.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to associate myself with the remarks which have been made. Bob was a friend; he is a friend; and he will be a friend in the future. We don't make this offer often, Bob—as you know there are very strict rules at Lee's; you have to be in the Senate to attend—but you are always welcome at Lee's. We hope that our paths cross in the future. You did have a great deal to offer this parliament and the rapid rise that you made when you joined the parliament reflected the talent and the capacities that you have. All of us here are very sad to have seen what has happened. We are appalled by the hounding of you by the press. I certainly wish you well in the future.

—I, too, would like to associate myself with these remarks. I probably have not known Bob for as long as other people in this place but I certainly welcomed him when he came and sat next to me when he returned to the Senate on the opposition benches, and I have thoroughly enjoyed his company at all times. I did read in the Australian Medical Association Journal this week of the very high regard in which Bob is held in the professional world. I am sure that regard is something he will return to after what I consider to have been unfair treatment by the media and some of the outside world during these last two weeks. I do hope that his return to spend more time with his family and to a successful professional career will embody everything that he hopes for himself. I do wish him all the very best for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add my words of good wishes to Senator Woods on his departure. We have had happy times and sad times and difficult times. I know that, whatever he and his family choose to do in the future, they will do well and I just wish him well, whatever it is.
—Bob, to you and Jane and your family, best wishes for your future.
